' how we keep our property fund open ' ; INVESTING Fund of the Week ; Brexit cause many to shut their door - but not Kames Property Income . its manager tell Laura Suter why
the commercial property market be hit hard after the EU referendum , lead to many large fund close their portfolio , effectively lock investor in . the Kames Property Income fund remain open , however . it go into the Brexit period with 33pc of the fund in cash to meet redemption request . it also impose a ` ` fair value adjustment ' ' - in effect , an exit fee - of 10pc at its peak . it remove this adjustment at the end of September . an investor who remain in the fund throughout the Brexit period to the present would have lose 1.8pc , accord to FE Trustnet , the investment analyst . however , if they have sell at the end of September , just before the adjustment charge be scrap , they would have lose 8.8pc . David Wise run the fund with Alex Walker . however , Mr Walker be leave the company in December , to be replace by Richard Peacock , who join from Aviva Investors . Mr Wise tell Telegraph Money about his view on the property market , how hold high level of cash will affect performance and the hard month of his work life . how do you manage the fund through Brexit ? we escape the bad of it and be one of the few that stay open through the post-Brexit period . but July be one of the most challenging month of my work life . while , in general , we be very focus on the individual asset , we ' re not afraid to make some big call when we need to . one of those be on June @card@ : we be sit on 33pc in cash and other liquid investment , by contrast with very low level at one or two major competitor . however , those cash level go from 33pc to 15pc at our low point in the Brexit aftermath . but about 50pc of the money that go out of the door in that panic period have actually come back in from those same investor . have you sell any property since Brexit , and what be valuation like ? we sell four post-Brexit , all either at or above the valuation we have pre-Brexit . I ' m not say we could have sell every asset above pre-Brexit level , but we believe small asset be more resilient , and those four sale be the hard evidence of that . what ' s the outlook for the UK property market ? Brexit do cast a shadow . across the market as a whole valuation be down by around 5pc , but that mask some variation . if you look at London , perhaps the area most expose to Brexit , valuation fall have be great , although there have be some underpinning from the fall in sterling . London tend to lead the cycle in real estate , and London be get pretty late in the cycle , so one ca n't see rent rise much further . London be a very expensive place , but it be likely to get cheap , although I do n't see it fall off a cliff . in general , we be buy in location that be fundamentally cheap and can give us high income return , typically in big northern city such as Manchester and Leeds . how do your investment strategy differ from your peer ? we invest in property worth around £5m-£20m , so small asset than our peer . the return and liquidity at the low end of the market be more attractive . it mean we will never be able to take the fund beyond £1bn , so we ca n't become one of the big fund , but we do n't want to . do you worry about the effect of high cash level on performance ? our cash level be currently 30pc . if I be hold hefty cash level for five year it would be very damaging to return , but I do n't anticipate that we will have 30pc cash well into next year . I be happy with that cash level . it provide some buffer if there be any more article @card@ bump in the road , but it also give us firepower to take advantage of opportunity . we tend to do a lot of buy around Christmas , when other people in the property market put their foot up . do you have your own money in the fund ? yes . I do n't want to say exactly how much , but a reasonably significant sum . what would you have do if you have n't become a fund manager ? I do a degree in zoology and before I get into real estate I have a position to research the malaria parasite . the fund have a total cost ( the ` ` OCF ' ' or ` ` TER ' ' ) of 0.96pc a www.year.Be sure to buy the right ` ` share class ' ' , which be ` ` B ' ' . the investment shop through which you buy the fund will also levy a charge . some will charge a percentage of the amount invest , other will apply a flat annual fee . our colour code table at www.telegraph.co.uk/ investing will guide you to the cheap fund shop for your circumstance .

ignore EU complaint - we must start negotiate trade deal now ; there be nothing in the EU treaty to stop Britain reach agreement that begin straight after Brexit
with Theresa May visit Donald Trump to discuss an early trade deal between the US and the UK , the question of whether and to what extent Britain can negotiate post-Brexit trade agreement with non-EU country before formally leave the EU be set to become one of the thorny issue of the Brexit negotiation . the average US trade deal take @card@ month to agree , so could be complete well before we ' ve leave . Australia say ratification could be complete within month of Brexit . at one level it be a mystery that this be an issue at all . we ' ve confirm we ' re leave the single market and custom union , so what business be it of the EU ' s what trade agreement we have , post-Brexit , with non-EU country ? imagine the furore if China tell Japan it be n't permit to have a trade agreement with Australia from @card@ . why should the UK any more tolerate be tell by the EU that it can not have a trade deal with the US or Australia that begin in @card@ ? some commentator and politician claim the EU ' S rule forbid the UK from negotiate with non-EU country before we ' ve formally leave . I ' ll argue in a moment that that ' s not true . but suppose it be . would n't the right response be to feel there be an overwhelming imperative to change those rule or to get permission from the EU to negotiate ? the EU have grant such permission before , even to continue member . at the time of the Lisbon Treaty EU member be grant permission to negotiate their own transitional arrangement for investment agreement with non-EU country . so surely , as a matter of urgency , if indeed the rule do require that , the UK should be grant permission to negotiate with the US or Australia ? as it happen , however , they do n't . the Treaty on the functioning of the European Union ( TFEU ) grant the EU exclusive competence over its common commercial policy , include in particular its trade policy . from this flow the EU ' s competence over trade negotiation . and where the EU have a competence , there be a duty of ` ` sincere cooperation ' ' . so EU member state can not negotiate with non-EU country over any matter that might impinge upon the exclusive or shared competence of the EU ( even in some case where the negotiation be not directly about those matter ) . but the EU be not competent over the UK ' s post-Brexit trade policy , and that apply from the moment the UK leave . there be no ` ` gardening leave ' ' or ` ` no-compete ' ' provision in the treaty . once we ' re out , the treaty do n't apply to us . since the EU do not have competence over our post-Brexit trade policy , it do not have competence over negotiate post-Brexit trade deal for us , and we have no duty of sincere cooperation in respect of the EU ' s post-Brexit trading arrangement . furthermore , the EU can not have competence over the UK ' s post-Brexit trading arrangement because it can not make post-Brexit deal for us . an EU deal such as the Ceta trade agreement with Canada can not bind either the UK or Canada post- Brexit . neither can the EU negotiate on behalf of just one of its party ( Ie the UK ) to the exclusion of the rest . there can not be a competence where there be not , even in principle , a power . thus the EU have no competence over our post-Brexit trading arrangement , because we ' ll have leave and because it can not make trade agreement that would bind us after we ' ve leave . why would we accept any restriction over our ability to negotiate with the US or Australia , say , when the consequence of that would be a delay in our finalise a trade deal with these country post-Brexit ? and to repeat , the argument ` ` that ' s what we ' ve sign up for ' ' do n't fly - there be simply no reference in the treaty to our agree to any gardening leave or no-compete period post-Brexit . we should be able to negotiate , finalise and ratify trade post-Brexit deal as soon as we ' ve formally declare we ' re leave the EU ( by trigger Article @card@ ) . if it provide a political fig-leaf and if we can be sufficiently certain that the ratification process in the US and Australia will only take month , we could accept merely negotiate all the main political term of the deal now but save the actual ratification for the post-Brexit period . the practical political reality , though , be that we be , and must be , negotiate now , regardless of what the UK Government say or how hard EU bureaucrat complain . ' we could accept merely negotiate the main term of the deal now but save ratification until later '

May ' S Big Speech must offer a Big Tent Brexit ; the PM ' s tendency to freeze out those who criticise or disagree with her will do her no favour
like so many modern political habit , the tradition of the Prime Minister ' S Big Speech come from Tony Blair . whether to stamp authority on an issue , answer critic allege a lack of leadership , or distract from some other problem , Mr Blair would offer a Big Speech , an act of oratory intend to dominate the agenda , capture headline and frame political debate . whether such speech actually work be an open question , not least since most people barely notice them . but politician always enjoy the idea that they can change the world through the power of their word alone . Gordon Brown and David Cameron like Big Speeches too . Theresa May resist for half a year , but she will soon give her first Big Speech , about Brexit . next month , she will ` ` set out more about our approach and about the opportunity I think we have as a country to use this process to forge a truly global Britain ' ' . sound grand . that ' s a problem of Big Speeches : they raise hope . just ask Mr Cameron . he make a Big Speech about Europe just three January ago and it destroy him . he do n't just announce the EU referendum , he cast it as a choice between leave and stay on radically different term . the expectation he raise mean the reform he finally offer could only disappoint voter . that leave him offer them a choice between Brexit and a status quo he have admit be unacceptable . in this respect , Mrs May will come to her speech with a certain advantage : no one will expect the exquisite detail of her negotiate strategy . the message-free message of ` ` Brexit mean Brexit ' ' have sink in , at Westminster and among EU leader . Mrs May ' s glacial opacity be now accept as a fact of life . yet she still need to learn from Mr Cameron ' S mistake . her speech need to balance hope and disappointment . more delicate still , her optimism and pessimism must be offer to the same audience : leave voter and the politician who speak for them . the optimism they need be this : Brexit will happen . Britain will leave the EU . that need to be say , loud and clear and often , to lift the curious gloom afflict many Leavers . despite a decisive referendum victory and the appointment of a Prime Minister who know her job depend on it , many Brexiteers remain oddly timid , fearful of political opponent whose strength and resolve they exaggerate : despite the magical power some Tories ascribe to him , Mr Blair will not bewitch Britain out of Brexit . nor will a few dozen refuseniks in Parliament block Article @card@ if the court force Mrs May to legislate ; she will win there , easily . yet even as she reassure the Brexiteers , Mrs May should ready them for disappointment , a Brexit that take longer than they ' d like and may include more Europe than they ' d hope . she should build on the hint of recent week to confirm that in the government ' S view , neither a ` ` transitional ' ' deal after our formal exit nor some participation in either the single market or the custom union be incompatible with honour the referendum result . there be two reason to prepare the ground for a Brexit that fall short of the Brexiteers ' dream . first , bar a failure of talk that really be n't in anyone ' S interest , the term of our exit and our new relationship with the EU will be a compromise , fall somewhere between Britain ' s ideal outcome and the EU ' S . second , Brexit will also be a compromise between different British position : it need to be accept not just by Leavers but by Remainers too . most of the latter , Contra Mr Blair , accept that Brexit be inevitable ; argue to stay in the single market be n't a plot to stop Brexit , merely an opinion about how to achieve it . the referendum result do not end political debate : the @card@ per cent may be in the minority , but they have vote , and voice . Mrs May should make clear she seek a Brexit for the @card@ per cent , or as many as possible , to make sure she go to the negotiate table with the broad support . the more aggressive player on the EU team , notably Guy Verhofstadt of the European Parliament , be openly try to exploit difference between Leavers and Remainers . Mrs May ' s good answer be to eliminate those difference , bring as many reasonable Remainers as she can into partnership with Leavers . instead of leave George Osborne to plot on the backbenches , she should make clear there be a place for him in what amount to a national coalition for Brexit . that do n't have to mean a ministerial job , just the chance to be hear , respectfully , within the government . Mrs May ' s unfortunate tendency to freeze out those who criticise or disagree with her will do her no favour either in the Brexit negotiation or the effort to sell the outcome of those talk to Britain . Mrs May would probably rather die than admit she owe any political debt to Mr Blair , much less draw inspiration from him . but since she ' S follow his pattern with her big speech , she might as well learn from his habit of cast his political net as widely as possible : time for Big Tent Brexit . follow James Kirkup on Twitter @ jameskirkup ; Read More at www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion

UK economy would be seriously weaken by Brexit
it be a fact that the balance of the conclusion from the serious and detailed economic study of the medium-term consequence of Brexit for the British economy be overwhelmingly negative . the central estimate from the study be that the economic loss from Brexit be in the range of 5pc to 10pc of GDP per annum around @card@ or @card@ year from now , or around £1,500 to £3,000 per person per year ( I deliberately use round number here to avoid spurious precision ) . estimate of short-term loss to GDP from Brexit over the next few year be in the range 0.5pc to 2pc . examination in some way of these result be the duty of anyone take their vote seriously in the referendum . my purpose here be to offer some help in evaluate this evidence , something I have be do for much of my professional life though I write now in a personal capacity . evaluation must come by look at the argument , assumption and quality of work . it should not be base on personal attack or impugn motive , as have all too often be a feature of this referendum campaign . the seriousness of the decision require we do good than that . in evaluate the argument we should also ask whether the bias in any estimate of loss point to over or underestimate . I will examine the most prominent and carefully research of the medium-term study : her Majesty ' s Treasury , the OECD , and the Centre for Economic Performance at the LSE . I have have the opportunity to discuss these study with lead author of each one , but be not involve in the production of any of them . the three study pursue their task of estimate loss or gain from Brexit by examine effect on investment , trade and productivity . they do not all make the same assumption about how a Brexit world would work , but they be centre on the ` ` Canada ' ' example . Canada and the EU have be negotiate a deal to remove many trade barrier and low tariff ( it take seven year to negotiate and be not yet in force ) . effect on trade , investment and productivity be then calculate , broadly , on the basis of what the extra trade barrier in the Canada post-Brexit example might look like , what opportunity and risk be likely to be perceive by investor , and how competitive structure and opportunity be likely to influence productivity . in each case evidence be use from economic study of past experience or change as to how much trade barrier , perceive risk and so on be likely to influence the GDP and economic activity in the new post- Brexit state . these be not forecast in the sense of predict where we will be . they be assessment of how much bad off after Brexit we might be compare with wherever we think we would be in , say , @card@ . that be a central question : would we as a nation , relative to the single economic measure of our output as capture by GDP , be bad off ? and we find , as I describe above , very serious loss . in my assessment of the quality of the work , the plausibility of the assumption and the use of evidence be as good as they could be in this kind of exercise . do they offer over or underestimate of the cost of Brexit ? my view be clearly the latter for the follow reason . first , they do not take into account the likely undermine of the stability of the EU of a UK exit and the feedback on the UK economy . second , they probably assume a ` ` too easy ' ' bargain from the EU in any new trade deal . the EU have a clear incentive to ` ` warn ' ' any other potential exiteer that the cost will be high . third , the study be quite conservative in their assessment of policy uncertainty and its effect on investment . my experience as chief economist of the World Bank be that magnitude of such effect be often underestimate . fourth , there can be large and lasting effect of short-run shock on medium-term outcome , as we have see from the financial crisis . Fifth , over the medium term the positive effect on productivity of be in a large and competitive market can be very substantial ( the CEP-LSE study with its large cost estimate of Brexit , rightly in my view , have a strong focus here ) . and , sixth , the dynamic effect of investment , innovation , learning and growth be , modern growth theory tell us , likely to be strong and important , magnify short and medium-term loss . my conclusion therefore be that these study represent the good we can do in these circumstance and , on balance , be likely to be underestimate of the loss from Brexit . within any set of assumption there be large margin of error . nevertheless , we surely should not go into a decision of such importance without do the good we can to assess the economic cost . the assessment of the medium-term cost point clearly and strongly one way : the economic cost of Brexit be high . of course , economic life , trade and investment would go on under Brexit . but the conclusion be that they would be seriously weaken . the change in the short term , not my focus here , have be clearly , plausibly and professionally set out by the Bank of England , the IMF , the Institute for fiscal study and other . their conclusion be that the shortterm cost be high too . whilst this crucial decision be about more than economics , the conclusion from the careful quantitative economic study be clear . Brexit be likely to be a very costly option . Brexit be likely to be a very costly option '

minister and the City require the same Brexit vision
consider how much they rely on each other , it ' s surprising how often the City of London and the government seem to be talk at cross-purpose - particularly when it come to Brexit . whichever way you look at it , the City of London be a British success story . the financial service sector employ more than a million people , pay roughly 10pc of all tax receipt , and run a big trade surplus with the rest of the world . London be the dominant financial centre in Europe and the lead international financial centre in the world : in many sector of the financial market , around two third of all activity in the rest of the EU actually take place in London . and whichever way you look at it , Brexit will have a big impact on the www.City.No , the City be n't about to decamp to Paris , and Frankfurt be n't about to overtake London as a financial centre ( roughly the same number of people work in the City as live in Frankfurt ) . however , between a quarter and a third of the City ' S business involve the EU , and on the other side of Brexit , that ' s go to be a problem . the late example of this disconnect be the breathless warning from the City over the past few month that unless the government agree a so-called Brexit ` ` transition period ' ' with the EU by the end of this year ( or , at the late , the end of March @card@ ) , then hundred of firm will have to start move thousand of staff to the continent . at first glance , it look like the City and the government be read different word from the same script . the City talk about a ` ` transition period ' ' , the government prefer the phrase ` ` implementation period ' ' . while the two term be often use interchangeably - roughly , they both mean a period of two year ( perhaps more ) after Brexit for both side to adapt - they mean different thing , be base on different assumption , and have profoundly different consequence . the key difference be time . an ` ` implementation period ' ' would first require reach a trade deal with the EU to implement and be base on what many people think be an optimistic assumption that the UK can negotiate such a deal by March @card@ . a ` ` transition period ' ' would need to be agree before a trade deal be reach . it explicitly accept that the chance of clinch a deal in the next @card@ month be slim , and be in effect an extension to the negotiation process . it would mean that regulation and market access would remain unchanged for a few year after Brexit , give politician more time to negotiate a good deal , and enable firm to wait until the detail of that deal be clear before have to move staff and operation to the EU . this be more than just semantics : by link an implementation period to a trade deal , the UK Government be reduce the chance of achieve either , miss out on the opportunity to agree a deal that would buy everyone more time , and increase the risk of a messy ` ` no deal ' ' Brexit . a similar effect be on display with discussion about what sort of longer-term relationship the UK want to have with the EU on the other side of Brexit . in her speech at the party conference in October last year and at Lancaster House in January , Theresa May leave no room for doubt that Brexit mean leave the single market . for the City , that mean lose the EU passport that allow so much business to be do in London . yet the City be still ask for the moon : in this newspaper recently the former city minister Mark Hoban call for an ambitious free trade deal with the EU base on mutual recognition of standard . the Bank of England have float the idea of an enlarged European area of shared common standard for financial service cover the UK and the EU . and to confuse thing further , the government be still talk about carve out a special deal for the city that have be repeatedly reject by the EU . as Michel Barnier say : ` ` on financial service , UK voice suggest that Brexit do not mean Brexit . Brexit do mean Brexit - everywhere . ' ' to be clear , these idea have merit . they would be an excellent potential solution in the long term . but anyone who think such a complex deal for financial service can be agree in a little more than a year can , in the Foreign Secretary ' S word , ` ` go whistle ' ' . the late big piece of market regulation from the EU - Mifid @card@ - will have take eight year of consultation and negotiation by the time it come into force at the beginning of next year . of course , if you want the moon , it ' S well to start by ask for the star . but it would be well still for the City and the government to start talk the same language . after the border issue come trade . that ' S when thing get really tough
steadily but surely , and sometimes in big , apparently unscripted jump , Theresa May , the Prime Minister , keep on cede ground in her Brexit negotiation , just as she have on much of the rest of her political agenda , from grammar school to social care . First come European Court of Justice jurisdiction over the right of EU citizen live in Britain ; then it be concede we ' d need a lengthy transition ; then come the money ; and now to the disgust of Northern Ireland ' s Democratic Unionist Party , the Irish border issue . May ' s negotiate refrain , ` ` no deal be good than a bad deal ' ' , be expose as no more than the unconvincing bluff it always be . it now transpire that almost any deal , however bad , be good than no deal , and EU negotiator know it . or just to give what ' S happen a slightly more positive spin , any Brexit be good than no Brexit , for such be the sense of political crisis hang over virtually all aspect of May ' s government that there must be some doubt about whether Brexit can be deliver at all . leaver can feel the prize slip away , and must therefore back whatever form of Brexit the politics allow . perhaps there be method in the madness . the issue seem to have become ever more intractable ; by demonstrate this harsh reality , the PM may hope to take the hardliner with her on the soft Brexit now apparently envisage . the EU can not simply be tell to ` ` sod off ` ` , as propose by the former Cabinet member Priti Patel ; even leave aside whether a hard Brexit would be an economically viable way forward for the UK , it could never command a parliamentary majority , and as we can now see , would stand a high chance of resurrect ` ` the Troubles ' ' in Northern Ireland . from all these perspective , no deal have come to be see as an unconscionable choice . it be therefore necessary to address the question of how many other red line must now be cross in order to win a satisfactory deal on trade . the divorce settlement be in a sense the easy bit . next come much more tortuous negotiation on trade . already it be obvious that a Canadianstyle deal , but with free trade in service add on top , be unrealistic . the problem could of course be solve simply by stay in the single market , much like Switzerland , Norway and other member of the European Free Trade Association . by the way , this would also substantially solve the Irish border issue , as regulation would then automatically be align between Northern Ireland , Great Britain , the Irish Republic and the rest of the EU . but both membership of the single market and the custom union have be rule out by the government , which seek instead a unique ` ` deep and special ' ' relationship with the EU . be these red line to be cede too ? it be hard to see how it would be ` ` take back control ' ' if they be . Britain would become a rule and trade agreement taker , with very little say in their construction - not so much take back control as abject surrender . the rest of the EU account for roughly half of British export , or around 13pc of our GDP - sometimes a bit more , sometimes a bit less depend on erratic such as nonmonetary gold . tariff-free trade in good and non-subsidised agricultural produce such as fruit and veg should be a relatively easy thing to agree . last year , we export £145.5bn in good to the rest of the EU , and they export £242bn in good to us , so it be overwhelmingly in the EU ' s interest for this trade to continue unimpaired . the awkward bit come in the service sector , where so-called non-tariff barrier be the main impediment to trade . unlike good , our export of service to the rest of the EU have be grow almost continually ever since the UK join the common market back in the mid-Seventies , reach a record £90.4bn last year . what be more , we enjoy a substantial surplus in these service export , again unlike good . this be a great position to be in , for despite the nostalgia we have for the day of British manufacturing supremacy - actually we today manufacture more than at any stage in our history , but no matter - the fact be that the price of manufacture good relative to service have be fall for decade , and with progressive automation will no doubt continue to do so . in other word , the term of trade with Europe have shift decisively in our favour . it ' S true that Europe also export a lot of service to us , but these be substantially in the form of overseas holiday ; if we all ` ` staycationed ' ' , our surplus in service trade would be even big . and so to the point ; the big driver of service sector export growth be finance . unfortunately , there be no free trade agreement in existence that give a free pass to finance . Britain owe this privilege when it come to the rest of the EU entirely to its membership of the single market . it be naive to believe Europe be about to set a precedent by cede free trade in finance . with careful persuasion and diplomacy , and by agree European jurisdiction in all such matter , it may eventually be possible to convince Europe that it be in its own interest to sustain the high level of liquidity London be able to offer , but I would n't bet on it , and in any case , such concession be likely to be quite limit in scope . roughly speak , around £40bn annually of City fee income come from the continent , activity that be entirely base on permission access . this in turn directly generate around £15bn a year of tax revenue , ignore income tax , national insurance and other spillover benefit from this business . it ' s quite a hole to be punch in our already stretch public finance . more trouble still , over and above the trade surplus , the City play a key role in fund the UK ' s overall current account deficit by act as a magnet for international capital . if this position be put at risk , the pound would need to fall quite a bit further to reach its equilibrium level , push up inflation and interest rate . tell the EU just to ` ` sod off ` ` be never really an option . even as a negotiate ploy , our affair be too intermingle to have make the threat believable . when he become leader , David Cameron make it his ambition to stop the Tory obsess about Europe ; in the end , the EU destroy him , just as it destroy Thatcher and Major . May scarcely look like break the habit . ' already it be obvious that a Canadianstyle deal , but with free trade in service add on top , be unrealistic '

the future be precarious as May learn the wrong lesson in defeat
one of the image conjure up during Britain ' s referendum campaign as a way of make the argument for leave be that of be ` ` tethered ' ' or ` ` shackle ' ' to a ` ` corpse ' ' . faintly distasteful though this idea might have be , it be both effective and partially true . at the time , many EU member be still deep in the economic doldrums , with crush level of unemployment , the continent be wrack by financial and political crisis , Europe ' s experiment with monetary union have come within a whisker of spark worldwide economic Armageddon , and populism both of the Right and Left be rampant . but that be then . little more than a year later , the table have turn @card@ degree . the government be in chaos after one of the most ineptly run election campaign in live memory , the long haul back to a balanced budget and a nation that once again live within its means be derail , and virtually all the economic indicator be turn negative . in Europe , meanwhile , the populist tide be ebb fast , the economy be grow strongly again , and a pro-business reformer have be sweep to power in France , together with the parliamentary majority that might enable him to actually implement his programme . even Italy seem to be step back from the brink , with the Five Star movement in ragged retreat . something akin to a blood transfusion seem to have take place ; the corpse be transform into Britain . you can almost smell the schadenfreude blow in from the continent . the symbolism of yesterday ' s meeting between Theresa May and Emmanuel Macron could scarcely have be great - the one humiliate and fight for her political life ; the other triumphant , have cruelly snatch the landslide election victory Mrs May have be count on , and ship it off to France . where do this once unimaginable reversal in fortune leave the UK economy and the challenge of Brexit ? start with Brexit , where Mrs May ' s determination to carry on with the negotiate strategy she have settle on ahead of the election look for the moment to be the right approach . give that it be what both the government and the EU have be plan for , there seem little point at this stage in rip it up and start again with a different set of objective . what be clear , however , be that Mrs May be no longer in control of the outcome - parliament will decide on whatever deal emerge . it may well be that Brexit purist will have to swallow their principle and accept Norwegian or Swiss-style arrangement , include continued budgetary contribution , no more than minor tweak to free movement , and some degree of European Court of Justice rule . on many level this would seem unsatisfactory , but even for hardliner some form of Brexit be presumably preferable to no Brexit at all . a soft Brexit may be the only form of it parliament can agree on . the other option would be to leave the EU without any deal , but such an economically disruptive outcome be very unlikely to be acceptable to MP and , bar accident , be therefore not really an option at all . why small business should not expect a smooth Brexit
Europe have 23m small and medium-sized enterprise . they be the backbone of the European economy , accounting for 99pc of all company in the EU and 67pc of employment . that amount to approximately 58pc of gross value add in the non-financial economy . and yet , as a Boston Consulting Group ( BCG ) report commission by AFME reveal , however much disruption Brexit may cause , it wo n't necessarily be big business which suffer the most , but rather the small and medium business who will be prop up our post-Brexit economy . this apply to SMEs in the rest of the EU as well as in the UK . we come to this conclusion after analyse how company and investor in the current EU28 could be affect by the impact of a hard Brexit on the wholesale banking service they consume . BCG ' S researcher speak to more than @card@ chief executive and treasurer of corporate , investment firm and SMEs , along with @card@ industry association which represent a wide range of company and sector . what be strike from the response be that SMEs could find themselves the hardest hit unless they take action now . there be three reason for this . first , the banking-related effect of a hard Brexit could lead to a high cost of capital for SMEs and more restricted access to wholesale banking service . while the exact figure will vary , there be a real risk of fragmentation unless industry and policymaker can work together for a solution that benefit EU business and consumer . secondly , while the scale and bargaining power of individual large corporate and investor mean that many of them would be able to navigate the wholesale banking impact of a hard Brexit , SMEs would undoubtedly find it hard . that ' S because not only be SMEs more likely to find their access to wholesale banking service restrict , but the cost of make adjustment - such as form new banking relationship - can be material for them . SMEs tend to choose a local bank and stay loyal to them . in fact , 60pc of SMEs currently only use one bank for their business banking because of high cost and great difficulty than large corporate when build new relationship . in the event a local UK bank choose not to establish a subsidiary in the EU27 , or that a hard Brexit result in bank have to change their service for exist customer , develop a new banking relationship could be timeconsuming , take anywhere from six month to replicate what SMEs currently do in the UK . thirdly - and crucially give the above - 55pc of the SME participant who comment in the report admit that they have make no plan so far for Brexit . worryingly , the assumption from corporate - small and large - be that their bank will continue to provide financing and be there in the same guise . some 44pc of the SMEs interview expect their bank to absorb any additional cost cause by Brexit . however , this may be overly optimistic . the loss of passporting may cause some bank operate through a UK banking licence to withdraw from the EU27 , reduce the capital available to company and investor . other bank be likely to use subsidiary to maintain cross-border operation , but this could be costly . we can not presume that the plumbing underpin the banking system will continue to function seamlessly . the most likely result be that the European financial and banking market become less integrated - ultimately limit access to market and raise cost . to mitigate such adverse effect of Brexit on end user , our interviewee make a number of suggestion . these include a transition period to give bank and their client time to adjust , as well as ` ` grandfathering ' ' of exist contract in order to minimise the legal and operational disruption to bank and their client . above all , business tell us that they want the status quo preserve . the majority hope Brexit negotiation will result in similar level of access to and cost of wholesale banking service as they have today . they feel strongly that the political negotiation should keep in mind the impact of Brexit on real economy end user . the continued stability of pan-European capital market and future economic growth depend on it . Simon Lewis be the chief executive of the Association for Financial Markets in Europe ' however much disruption Brexit may cause , it wo n't necessarily be big business which suffer the most '

voter have disarm our Brexit negotiator - we ' ll get a bad deal ; if the PM do n't have the backing of Parliament , the EU will have no incentive to concede anything
deal or no deal ? on Thursday , Britain take its good option for Brexit off the table . although the government say that ` ` no deal be good than a bad deal ' ' , its ultimate goal be to ensure that we never face that choice . the election have , however , make a good deal impossible and so the choice between ` ` no deal ' ' and a ` ` bad deal ' ' now look inevitable . unfortunately , the election have also now ensure that the consequence of ` ` no deal ' ' would be immeasurably more damaging . let me explain . negotiation with the EU be always go to be difficult and nasty . authority over its citizen ' right , continue regulatory meddling and so on . the deal on offer could be so bad that it would simply be good to stay in the EU single market or European economic area for the time be . this be , of course , many Remainers ' preferred choice . it be not a good option , however . although it guarantee continued tariff and customs-free trade and offer us some recourse the less , this be our likely option one . naturally , Brexiteers will consider any possible www.alternative.No deal be good than a bad deal , right ? well , perhaps , before . but the new paralysis in Parliament have dramatically heighten the danger of a ` ` no deal ' ' scenario . if the Tories have a large majority , withdraw from the EU without a deal would have be painful , but the government could have mitigate some of the risk . it could have pass a budget include cash to upgrade immigration and custom capacity , put EU law into British law for the time be to provide some legal certainty and temporarily replicate EU tariff to ensure international trade could continue smoothly . it would still have be a rough ride , but minimally cushion by the government . none of these preparation be possible , however , if Parliament will not pass them . the only way for us to quit the EU without a deal in such a situation be for the government to sit tight and let the time run out on negotiation . at that point , in March @card@ , Britain would crash out with no plan in place . business and investor would not know if their legal contract be enforceable . border and custom official would have no idea how to process the queue of people and lorry . plane take off from runway in Luton would not know if they have permission to land in Lyon . million of EU citizen here and Briton abroad would be in limbo . all of this be bad enough , without the additional risk from Britain ' s enormous current account deficit . every year , our economy require a vast inflow of cash from abroad to keep go . that mean any market freeze trigger by a Brexit -related legal vacuum could send sterling into freefall and generate an instant debt www.crisis.No responsible government can take such risk . this leave a nightmarish choice : betray Brexit or risk disaster . either choice be electoral poison for the conservative . it be quite possible that whoever be then our prime minister will instead opt for another election or referendum to avoid make it . there be many Remainers who , calculate that Friday ' S result will lead to an ultra-soft Brexit , be rather please . Cheer up : a Brexit would help British GDP
as Lenin famously put it , a lie tell often enough become the truth . for some in the City , Brexit be a bit like bad weather , or major sport tournament : a convenient excuse for business face a tough time . of course , bad weather can depress a retailer ' S sale and football game can distract worker - but four time out of five , such ` ` explanation ' ' be merely trot out to camouflage deep , more genuine problem . the same be true of the uncertainty surround a possible Brexit : some investor be doubtless wait for the result before they allocate capital . so Brexit jitter will be have some , marginal impact on the economy , in the same way that some transaction be doubtless delay by a few week before last year ' S election . but most of what ' s happen in the economy have nothing to do with our national debate about the European Union . the top of the housing market have primarily be affect by a sharp hike in stamp duty and reduce demand from emerge market buyer . bank be lay staff off because high capital requirement and rock-bottom interest rate have hurt their business model , and there have be a global downturn in capital market activity . it be true , though , that some company have start to believe their own scare story about what would happen be we to quit the EU and have put some project on hold . more fool them : the UK will be fine regardless of how we vote , but unfortunately this will have a small impact on overall GDP . it be time to nail one myth , however : the idea that there have be no serious economic analysis suggest that we would be good off outside of the EU . that be n't so : most economist be pro-Remain , but there have be some excellent - and in my view - far more persuasive work on the Brexit side . five report in particular stand out , but there have also be other , as well as various analysis of our post-Brexit trading option . Open Europe have publish a range of estimate of the economic effect of Brexit . its comprehensive analysis suggest that we could be anywhere between 1.6pc well off and 2.2pc bad off . the good scenario be contingent on striking lot of free trade deal around the world and deregulate the economy ; the bad one if we fail to keep trade liberal and if we be to embrace protectionism . in my view , the first scenario would be by far the likely ; Open Europe ' S analysis be much more balanced and sensible than the Treasury ' S . the Centre for Economics and Business Research have also publish a nuanced report on the matter . it believe that there would be a shortterm hit from Brexit , last maybe two year , and sterling would fall 10pc to 15pc - but once the business community get use to the new arrangement , the low exchange rate would help attract foreign investment and ` ` most of the lose GDP would be recover and quite likely the economy would settle on a slightly fast growth path ' ' . by @card@ , GDP would be high than it be if we remain in the EU , though as ever the result be contingent on striking trade deal and remain an open , promigration economy . Andrew Lilico of Europe Economics , who also back Brexit , have point out there be many more such study . the one publish by the Mayor of London ' s economist ( lead by the excellent Gerard Lyons ) argue cogently that Brexit would enhance our economy compare with stay in the unreformed EU deliver by the Prime Minister . as to Capital Economics , run by our columnist Roger Bootle , its study commission by Woodford Investment Management argue that Brexit would n't have much of a net effect on the economy ' S performance . Capital Economics expect us to continue to outperform the rest of the EU either way . another fascinating approach be that of Patrick Minford in the new edition of ` ` Should Britain leave the EU ? economic analysis of a troubled relationship ' ' : his cost benefit analysis use a general equilibrium model suggest that we would be massively good off if we leave the EU and declare unilateral free trade . our consumer waste 4pc of GDP on excessive cost because of EU protectionism , and we would benefit greatly from deregulation also . last but not least , the Change or Go report from Business for Britain serialise in this newspaper contain much excellent analysis . it be untrue that there be no serious economic study that support the Brexit case . we need more , of course . but in the meantime take the pro-EU doom-mongers with a bucket of salt . allister.heath @ telegraph.co.uk ' it be untrue there be no serious economic study that support the Brexit case '

as haven of sensible regulation , the City might even gain from Brexit
Xavier Rolet , chief executive of the London Stock Exchange , think Brexit might end up cost the City @card@ job . Bank of England estimate be scarcely any more reassuring . collate contingency planning by City firm for a hard Brexit , the Bank put the cost at a possible @card@ job . Lloyd Blankfein , chief executive of Goldman Sachs , have also suggest in a tweet that thanks to Brexit , his new partially complete European headquarters in London may be leave substantially empty . it all sound and look pretty grim , and for certain , intra-European , activity it probably be . but it do n't mean the City be doom ; the clever operator be already look through the legal and economic quagmire of Brexit to the more conducive regulatory environment for international capital that could lie beyond , give the political will . a case in point be the European Union ' S so-called Solvency II directive , the subject last week of a deeply critical report by the UK parliamentary Treasury select committee . Brexit provide the opportunity to reform this 3,200-page piece of regulatory gobbledegook in a manner which put the competitiveness of the UK insurance industry first , rather than the misguided and destructive notion of consumer and systemic safety the directive be intend to give tooth to . but first , the negative . the City , it scarcely need say , be far from happy about Brexit , and particularly unhappy about the way the talk seem to be go . one senior banker I recently speak to put the chance of a decent deal for financial service at less than 10pc . I ' d be a bit more optimistic , but not much ; the government ' s narrative on this issue be instruct by little more than wishful thinking . it may be true that the City provide Europe with an invaluable service that it would be hard to replicate , but it do n't cut much ice with Europe ' s political class , where the ` ` Anglo-Saxon speculator ' ' be still routinely blame for almost any ill . a similar argument be often apply by Brexit optimist to trade in good ; they ' ve get more to lose than us because we ' ve get a whacking great deficit with Europe while Europe ' S get a whacking great surplus with us . as a statement of fact , this too be true , but it draw the wrong conclusion . a parallel can be make with my mother ' s home town of Cholsey , which be it - like Catalonia - to declare independence would no doubt argue that the rest of the country would be stupid not to continue with free trade because its export to Cholsey far exceed Cholsey ' S export to great Britain . indeed so , but the rest of the country would scarcely miss Cholsey if it be entirely wipe from the map , whereas Cholsey would suffer a crippling loss be it suddenly to be deny access to market elsewhere in Britain . on both good and service , the EU unfortunately hold most of the card . there be not a free trade agreement anywhere in existence that include the sort of deal that Britain be look for in financial service . it stretch credulity to think that an internal market determine that Britain - pour encourager les autres - be see to be bad off once it leave than before be about to set the precedent . remember , in the EU the politics always trump the economics . the same go for Liam Fox ' S hope of focus free trade talk with the US on service rather than good . the international trade secretary ' S suggestion be naive in the extreme . that the US be about to roll over and allow its financial service to be run out of London be about as likely as Elon Musk ' S plan for colonise Mars ; it ' S not go to happen in our life time . fortunately , financier , like business people , be first and foremost pragmatist ; when push come to shove , they will attempt to turn any loss into an opportunity . friendly regulation be one such chance . solvency II provide a particularly glaring example of European , regulatory overkill . it ' s be under construction since the turn of the century , and at quite shocking cost , recently come fully into operation . in total , HM Treasury have estimate a one-off cost to UK business of ` ` £2.6bn ... and ongoing cost at approximately £196m each year ' ' . the directive be not entirely without merit ; it may have improve risk management in Europe and it allow firm to write business in other EU member state without need to go through local regulator . but in other respect it be have some deeply negative consequence , considerably add to the cost of capital , undermine value to the consumer , and make the UK an increasingly unattractive place for insurance . the directive also unnecessarily drive insurer into safe , liquid asset - mainly government bond - to the detriment of long term business and infrastructure investment , for which the industry ' S nearly £2 trillion of asset under management be ideally suit . furthermore , the directive ' S impact be far great in Britain because of the mix of business in UK company and the number of firm require to adopt its model . insurance be simply a much big industry in Britain than elsewhere in Europe , and it be be force feed a particularly ill-suited form of regulation . the same may be true of other financial service . by liberalise accountancy rule , for instance , the City might be able to attract risk management of huge amount of additional , offshore international capital . my suggestion here be merely that of change the regulation , not abandon it entirely . nobody be advocate complete deregulation ; by make the system unsafe , this would be more likely to deter capital than attract it . but put the competitiveness of the City back centre stage as a regulatory priority - something that virtually disappear with the creation of the Prudential Regulatory Authority - have plenty to commend it over the alternative of seek regulatory equivalence with Europe , an approach which condemn the UK to rule take with no say in the way the rule be make . that ' S the bad of all possible world . what the Continental fear most be that the City break away entirely and compete on its own term for international business , leave the EU an entirely close zone for finance . get the regulation right , and what the UK lose on the one hand , it may gain on the other . May must explain how Brexit can strengthen , not overturn , the West ; the EU do n't seem to realise that our capitalist , liberal democratic framework be under threat
this be n't the way Theresa May want it to be . like most politician , she covet power for year . now that she have it , her carefully consider domestic agenda keep disappear under heavy file mark ` ` Brexit ' ' . but as Margaret Thatcher find in the Falkland , unexpected adventure abroad can make a premiership . if Mrs May want to win the authority need for domestic reform , she must seize the moment . Brexit call not just for technical squabble in Brussel and platitude at home , but for leadership on a grand scale . what kind of world do Mrs may want us to live in ? how will her leadership help get us there ? and , vitally for Britain ' S interest , how will she defend the Western order ? over and over , Mrs May ' S enemy claim that she must lay out a vision for Brexit , but they be focus on the wrong kind of vision . we do not need or want a Prime Minister who foolishly lay out Britain ' S demand , fall-back position and red line . what be require be not a Westminster row about the single market and the EU ' s legal structure , but to elevate the debate . the country and the EU need to understand what be at stake . the capitalist , liberal democratic framework that have serve us so well since @card@ be under threat . Brexit do not mean , as the EU assume , that Britain want a revolution to throw it all away . we want to build a new model of co-operation with a great a role for the nation state , to defeat the corrupt authoritarianism and state-rigged trading model of China and Russia . to that end , Brexit should not be about punishment , but must revitalise the alliance between freedom-loving Western nation . this be the unambiguous message Mrs May need to deliver before negotiation begin . the Prime Minister understand the domestic piece of the puzzle very well . after the financial crisis and year of wage stagnation , capitalism be threaten not just by foreign power , but by disillusion at home , which be why Mrs May keep call Brexit ` ` a vote for change ' ' . her initial instinct push her towards ineffective socialist idea like worker on board , energy price cap or state bailout for industry . but unlike many politician , she be good at listen to her Cabinet colleague and be slowly move in the right direction : a radical shake-up of the housing market , much more investment in skill and education , and an energy policy that serve consumer and the economy , not just emission target . so Mrs May be right not to ignore the domestic anger the referendum lay bare . fundamentally , though , Brexit be a matter of foreign policy - one of the few brief she have never hold . the government must rethink how Britain manage all of its dealings with the outside world , from trade to immigration and defence . the EU ' S ideologue insist that there be only two possible model . the first be that we be govern by supranational organisation within the single market . the second be total isolation . the define feature of this argument be that it an obsessively legal one . it assume that Brexit can create no new legal form of co-operation or trade , but must rely on the current available option . it ignore that fact that we be not deal with lawyer and statute on a two-year timetable . Brexit be about the fate of nation over decade . it be for elect politician to make the decision , not lawyer . so far , the lead elect politician on the continent have be extremely reluctant to admit this fact . they be defer to the lawyer when they repeat the mantra that the EU ' s ` ` four freedom ' ' be inseparable ; in other word , there can be no free trade of good , capital and service without the free movement of people . they be convince , for the moment , the legal edifice be what matter and if they allow it to be alter , the whole European democratic order will crumble . Mrs May ' s central task be to make Brexit a matter of politics , not legal technicality . in this mission , she do have potential ally on the continent , even in some of Brussels ' staunch pro-EU circle . in August , five author publish a paper argue that Brexit be a chance to create a ` ` continental partnership ' ' between Europe ' s EU and non-EU nation . the author include two top thinker from the Bruegel Institute , Brussels ' most influential think tank ; Jean Pisani-Ferry , a former EU official and French government adviser ; Norbet Röttgen , a German MP and chairman of the Bundestag foreign affair committee , and former Bank of England deputy governor Paul Tucker . it would be easy to assume that this list of author be capable only of parrot EU dogma . it would also be wrong . ` ` free movement of worker , ' ' they write , ` ` be not indispensable ... free movement of worker can be separate from [ free trade ] . ' ' the ` ` continental partnership ' ' they describe would let the UK set quota on EU immigration while allow British firm to operate freely in the single market . as with any modern trade agreement , it would establish an arbitration system to ensure we have sufficiently similar trading standards.But it would not allow foreign judge to interpret human right law here or decide whom we deport . this might still sound unpalatable to some Brexiteers . it do , however , provide a crucial advantage over a straightforward ` ` hard Brexit ' ' . it mean Britain can continue to exert a strong influence over geopolitical decision that will make or break Western power , like whether to impose sanction on Russia , the imperative for EU country to stop free-riding and contribute more to Nato , and whether the West should compete with China by embrace protectionism and massive state subsidy programme . the ` ` continental partnership ' ' might not be the exact model we adopt , but it provide the key insight : even after Brexit , Britain need a platform to influence our EU ally and nudge them in the right direction . the task be certainly daunting.Mrs May must engineer a Brexit that strengthen , rather than weaken , the West ' s resolve to tackle threat from disruptive , anti-democratic power . if she fail , Britain could quit the EU declare that it want to be a beacon of free trade only to find that free trade , capitalism and the rule of law be in retreat across the world . ultimately , our prosperity do not depend on a ` ` soft ' ' or ` ` hard ' ' Brexit . it depend on openness and security . for the first time since the Cold War , the West be enter a battle of idea . Brexit be not a one-off , look at Europe ' S woe
there be a way of think about Brexit that have prove popular because it be of comfort both to the UK and to the remain @card@ member state of the EU . this be to view it as a uniquely British affair , one that realign this country with its old tradition - in Europe , but not a direct part of it ; a bridge between Europe and the US . the continental version , meanwhile , view Brexit as a liberation for the EU after put up for decade with grumble brit . as one French journalist put it a day after the referendum : ` ` my English friend , thank you for your sacrifice . ' ' this be wrong . far from be an isolated event , Brexit be representative of grow economic and political tension within Europe on the matter of European integration . look at the political tremor now shake the EU ' s keystone nation , Germany , which have even threaten the position of Angela Merkel . importantly , both Britain and nation of the continent have economic frustration with the EU . as there be no single European economy , citizen in Europe experience ` ` ever close union ' ' through their national growth model . in Britain ' S case , the economy grow by expand the labour market . this inject life into the country ' S service sector-dominated economy but make the UK dependent on very high level of net migration . this model deliver low unemployment but also low productivity and low wage growth . the tension produce by this growth model be important driver of Brexit . Germany ' s experience of the Single Market be quite different , but also problematic . lie behind Germany ' s success in export market be an economy characterise by low aggregate demand and high saving rate . Labour market reform have lead to a decade-long squeeze on wage , mean that most Germans do n't feel rich . this be why there be so much opposition in Germany to a European fiscal transfer union . ` ` we ' ve not have it easy , ' ' go the argument , ` ` so why should we help out the Greeks and the Italian ? ' ' Further integration of the eurozone will run up against ordinary Germans ' experience of life in the single market . there be also frustration common to Britain and the continent with government which seem more focus on striking deal in Brussels than in represent the wish of their citizen . the European orientation of the administrative British state be on show throughout the referendum campaign , with major British institution - such as the Bank of England and the Treasury , and the ` ` deep state ' ' of the high education sector - openly back the Remain campaign . since the Brexit vote , British diplomat have be push to act as if the UK be a 19th century nationstate , when in fact it be a 21st-century EU member state , accustom to the pursuit of consensus and compromise . their refusal to consider Brexit as a challenge to transform the state continue . British civil servant currently work within the Department for Exiting the European Union ( DEXEU ) be only second , for a term of two year , from their original ministry - the implication be that their service will only be need for a short transitional period . this be clearly a dramatic under-estimation of the administrative , constitutional and economic challenge pose by Brexit . Brexit reveal in a dramatic fashion the way in which EU member state struggle to fulfil even the most basic function of self-government associate with the model of the modern sovereign state . this be by no mean only a British affair , as we see it also in @card@ when the Greek government be unable to translate the wish of its own people into a new deal with its creditor . this be an urgent issue for all European citizen who believe in the capacity - and duty - of government to represent the will of their citizen . Brexit should not be treat as a stand-alone phenomenon , isolate from the rest of the European continent . it be unlikely that other country will follow suit in the near future , not least because of the difficulty in leave an integrated currency union . but Brexit nevertheless express fundamental tension at the heart of ` ` ever close union ' ' . ironically , it be precisely in its decision to exit the EU that the UK have identify itself most as a European state , whose fate have many lesson for the EU ' S @card@ remain member . Chris Bickerton be a fellow of politics at Queens ' College Cambridge . this be adapt from an essay in Brexit and Beyond : rethink the Futures of Europe , available to download free from UCL Press from Jan @card@ Read More at www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion

George Eustice say Brexit will provide a ` ` good deal ' ' for fisherman because current quota give a ` ` disproportionately large ' ' share of catch to fisherman from the European Union . he say after Brexit the UK will strike new ` ` reciprocal ' ' arrangement with the EU , which will give fisherman a great share of catch in British water and abroad . he say that during Britain ' s membership of the EU negotiation about fishing quota have stall because of the ` ` institutionalise inertia ' ' of Brussels . he tell the Daily Telegraph : ` ` it ' s pretty clear Brexit can be a good deal for British fisherman because we regain control . the equation be they have one million ton of UK fish and we get about @card@ ton of various specie . ' ' Leaving the EU will spell the end of the hate Common Fisheries Policy and enable the UK to assert control over its 200-mile Exclusive Economic Zone ( EEZ ) . this mean that foreign vessel could not then fish in the zone without express consent . more than half of the UK ' S EEZ be around Scotland and fishing leader north of the border be furious with Nicola Sturgeon ' S attempt to somehow bypass the Brexit vote and keep Scotland in the EU . a major report publish earlier this month find that more than half the fish catch in British water be currently land by trawler from the rest of the EU . Mr Eustice say : ` ` there be area we would hope to get a good deal , particularly with cod and plaice . ` ` the truth be , thing will change in a very fundamental way . in the Channel the French get twice as much plaice and three time as much Dover sole as we do . there be an imbalance . ' ' Mr Eustice believe that fisherman in the Channel and the West country in particular could benefit from reform to fishing quota . he highlight Britain ' s ` ` incredibly low ' ' share of plaice and sole in the English Channel , with a similar situation for cod and haddock in the Celtic Sea . he say that here be no ` ` balance ' ' to Britain ' s fishing agreement with the EU , and that it ` ` benefit more from access to the UK than the UK benefit from access to them ' ' . it come as French fisherman accuse their British rival of ` ` plunder ' ' continue on Page @card@ continue from Page @card@ scallop in the Channel , say Brexit could leave UK trawler free to increase their catch without the constraint of EU regulation . ' ' the French be aggrieve because they say they be already subject to strict fishing limit than the British , and they fear Brexit will disentangle UK boat from the web of EU rule . Mr LefÈvre explain that under national regulation to prevent overfishing , French fisherman be oblige to respect strict quota . these rule do not apply to the British , who be subject to ` ` more lenient ' ' British and EU regulation . ` ` after Brexit , Britain would perhaps not be bind by EU regulation . we hope we can agree on a solution with our British friend before the UK leave , ' ' he say . ` ` the problem be that the British see only the business side of thing while we be think about conservation too . Scotland May ' s Brexit dilly-dally offer a golden opportunity for Scotland ; if it act now , the Scottish Government can put its demand at the top of the UK-EU negotiation agenda
three month on from the European Union referendum it be blatantly obvious the UK Government have n't a clue about how or when to proceed with Brexit . Theresa May ' S Cabinet ca n't even agree amongst themselves what their definition of Brexit be , as witness by their contradictory statement on the future relationship between Britain and the European single market . the Scottish Government therefore have a golden opportunity , which it should not let slip , to fill the void by put Scotland ' s Brexit demand at the top of the UK-EU negotiation agenda and do so now . rather than wait until Mrs May eventually get her act together , the Scottish Government should immediately publish its ` ` List of Scottish Demands ' ' for the Brexit negotiation . do n't wait for Whitehall . set the agenda now . force the UK Cabinet to acknowledge Scotland ' S priority . preempt any attempt by the UK Government to place unacceptable limitation on Scotland ' s Brexit ambition . top of the list of Scottish demand should be the transfer of the power be repatriate from Brussels , as they relate to Scotland , to the Scottish Parliament - not Westminster . all the power relate to exist devolve matter , such as farming and fishing , should automatically transfer to Edinburgh . Brexit also provide the ideal opportunity to devolve all the other power currently control by Brussels to the Scottish Parliament . this would include power currently exercise by the EU cover employment law and worker ' right , environmental protection , social policy , consumer protection , certain aspect of transport policy , some aspect of energy policy , public health matter , and certain aspect of justice and home affair policy as well as external affair . finally , a range of other power which have n't be devolve to Scotland because of EU rule should also be transfer to Edinburgh . the most important of these would be give the Scottish Parliament full control over value add tax ( VAT ) . until now the UK Treasury have argue that VAT could n't be devolve because the EU would n't allow rate variation within a member state . after Brexit , this excuse be no longer valid . VAT could easily be transfer in Toto to Edinburgh . the leave campaign ' s promise during the referendum that if the UK vote for Brexit , then Scotland would get control over immigration policy must also be honour and include in Scotland ' s list of demand . the second item on that list should be the transfer of all the funding associate with these new power mention above , include Scotland ' s share of the UK annual contribution to the EU budget , itself estimate by the Scottish Parliament ' S Information Centre ( Spice ) to be worth around £800 million a year net of the funding Scotland currently get from the EU . with this money , post-Brexit , the Scottish Government could continue to finance all the project currently support by the EU in Scotland to the same level of fund as at present , and still have another £800 million or so a year leave over to invest as we choose . the accumulation of all these new power and finance would bring about ' neo-Independence ' ' for Scotland , create the ideal platform for advance to full sovereignty for the Scottish people in the early 2020s . the third key item on Scotland ' S list must be continue access to the benefit of the single market . eleven per cent of all good and service sell furth of Scotland every year go to the EU . these export support many thousand of job in Scotland that we ca n't afford to lose ; so retain both free access to this market along with the other benefit of the single market , such as ` ` passporting ' ' for our financial sector , be essential . Scotland should continue to benefit from the free movement of people between Europe and Scotland . the crucial role play by people from Europe and elsewhere in the world in staff some of our key industry such as tourism , agriculture and horticulture have to be protect . there be no reason why Scotland should not be able to implement its own immigration policy which would allow free movement to continue . the UK Government would find it difficult to refuse these demand , if Scotland play its card right . to help ensure our demand be meet , the Scottish Government should organise a ` ` Brexit coalition ' ' of the nation and region of the UK . such a coalition could form a share platform of key demand that the nation and region need to be meet from Brexit and force Mrs May to reach a deal which be as acceptable to them as it be to her . Alex Neil MSP be a former Scottish Government Cabinet Secretary

yet there be no commensurate response from Philip Hammond , no firework , no game-changing tax reform , no think the unthinkable . prudence and caution be ordinarily great attribute in a chancellor ; and Mr Hammond be right that spend a little bit more on road make sense . yet these be time that require visionary leadership , not managerialism . it ' S not enough merely to tweak a few scheme here and there , or even , in time , to increase capital spending by a few tenth of a percentage point of GDP . we need a Ronald Reagan style ` ` it ' s morning in Britain ' ' moment ; instead , we be offer a collection of micropolicies that could almost all have be deliver by George Osborne , Vince Cable or even Ed Miliband . this government ' s passivity in the face of seismic change at home and abroad , its inability to imagine and describe a great , exciting future for this county , its refusal to seize the moment - these be fast become its define feature . this be tragic : the Tories have n't be this popular since the eighty , yet they be fail utterly to take advantage of it . there be three possible explanation for this extraordinary timidity . the first be that the Treasury remain in denial , that it secretly hope that Brexit will go away , that Donald Trump will be unelected and that the French election wo n't happen next year . while plenty of powerful people still hope that Brexit will be derail , Mr Hammond be n't one of them , so this theory can be dismiss . the second be that the government want to retain some firepower in case the economy slow . this be plausible , but regrettable : it should be lead , not follow , boost the economy pre-emptively . the third , and in my view most plausible , explanation as to why Mr Hammond choose not to rock the boat be that Project Fear live on , and that the Chancellor do n't have the desire or appetite to take it on . Britain have vote to leave the European Union , the government have pledge to make it a success and yet the country ' s official forecaster continue to assume that Brexit will be bad for growth , productivity and the budget deficit . it ' S like a scene from Yes , Minister , a case study in how the establishment never give up . it would be comical if it be n't so serious . the Office for Budget Responsibility believe that the state will now borrow £122 billion more by @card@ than it forecast in March , a huge change that will send the national debt shoot up all the way to @card@ per cent of GDP in @card@ . Mr Hammond ' S decision be responsible for £26 billion of this increase ; and another £26 billion can be account for , the OBR guess , primarily by the fact that it be become harder to wring income tax out of the economy because of the rise in self-employment . but the OBR also assume that £59 billion of high borrowing be ` ` relate to the referendum result and exit the EU ' ' over this fiveyear period : that number therefore become the ` ` official ' ' cost of Brexit , and have be welcome with hysterical glee by Remainers . the hit be base on highly contestable assumption , include low productivity , reduce business investment , increase barrier to trade and less immigration than there would otherwise have be . for those of us who believe that Brexit will , in time , be good for growth and bolster openness and competition , this be madden : what ' s the point of win a referendum if the government machine be on autopilot , pre-programme to trash Brexit and to assume the bad at every stage ? this inbuilt Remainian bias risk become self-fulfill : the Chancellor can not cut tax because it be assume the economy will slow , so he do n't and it do . as it happen , the only one of the assumption that the OBR make that might be true be that immigration will fall , but it ' S still impossible to predict precise number . I do n't blame Robert Chote , the boss of the OBR and a first-class economist , for this deeply unsatisfactory set of forecast : his job have become impossible . the government have n't tell him anything about the shape of Brexit , so he have take the consensus , establishment view on it . what choice do he have ? have he say that Brexit will , in fact , be good for growth , the explosion of establishment rage would have engulf him . his report make it very clear that these be not really prediction but merely deduction from assumption . in fact , it could have be far bad : the hit from Brexit in the OBR ' S forecast be actually very small : the economy will grow by @card@ per cent this year , fast than the @card@ per cent expect by the OBR in March . growth next year will be a perfectly respectable @card@ per cent ( down from @card@ per cent ) , then @card@ per cent in @card@ ( down from @card@ per cent ) , before return to the @card@ per cent previously expect . Britain would still be grow faster than the Eurozone . this be a dramatically good picture than the catastrophic fantasy recession predict by the treasury during the referendum campaign . even if growth do perform as the OBR suggest over the next two year and then eventually bounce back , as Eurosceptics believe it will , the UK would still end up well off as a result of Brexit . but all of this mean that any forecast for public finance have become even more meaningless than usual . the suppose massive fiscal loosening announce at this Autumn Statement be primarily a statistical fluke . regardless of Brexit , George Osborne ' s deficit reduction target be unachievable ; Mr Hammond be right to ditch it . the real tragedy be not that the national debt be spiral out of control - I just do n't believe the number . it be that the government be do almost nothing to build a new , strong , free-market Britain to capitalise on Brexit . as waste opportunity go , this one truly take some beating . follow Allister Heath on Twitter @ AllisterHeath ; Read More at www.telegraph.co.uk/ opinion

' ' there be those who want Brexit to be as light as a feather : a slow retreat from the EU , pay it off to keep it sweet and stay in the single market , with a few cosmetic change . on the other hand , there be those who want Britain to win the maximum of liberty at the low price : keep control of our border , our court and our ability to trade with whomever we wish . get the most out of Brussels might require brinkmanship , say that the UK be willing to walk away without a deal . it be a risk ; Brexit always involve risk . but one never get what one want without ask . the voter understand this : only the most militant Remainers take every threat from the EU negotiating team as a statement of fact . and as the week go by , the stake of that negotiation be become clear . we be tell during the referendum campaign that the EU be just a trade club motivate by mutual self-interest . this week , however , Emmanuel Macron call for fast , close integration - EU identity card , a shared defence budget , an EU army . just as the domestic battle have become dramatically sharp - socialism vs capitalism - so the debate over Brexit have crystalise into pan-Europeanism vs nation-state democracy . the IMF must stop play political game and get back to its root

I be a remainer , but I ca n't accept this interpretation of Britain ' s vote to leave . troublesome , but it be most unlikely to be disastrous . not for the first time , the IMF have become captive to ` ` group think ' ' and powerful establishment force . over the last @card@ year , the
