out the banker . it have also be consistently wrong about the UK . some serious soul search be in order . the very purpose of this institutional corner stone of the post-war , Bretton Woods economic settlement be be call into question as rarely before . time and again , the IMF have be find guilty of faulty forecasting , analysis and policy . too often it become captive to powerful political interest in its membership , as occur in Britain ' s referendum campaign when it be use as a key part of George Osborne ' s ` ` Project Fear ' ' . yet the big failure be over the euro . first the IMF ignore the design flaw at the heart of European monetary union , and therefore completely fail to see its propensity to crisis . then , as the debt meltdown begin , it remain upbeat about the health of the Europ=ean banking system , take at face value the self interested reassurance of national and euro area regulator . and finally it squander the fund ' S resource on an unprecedented scale support the continuation of a currency which for some of its member have become an economic doomsday machine . ensure the single currency ' S survival be routinely prioritised over the individual nation ' s good interest . this may have be understandable in view of America ' S still recent banking crisis . Larry Summers , a former US Treasury Secretary , warn that a sovereign default within the eurozone would be ` ` like Lehman ' S on steroid ' ' . yet fear of contagion provide only a partial excuse . the effect be to bail out banker at the expense of citizen . the internal devaluation impose on large part of Europe give it no plausible way back to growth or liberation from mountainous debt . forecaster be ignore the only certainty - another recession
' T be the season , it seem , of ` ` official ' ' economic forecast , and the more that roll in , the more depressing they get . last week it be the Office for Budget Responsibility , which sharply downgrade its productivity assumption , and therefore its growth forecast , for the wide UK economy . this week , it ' S the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development ( OECD ) , which have chime in with even bleak prediction than the OBR . in the OBR ' S case , there be at least no attempt to calibrate the forecast against other advanced economy , but the OECD spare us no such blush ; other than Japan , Britain ' s growth prospect be judge to be significantly bad than the rest of the G7 , at least for the next two year . implicit in both set of forecast be a substantial negative impact from Brexit . with political sensitivity in mind , the OBR try its hard to disguise the Brexit effect , blame the downgrade on a low post-financial crisis trend in productivity growth . but it be nonetheless there as a factor in those very same productivity assumption . with the OECD , the Brexit judgment be a good deal more overt ; the close the eventual trade deal with Europe , the OECD opine , the well it will be for growth . as it be , the OECD assume the talk will result in relatively favourable transitional arrangement , which be by no mean a give . Brexit present a particularly thorny issue for forecaster . if you could park it as an unknowable quantity , leave it out of the equation altogether , you most certainly would , if only to avoid the opprobrium heap from both side of the debate on any positive or negative judgment . yet no forecaster can credibly ignore it . furthermore , it be already obvious that whatever the long-term impact , Brexit uncertainty be indeed have an economically chilling effect . the chill instruct the forecast , which in turn inevitably feed into the wide political narrative , where their nuance and context quickly become ignore . in any event , as with the referendum campaign itself , we be again subject to a relentless diet of negative prediction . whether it turn out to be right or wrong be almost irrelevant . as Brexit negotiation reach their most politically difficult and define stage , the tone of the forecasting become steadily more doom laden . this be go to affect both the public mood and the concession that UK politician be prepare to make to ensure single market access . support for Brexit will erode the more leave the EU be see to damage the UK ' s economic prospect . Sir Michael Caine , one of the UK ' s national treasure , say of Brexit that he would rather be a poor master than a rich servant . noble , inspiring and widely share though this sentiment might be , it ' S not a choice that anyone of sound mind would voluntarily want to make ; we ' d all much rather be a rich master . to be a poor one be not the way Brexit be sell . as Philip Hammond , the Chancellor , keep stress , the UK do not vote to become poor . unfortunately , the implication of both the OBR and OECD forecast be that this be precisely what we have do . I worry a lot about the political repercussion if their gloom turn out to be justify . already the financial crisis have cause the UK to miss out on an entire decade of wage growth . the implication of the OBR ' s productivity downgrade be that we be head for a second such hiatus . real wage growth never equate exactly with underlie productivity growth , but the two be closely relate . without productivity growth , there can be no appreciable increase in live standard . in recent year , we ' ve see a reasonable amount of economic growth , but much of this be down to rise level of employment , which in turn boost overall consumption ; it add to spending power in the round , but not at an individual level . most of us be bad off than we use to be . the job boom have now very likely run its course , make the depressed OECD and OBR growth forecast all too plausible . if the vote for Brexit be at least in part a howl of rage against year of belt-tightening , just think what a further prolonged period of the same be go to do to the political landscape . the OECD have well get its model up to speed , for whatever the negative economic consequence of Brexit , they will be as nothing compare to a full-on dose of Jeremy Corbyn . if the OECD forecast look bad for Britain , it ought to be add that they do n't look particularly good for anyone . poor productivity growth be a universal disease afflict all advanced economy . for the time be , world growth be be sweep along by recovery in the previously depressed eurozone . this cyclical upswing will eventually abate , leave everyone in much the same boat as the UK , with still quite poor trade intensity compare with the pre-crisis period , not enough investment to sustain the present growth spurt , very high level of private and public indebtedness , and a distinct lack of both business dynamism and innovation . Hammond have declare that he will prove the OBR wrong on productivity . I hope he do , though I do n't see much in the government ' s industrial strategy White Paper to support the ambition . as be the way of these thing , the paper be a great deal well on the diagnosis than on likely cure . in any case , I ' m with Ronald Reagan on these matter . ` ` the nine most terrifying word in the English language be : I ' m from the government and I ' m here to help , ' ' he say . government tend to impede growth , not facilitate it . still , it might be say , at least our bank be off the critical list . accord to the Bank of England ' s late stress test , they be now sufficiently recover from the financial crisis to survive almost anything the world economy could throw at them . which be , I suppose , a relief , because far from ease since the financial crisis , overall national indebtedness - household , corporate and public combined - be now a great deal higher . and although the late forecast might look unduly gloomy , there be one thing they do n't predict which be actually almost certain - another recession . the present expansion have already be long by past standard ; that it can last another five year without mishap be almost inconceivable . it be unfortunately the case that the OBR and the OECD be be too optimistic , not too pessimistic . ' if the OECD forecast look bad for Britain , it ought to be add they do n't look that good for anyone '

a war be be fight for the soul of Britain - and the optimist must win ; the Tories must turn Britain into a free-trade haven and pledge to boost opportunity for the poor
there be two nation in Britain today , but they be not quite the one that Benjamin Disraeli have in mind . on the one hand we have the optimist , Brexiteers as well as ex-Remainers , who be gradually come together in their embrace of our new future , reunite in their determination to make the most of the next few year to reform and improve our country . on the other , we have the pessimist , a shrinking but still extraordinarily vocal group : to them , the outlook be so unbearably gloomy that they can not bring themselves to think constructively about a country they no longer recognise . the good news be that , after a few difficult week , the optimist be finally in the ascendant . Theresa May be now their official leader , as well as our Prime Minister : she do n't back Brexit , but be go to implement it with gusto . her strong leadership be exactly what be need : it be no surprise that it be prove infectious . support for the now officially pro-Brexit Tories have jump to @card@ per cent , accord to YouGov ; consumer spending be hold up , accord to the Bank of England ' s regular regional survey ; and a grow number of institution be start to propose helpful , constructive idea to make the most of Brexit . take the President of the Royal College of Surgeons : she have urge the NHS to ` ` seize the moment ' ' and use Brexit to tear up red tape that damage patient safety , include rule that prevent hospital from demand a proper mastery of English and working-time law that mean surgeon do n't undergo enough training . one lead regulator have tell me privately that leave the EU would allow a much more robust pro-competition policy ; Siemens , a pro-Remain company , now insist that it be fully commit to Britain and that it would build a ` ` huge manufacturing place ... in a heartbeat ' ' if it receive enough order for its train carriage . the list be grow visibly longer by the day . Ineos , the giant chemical maker , be relocate its headquarters and senior management back to the UK from Switzerland ; SoftBank , one of Japan ' s big company , be make the largest-ever Asian investment in the UK , argue explicitly that it believe in a post-Brexit Britain . a number of company have also agree to rent or commission new office in the City since the referendum . the optimist be not delude : they know the go will be tough , that Brexit have crystallise long-standing structural weakness in the economy , that many big company be scare , and that it will take hard work to sign trade deal and negotiate the right exit from the EU . there will be cost as well as benefit from Brexit . but they relish the challenge and be convince that we now have a once-in-ageneration opportunity to change our country and economy for the good , or simply to continue make money in one of the large , most prosperous economy in the world . then there be the pessimist . some be Remainers who still believe Brexit to be an epoch-defining catastrophe , who continue to plot and scheme to overturn the result , who cling to the derange , insulting notion that those of us who vote leave be either stupid , racist or evil , who scour the news for every negative datum point and who , in a few isolated and extreme case , would actually like a recession ` ` to prove them right ' ' . you also have some Leavers in this pessimistic camp who believe that nothing will ever change , either because we wo n't actually leave the EU or because they feel that the political class will return to business as usual . this latter group often hail from deprived community ; they vote Brexit in part to give the London establishment a kick but fear that they will continue to be ignore . the challenge for the optimist be to reunite the two Britain . they need to inspire and assuage the angry Remainers , show all but the most die-hard that the future can be rosy ; and they must reach out to those Leavers who feel that they have n't benefit enough from globalisation . all group in society have a responsibility to take part in this project to rebuild Britain for a post-Brexit 21st century . entrepreneur and firm need to propose the reform they believe be require to allow our economy to prosper outside of the EU : we need to hear solution , not whine , from business . the same be true of other professional , from university administrator to architect to the police force , as well as from the charitable sector . Britain need a ` ` can-do ' ' revolution , with as many positive idea as possible from all quarter and perspective . the question be no long whether or not to Brexit - it ' s how to make it work as well as possible for the whole country . the government , for its part , need to unveil a three-fold programme to woo the sceptic . the first pledge should be to turn Britain into the nation that be the most open to trade of any Western economy in five year ' time . to reach this target , the government would seek to limit the reimposition of tariff or non-tariff barrier with the EU , while urgently pursue as many free-trade deal as possible with faster-growing economy worldwide . the second pledge should be to make the UK the most entrepreneurfriendly country in the West by @card@ . this would include tear up red tape , cut tax , make it easy for tech firm to continue to hire skilled migrant talent , and encourage university to become incubator for start-up . last but not least , the government should make an explicit promise to Britain ' s poor group and region that their opportunity will drastically improve . the free school programme should be turbo-charged by allow for-profit company to open new one , start in the north of England and Wales before be roll out nationally ; new selective school should be open , as part of an extension of parent choice ; much more land should be make available for build in the south of England ; and expensive green energy rule should be ditch . Britain be also in desperate need of several low-tax , low-regulation new enterprise zone near university in poor part of the North and Wales , with a vision and management structure similar to London ' S Canary Wharf . it ' s be almost a month since the referendum and the optimist , thanks in large part to May ' s steady hand , be finally on the rise again . they must now begin the long , slow process of reunite the country . that be the mission on which they will ultimately be judge . follow Allister Heath on Twitter @ AllisterHeath ; Read More at www.telegraph.co.uk/ opinion

Tories must regain their own conviction body : if Brexit be the revolution , we be enter a very British , bloodless version of the Terror . there be no guillotine in Westminster , but the sexual harassment scandal have create panic - plot within plot , score to settle . rather than make history , MP be now force to ride it and pray that they emerge with their career intact . there be a way through : conviction politics . if honest , bold conservatism do n't win the revolution , there ' s a terrible risk that Jeremy Corbyn ' S socialist just might . one of the peculiarly British feature of the Brexit upheaval be that after it happen , the manager of the old system largely stay in place . it be Remainer Theresa May , in coalition with a few Leavers , who get to choose what kind of Brexit the UK would chase , and while she embrace revolutionary slogan such as ` ` Brexit mean Brexit ' ' , she fail to translate this into a compelling election message and fail to leverage the optimism of Brexit to her advantage . Mrs May wake up on June @card@ with few MP and an ascendant Labour Party . then come the harassment scandal . what have this generational verdict on workplace misogyny get to do with high politics ? the answer be that it appear to have be hijack to serve other end . the principal party in the Cabinet all have some stake in a reshuffle or the debate over Brexit . Brexit be about sovereignty and opportunity , take power from the bureaucrat and give it to the people . it would be terrible if it become tar by association with the harassment scandal , another Tory idea undo by the incompetence of Tory politician - and the smug elite of militant Remain could just sit back and watch it unravel , without lift a finger . the other battle the conservative face be with the Left . Brexit break the rule and create new possibility in politics ; one of those be Jeremy Corbyn in No @card@ . it would be deeply unjust if Labour benefit from the harassment scandal , give the accusation face by its own MP and official . but Mr Corbyn can power through this chaos with one natural advantage : he believe the end justify the mean . he be a true radical . while his ideology be well beyond the centre of British politics - alien , in fact , to most of us - there be a risk that he win simply because he offer a clear alternative to a regime in disarray . to stop him , the Tories have to regain their own sense of mission . they must do what it take to clean up politics , yes , but also unite with conviction around the delivery of Brexit , lest the people boot them out and replace them with a leader of the revolutionary leave .

May would be in sole charge , end all power struggle . all member should be move to a single venue - ideally , in @card@ Downing Street - and treat like a core executive and operational team , responsible for the negotiation . the PM would be imbue with absolute authority and bear full responsibility , which mean that she would drive the committee ' S member very hard indeed . in turn , this sense of urgency , of emergency even , would be cascade down the rank , dramatically accelerate Project Brexit . once a week , or more frequently , official would be subject to a grill by the Prime Minister , and force to tell her exactly how everything be go , the state of the preparation for a ` ` no deal ' ' outcome , and how exactly the negotiation with the EU be unfold . the aim would be not just to get thing do but also to end the current habit of obfuscation and bury bad news ; these would be Cobra-style meeting . the first few would be grim : May would be tell by ashenfaced official about the parlous state of HMRC ' S system , or the fact that the Budget contain nothing at all to help smooth Brexit . but without some internal honesty - a commodity that be sorely lack in Whitehall - nothing will ever change . the other immediate change should be to appoint Francis Maude to a new job task with reform the Civil Service , with genuine change start before the end of the year . Mark Carney say Brexit could have a ` ` material economic impact ' ' result in fall house price , rise mortgage cost and low living standard . the Bank ' S Monetary Policy Committee unanimously vote to keep interest rate at a record low of 0.5pc yesterday . the Bank cut its growth forecast over the next three year and say household spending be likely to slow regardless of the outcome of the June referendum . its quarterly inflation Report say the pound , which have already fall by 9pc against a basket of other currency since last November , could drop ` ` sharply ' ' in the aftermath of a Brexit vote , raise import cost and push up price . ' ' the Bank also suggest that a Brexit vote could spark violent market movement in an environment of evaporate liquidity that could lead to a credit crunch . the airline fly into turbulence over Brexit ; shareholder nationality could become crucial to avoid disruption , write
UK-based airline be clamour to be at the front of the queue when negotiation over Brexit begin earnest . meeting have be take place between European Union official and airline in recent week in an attempt to flesh out the issue that need to be tackle for the travel sector . there have be mount concern from the airline industry that it could be hobble if discussion between the UK and the EU turn acrimonious . the issue of Brexit be particularly acute for the airline industry give existing agreement allow company to fly between the UK and EU - as well as between mainland European country - and these will need be renegotiate before the UK formally exit the bloc . a key sticking point be that the agreement , know in the industry as EU Open Skies , be oversee by the European Court of Justice , but Theresa May , the Prime Minister , want Britain to be unencumbered by ECJ ruling . most airline have some form of contingency planning in place , and in many case this be now be act upon . EasyJet the Luton-based company could be view as the most expose to a hard Brexit because it be base in the UK and have only a UK and a Swiss air operator certificate , or AOC . the UK AOC , as thing stand , allow the company to fly between the UK and EU country ( and vice versa ) as well as between EU state . to fly between EU state post-Brexit , it be likely to need another AOC , because Switzerland be not a member of the EU . just week after the EU referendum in June easyJet say it be in the process of apply for an EU AOC , which should be enough to allow it to operate intra-European flight after March @card@ . currently only EU-owned airline can operate flight within the EU - this mean that 50.1pc of shareholder must be base in Europe . there be some flexibility to this geographic limit : for example Norwegian Air be base in Norway , which be outside the EU . however it should be note that Norway sit within what be know as the European Economic Area , which include all EU country as well as Iceland , Liechtenstein and Norway , allow the three latter nation to be part of the EU ' s single market . it be increasingly unlikely that the UK will be a member of single market after Brexit . Liberum transport analyst Gerald Khoo say the ownership and control structure that easyJet would be use - have multiple AOCs and operate company - would be the same as that of Air France-KLM . therefore , ` ` if easyJet ' S arrangement be challenge successfully [ by the EU ] , Air France-KLM would have to be break up too ' ' . a spokesman for easyJet say the company ' S headquarters would remain in the UK post-Brexit and that it be 49pc own by European shareholder at present , so cross the 50.1pc threshold under European ownership rule should be simple enough to do . Ryanair the low-cost giant be already base in Dublin and will therefore remain an EU company even once Brexit be do and dust . this mean the Irish carrier will not have any problem with its flight between EU state . however the UK be an important market for the airline and so it will be hope for the exist regulation to be replicate to ensure barrier-free fly between Britain and the EU . if this do not happen and the exist EU Open Skies policy be not replicate , it might need to apply for a domestic UK AOC to fly its intra-UK route . a potential issue for the company be the make-up of its shareholder , over half of which must be in the EU for it to operate as before . once the UK leave the EU , the percentage of EU-based owner on the Ryanair register could drop , as much of its shareholder base consist of UK-based institution . to get around this , any fund manager hold the stock could simply switch ownership from one of their UK-domiciled retail fund , sometimes know as Oeics or uni trust , into either Irish- or Luxembourg-based equivalent , often know as Sicavs . IAG British Airways , own by International Airlines Group , do not fly any intra-continental route and so would not be hit if the EU prevent UK airline fly within the confine of the bloc after March @card@ . furthermore , IAG ' s other airline include Spanish-based Iberia and Vueling , as well as Ireland-based Aer Lingus , mean the wide group already possess permission to fly within Europe . as for ownership , IAG be the listed entity and trade on both the London Stock Exchange and Madrid bourse thanks to its Spanish registered office . the company decline to provide a breakdown by nationality of its shareholder but it say it would comply with EU regulation . Qatar Airways own 20pc of IAG , but it do so via its Luxembourgbased company , something that be likely to help it maintain the necessary 50.1pc ownership by EU-based investor to continue its operation . uncertain flightpath industry want contingency for worst-case scenario it ' S important to note the mutual benefit of barrier-free travel between the UK and Europe post-Brexit - and this be something that be acknowledge by various party on either side of the Channel . Brussels-based ACI Europe , an arm of industry group Airports Council International , have express concern about the uncertainty create for the aviation industry by the Brexit . Olivier Jankovec , director general of ACI Europe , tell its annual London conference this week : ` ` as responsible business , at this stage we simply can not rule out a cliff-edged scenario for Brexit and aviation . the potential impact of this on air connectivity , consumer and the wide economy need to be address by Brexit negotiator - on both side . ` ` this mean that adequate contingency need to be establish ... in case the UK would exit the EU without any agreement on its future relationship with the bloc . ' ' he note 53.5pc of passenger handle by UK airport be fly to or from the @card@ EU member state while more than one in @card@ passenger handle by its EU airport be fly to or from the UK . nearly 40pc of Ireland ' s air traffic come from the UK while the figure be 33pc for the Slovak Republic , 31pc for Malta 20pc for Poland and 17pc for Spain . EU ' s dire warning over regulation do n't match the economic reality
shortly before he be sack in @card@ , a colleague and I interview Martin Wheatley , then-head of the Financial Conduct Authority , for the Wall Street Journal . the City be debate Brexit and we want to know what he think about the risk , as a regulator . expect dire warning , we be surprise when he declare : ` ` in the short term , not as much would change as you might think ... we ' ve operate reasonably successfully , as a number of country have , outside of the eurozone , so it ' S not to say that there be n't a model that can work but it ' S a different model . ' ' shortly afterwards , he be fire by George Osborne . he would have be sack anyway , but his rather honest assessment of Brexit ' S impact probably do n't help . yesterday , two year after that interview , Andrew Bailey , the current FCA chief , make his own contribution to the Brexit debate . his view ? Brexit require an institutional rearrangement , but should not fundamentally threaten the UK or EU ' s ability to cooperate on financial regulation and keep market open . ` ` Does [ Brexit ] require membership of the single market to get the benefit of free trade with the EU ? no , ' ' he say . protectionism and close off market ` ` be not a necessary response to the choice of Brexit ' ' , he add . in order to understand why Mr Bailey be right , it ' S helpful to know the current arrangement . at the moment , the framework for international financial regulation be agree at forum like the Financial Stability Board and Iosco , which be nothing to do with the EU . it be the FSB ' s Basel committee that come up with the Basel capital rule , a major regulatory response to the financial crisis . within the FSB , the UK be a heavyweight and respected contributor in its own right . the FSB rule be then pass down to the EU and regulator everywhere else . in Brussels , member state thrash out important detail of how to implement the framework . and then , national supervisor like the FCA ensure that the rule be implement and follow . this deep level of cooperation within the EU have help to build a consensus for open up financial market and try to keep them open . they remain much less open than the EU like to claim , but be free than they have ever be in the past . the UK have accept both this and some US involvement in supervise firm in London as a quid pro quo for open market . it be easy to see how , post-Brexit , these arrangement could be adjust to ensure that the EU and UK continue to cooperate on financial service regulation . the UK will still be intimately involve in the FSB , Iosco and other forum . thereafter , the difference be that Britain will decide for itself how to implement those framework and will negotiate cross-border arrangement with the EU from the outside , rather than inside . as both Mr Wheatley and Mr Bailey have point out , the UK be unlikely to embark on a regulatory bonfire and , indeed , often make rule much tough than the international framework require . it should therefore be possible for Brussels and London to agree that their financial regime be both highly rigorous , to set up a mechanism for how to resolve any future divergence or dispute , and to allow EU-UK trade to continue unimpeded . at the same time as Mr Bailey be deliver his speech in Canary Wharf , however , Michel Barnier , the EU Brexit negotiator , be give his own oration across the Channel in Brussels . Mr Barnier ' S message be very different from Mr Bailey ' S . ` ` you can not leave the single market and then opt in to those sector you like most - say , the automobile industry and financial service , ' ' he say . ` ` [ some ] argue that one can leave the single market and keep all of its benefit - that be not possible . ' ' as far as financial service be concern , Mr Bailey disagree . he argue it be possible to keep market open without be inside the single market , provide the UK and EU be prepare to cooperate on regulation . the UK , Mr Bailey have indicate , certainly be . the EU begin to recognise the importance of cooperate with non-EU country several year ago , in an initiative that Mr Barnier himself lead . it start with the need for EU client to use derivative trade platform provide by US firm , for which they need EU regulatory authorisation . the EU therefore build something call the ` ` equivalence ' ' regime . its regulator would assess whether or not US rule govern its derivative platform be as rigorous as the EU ' S . this be an arduous process but , eventually , the US be indeed deem equivalent in this area , free up derivative market . what the UK now face be a long , tortuous tussle over equivalence . it wo n't always be easy and Britain will have to argue its case constantly against protectionist or destructive demand , but the basis for cooperate to keep market open already exist . the alternative be that the EU decide to single out Britain for particularly punish treatment . proponent of this approach claim that London can not use the ` ` equivalence ' ' regime and need special , disadvantageous treatment because the eurozone be so reliant on its market . but freeze out London while cooperate with New York will simply push activity to the US , over which the EU have very little influence . the EU face the same choice over clearing . we be tell over and over by naysayer that clearing would be ` ` stripped ' ' from London if Britain vote leave . but when the new rule come out last month , Brussels have blink . after all the rhetoric , it settle just for give its regulator the potential power to force euro clearing house to move into the EU - a power that be unlikely to actually be use because it will impose huge cost on European firm . so Mr Barnier can issue ` ` wake-up call ' ' and warning , if he like . but the economic reality be that EU and UK financial regulator need to work together for our mutual benefit . it wo n't always be a harmonious working relationship , but it will work . the only alternative be for the EU to shoot itself in the foot by cut its firm off from the world ' s big financial centre . as Winston Churchill observe , ` ` attitude be a little thing that make a big difference ' ' . it ' S time , on all side of the Brexit debate , to stop carp and unite to deliver the good deal for Britain . sure , a vocal but dwindle minority of diehard Remain MP and unelected peer will continue to predict doom and try to trip Brexit up . but they be pit themselves squarely against the popular mood . accord to YouGov , the public be now commit by three to one to respect the referendum , however they vote , and make Brexit work . in Scotland , that view hold , too , by two to one - with an even large proportion of Remain voter resolve to see Brexit through than across the rest of Britain . just @card@ per cent of Scots back Nicola Sturgeon ' s SNP in seek to frustrate the process . during the roller-coaster of Brexit negotiation , this grow moderate majority need to be guardian of the nation ' s blood pressure , avoid over-reacting to every bump along the way . take the economic good news last week . somehow , record employment datum , dip inflation and Google ' s announcement of £1 billion of fresh investment in the UK be eclipse by medium furore over a fake memo by Deloitte , dress up as a critical review of the government ' s Brexit preparation . it be a classic triumph of tittle-tattle over what really matter . similarly , we risk miss positive political development . for all the understandable concern around the US election , President Trump will offer Britain the opportunity of a free-trade deal shun by Barack Obama , as well as present ( more regrettably ) a key role in shore up our European ally within Nato . and last week the German Chancellor , Angela Merkel , publicly signal her flexibility on free movement , a significant diplomatic move before formal Brexit talk - or German election - have even begin . as more and more Remainers make their peace with the referendum result , we Brexiteers need to avoid sound miserly . at home and on the continent , we ' ve leave people in little doubt as to what we ' re against . they be less clear about what we ' re for . I support the @card@ Conservative MP who have say publicly that Britain should leave the custom union , because we ca n't deliver on the Prime Minister ' s ambition to end free movement and the jurisdiction of the European Court , or make Britain a global leader in free trade , without do so . but we also need to set out a positive and optimistic vision of the UK ' s relationship with the EU after Brexit - for the British people , and our European friend . Britain ' S ambition should be to prove we can be an even well European neighbour , free from the fetter of the flawed political club . Let ' s start talk the language of friendship with a great generosity of spirit . for its part , the government be wise to avoid dripfeeding its negotiate stance into the public domain , which would just offer critic - at home and on the continent - a target for their daily sniping . equally , the Prime Minister have commit to spell out the high-level principle guide our negotiate strategy by the new year . that will be crucial to communicate a compelling , positive offer we can take to Brussels . what should that package include ? our top negotiate priority should be to avoid new barrier to trade - base on rational , economic and mutual selfinterest . we should n't just be take this message to European www.governments.UK politician and business leader should be permanently tour Europe , speak to industry , business group and union , make the case for maintain our current trading tie , and avoid the harm that protectionist measure would inflict on UK and - disproportionately - European profit and job . we need to be equally clear , with diplomatic brow duly furrow , that we take no solace from the fact that apply the EU ' s external tariff would bring in £8 billion more to the UK than the EU in tariff revenue . it ' s not what we want . Brussels would have to force us into such a retrograde move . second , as a net contributor to EU justice and home affair cooperation , Britain should offer to maintain - and enhance - our commitment to collaborate on security matter . from data-sharing to joint police investigation at Europol , depart from the EU be no bar to operational law-enforcement cooperation . we must leave our fellow European in no doubt that Britain be loath to abandon them in the aftermath of the terrorist attack in Brussels and Paris . likewise , we stand shoulder to shoulder in solidarity with our Baltic and eastern European ally in the face of the increasingly bellicose Russian president , Vladimir Putin - whatever President Trump do . third , rule out acceptance of EU free movement hardly preclude sensible reciprocal arrangement on immigration . we can offer visa waiver for tourism and business trip , flexible term to allow recruitment of top European talent by UK company and a permit system for skilled labour . between open-door immigration and pull up the drawbridge , there be ample scope for a deal that preserve UK national control over the volume of immigration , as well as the sensitive rule on skill eligibility , welfare entitlement , residence condition and security check . the public have see with its own eye that Remain ' s referendum forecast of economic Armageddon post-Brexit be partisan propaganda . they now yearn for some unity of purpose to make the good of Brexit , and mitigate the real risk and genuine uncertainty that be inherent in the process . accord to ComRes , two third of Briton feel positive about Britain ' s post-Brexit future . meanwhile , a survey this month by US consultancy Synechron find that @card@ per cent of UK banker believe London will still be the financial centre of Europe in five year ' time . forget the medium froth , there be quiet but grow confidence that the UK will thrive outside the EU . Britain be strong enough to withstand the economic buffet of Brexit , and we should be confident enough to make a generous overture to our European friend . now , we need a positive attitude and a unite front , reach out across the overwhelming majority who want to make Brexit work , however they vote back in June . with a Churchillian dose of stubborn optimism , we can grasp the kind of deal most people want - and see Britain go from strength to strength . use radical idea to energise a free Britain

this be n't about say I-told-you-so to Remain supporter - they be as concern about our country ' s future as us and deserve respect . nor be it about put head in the sand and pretend Brexit pose no challenge . but support Brexit be too often portray as a vote to turn back the clock . nothing could be further from the truth . for us , the referendum be about two competing vision of Britain ' S future - and we be excite about our prospect as a dynamic , global , independent nation . it be vital we start emphasise this optimistic vision . because if we sleepwalk into see the next two year as an exercise in damage limitation , we will wake up to find a once-in-a-generation opportunity have slip through our finger . and , like it or not , that failure will be blame on us conservative . if we lose confidence in Brexit as a party , we should n't be surprise if the British people lose confidence in us . in five key area the government must use this Parliament to make sure that do n't happen . the first be trade . free of the custom union , we can use our new power to link our exporter to dynamic growth around the world . simultaneously , the government should scrap the tariff protect EU special interest , a move that would instantly lower price for British shopper . second , immigration . not one of us believe in pull up the drawbridge to international talent . but , by refuse to give the public a say on how low-skill immigration be manage , the EU have cause faith in the system to collapse . by introduce a humane , controlled immigration regime that recognise talent and show compassion , we have an opportunity to regain the public trust necessary to reinvigorate British internationalism and once again become a beacon for the world ' s bright . next come regulation . just like company , government innovate good when they compete . it ' S not surprising , therefore , that European collectivism have leave our regulation flabby . Brexit be an opportunity to spur our regulator to innovate , force them to make rule that revitalise our economy , not bog it down in red tape . the fourth opportunity be economic innovation . Brexit can be our industrial strategy ' s rocket fuel . thanks to restrictive state aid rule , EU membership make support for infrastructure , like broadband , subject to onerous approval process or bureaucratic work arounds . Brexit be a chance to sweep these aside . well still , we can start use innovative tool currently constrain by the EU , such as beef up , low-tax enterprise zone and free port to attract job and investment to the country ' s most deprived area . last , but most importantly , Brexit be a chance to revitalise our democracy . by muddy the water of accountability , EU membership have make it too easy for politician in Westminster to pass the buck to Brussels . or they struggle against an interventionist European court that do n't reflect British value . with a clean break from the EU , British voter will once again know exactly who be responsible for everything , from support the steel industry and keep our river clean to set the VAT on tampon and raise animal welfare standard , make it easy to kick out lawmaker who do n't have their own bold conviction . opportunity like these be what Brexit mean to us and why we vote to set Britain on this bold future course . we British have always be suspicious of radical idea . but if ever our country need to soften its upper lip , to energise it politics with passion , imagination , and optimism it be now . we ' ve spend long enough on the back foot . it ' s time to shout about that idealistic and hopeful vision for post-Brexit Britain and find the self-confidence to deliver it for the British people . MP must be allow to improve the Brexit Bill - but not thwart it ; Labour have move beyond fair scrutiny into actively weaken our country ' s negotiate position
shortly after the General Election , I fear the new makeup of Parliament would prove toxic for Brexit . the government , I think , would n't be able to pass law either to implement Brexit sensibly or prepare for a ` ` no deal ' ' collapse in talk . the EU , see our dilemma , would offer Britain a dreadful , take-it-or-leave-it deal as the only alternative to crash out . I ' m not quite as pessimistic as I be , but last week the government run into the first roadblock that I be worry about . it be force to postpone its most significant piece of legislation so far , the EU Withdrawal Bill , after MP table as many as @card@ amendment . the government now face a hard reality : how can it pass the law need to implement Brexit through a Parliament dead set against it ? to navigate its way through , it must engage not only in negotiation abroad but with its own MP . that must involve concession . there be plenty of reasonable concession it could make . the simple purpose of the bill be to transpose into UK law all of the EU rule we have be obey for @card@ year - and to do it quickly - so that we do n't face a legal vacuum in March @card@ . without it , MP would have to debate and vote upon some @card@ measure in the next @card@ month - clearly impossible . however , in order to achieve its aim , the Bill have to do some rather unpalatable thing . it give the government all sort of unusual power , like the ability to rewrite huge swathe of regulation without parliamentary scrutiny . doubtless many of these power will be need because of the unpredictability of Britain ' s talk with the EU . our government can not negotiate certain important matter , like whether and how to cooperate on drug regulation for example , if Parliament have preemptively nail down an answer . it need legal room for manoeuvre . at the same time , there be reason to be very careful when hand the government what be effectively , in the word of Tory MP and former attorney general Dominic Grieve , ` ` a blank cheque ' ' . Power can not be trust to police itself . acknowledge this do not amount to betray Brexit . in judge Parliament ' S behaviour , therefore , it be very important to distinguish between those MP and amendment whose aim really be to sabotage Brexit and those that be simply do what Parliament be mean to do : scour the bill for risk , excessive power-grabs , contradiction and legal ambiguity . though I do n't agree with all of his suggest change to the bill , it seem that Mr Grieve ' S activity fit into the latter category . among the worry he and other have express be that the government be give itself more power than necessary while remove people ' S right to challenge that power . for example , the Bill hand minister the power to amend legislation derive from EU law without any scrutiny from MP . that might make sense when adjust supervisory process for bank , but a lot of other law be be sweep up in the same category . one example be the @card@ Equality Act , which outlaw discrimination in the workplace . this be a controversial area in which to let a government rewrite the law without oversight . then there be the ambiguity . for example , the Government say it intend to transfer various EU legal right and obligation into British law . one example be the EU state aid regime , which stop state from bail out industry on a whim . the EU test for whether state aid be allow be whether or not it distort trade and competition ` ` between member state ' ' . it be impossible to translate this straightforwardly into UK law , yet the current bill seem to attempt exactly that . by what method remain unclear . just consider the problem arise from such legal ambiguity . the first danger be that post-Brexit Britain face a gamut of lawsuit from company or individual argue over what exactly the law mean . but there be another , political danger that should concentrate Tory mind in particular . imagine that Jeremy Corbyn be to win the next election and find himself preside over this legal morass . various protection , like state aid rule , that have for year insure against a return to untrammelled socialist excess might disappear just at the moment that voter hand power to a genuine Marxist . only yesterday , Mr Corbyn be boast that he be , as Phillip Hammond warn , an ` ` existential threat ' ' to Britain ' s economic model . should we really , for the sake of Brexit fervour , remove various safety feature design to check government power just as Mr Corbyn get close to it himself ? but , while many MP , include Mr Grieve , think Parliament should get a final vote on the Brexit deal , Labour ' S policy go further . Shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer have make it clear any deal Britain negotiate with the EU will always in his view be preferable to no deal . Labour will never , he say , vote to endorse a ` ` no deal ' ' Brexit . there be two problem with this . the first , obvious one be that it send the message that the EU can dictate whatever term it like , because our Parliament will swallow anything rather than let the government walk away from the table . this be deeply unhelpful . the second problem be that Labour seem to assume that if Parliament reject ` ` no deal ' ' it will effectively stop Brexit . in fact , since Article @card@ have already be trigger , we have no idea what such a vote would do , but it would likely add to the legal chaos and ensue economic shock cause by crash out . in reality , Labour ' S position be entirely self-serving . it be use parliamentary procedure to state , pre-emptively : ` ` do n't blame me . ' ' the party vote to trigger Article @card@ and have be ambiguous about Brexit , but at the end of the process , it want a chance to disown the whole thing . this would be legitimate party politics but for one shameful fact : it actively damage Britain ' s negotiate position just when we need to show strength . Brexit be a task of great complexity . there be bind to be correction and amendment need along the way . MP should not be pillory for do their job . but those MP who use their leverage to send political message that damage Britain ' s negotiate position should think long and hard about whose interest they be serve . follow Juliet Samuel on Twitter @ CitySamuel ; read more at www.telegraph.co.uk/ opinion

the good company embrace change
I ' ve long have a problem with publicly own company do politics . they can and should do policy , of course : they certainly owe it to their shareholder to try to influence the law and tax that affect them directly . they be also perfectly entitle to fight for capitalism in a broad sense : without that , they would n't exist . but there be a line that should n't be cross . they should n't explicitly back a political party or a particular side in a referendum . that should be the preserve of private individual and private company . PLCs should try to make the good of democratic decision , and they should accept and embrace big social trend . it be genuine progress , for example , that big business increasingly embrace modern society as it be currently be , and be desperate to hire a diverse workforce . major election and referendum often reflect another kind of social change ; that too need to be absorb by the business community . which bring us to Brexit : the job of PLCs be to try to mould the outcome in a way that be good for them , or for the economy as a whole , not to seek to reverse it . some bank have a real challenge on their hand , because of the EU ' s protectionist attitude to the selling of financial service : but they should seek way around it , and replacement trade arrangement , not campaign against Brexit per se . it be fair for company who believe that their business have be damage by a side-effect of Brexit to say so ( for example , the partly irrational slump in sterling have damage retailer that import the kind of product it be n't feasible to produce in the UK ) . but other that have n't really be affect should n't use the referendum as an excuse for poor management or bad luck . conversely , firm that have do well from what have already happen as a result of Brexit should be free to say so . export volume of manufactured good have be booming , thanks to the weak pound : there be a @card@ percentage point rise in the three-month year-on-year rolling average growth rate between July @card@ and March @card@ follow the EU referendum vote , accord to the Office for National Statistics . the reality be that the good company be those that always embrace change . they realise that it be pointless and stupid to fight against the tide of history and do their good to make the most of it . one of the good response to Brexit to date from a major business - and one that certainly meet my criterion of what a firm should say when confront with major political change - come from Burberry this week . Christopher Bailey , chief creative officer , say as part of the company ' s late result presentation that the potential for post-Brexit Britain be ` ` enormous ' ' . he point out , quite sensibly , that his company be ` ` absolutely committed ' ' to keep its manufacturing in the UK . even well , he argue that ` ` Britishness resonate globally ' ' and that his business now have a huge opportunity to grow . this be the sort of upbeat talk that real leader understand to be necessary in time such as these . he be absolutely right - just as he be right to warn that restriction to immigration should n't become so severe as to make it too hard to operate a dynamic business from London . his intervention be pitch exactly right , and it be worth remember that Bailey , like many other big business leader , back Remain . so this be my new litmus test : I respect business that embrace the upside of Brexit and that seek to mitigate the downsides in a constructive , sensible manner that be respectful of the UK ' s democratic choice . I respect those that come up with plan to make Brexit work as well as possible , in the short as well as long term . I do n't respect those that seek to bully or blackmail the UK into reverse our choice . and , guess what - I bet that upbeat , optimistic firm such as Burberry will do much good than those that still refuse to accept the new political reality . without a free trade vision , we may lose our Brexit opportunity
proverb @card@ in the King James Bible state , ` ` where there be no vision the people perish ' ' . in a contemporary context the verse make me think ` ` where there be no vision Brexit perish ' ' . the Prime Minister ' s Florence and conference speech be n't about the ` ` vision thing ' ' - a vision of Britain ' s place in the world , a new , outward-looking , dynamic economy , eager to exploit post-EU freedom to become the ultimate offshore economy , very free , very big and very wealthy . but that ' s the vision that need to be sell . instead of be iffy about abandon the EU regulatory state , the Prime Minister and Chancellor should embrace the offshore potential exhibit by small economy such as Singapore and Hong Kong . per capita nominal GDP ( in US dollar ) in Singapore be 33pc high than in the UK . we should abandon the EU regulatory state and embrace economic freedom with alacrity . turn away from interventionism and towards economic freedom be much more than abandon statism at home . it be also about abandon protectionism abroad . it be about the destruction of the protectionist fortress that be the EU Common External tariff , and its replacement with classical free trade and zero-tariff and non-tariff barrier on import from every country in the world . this be the true Holy Grail of Brexit : zero-tariff and non-tariff barrier on import from everywhere . unfortunately , HM Treasury see the Holy Grail as precisely the opposite - zero-tariff and non-tariff barrier on our export to the EU . if the Prime Minister be to project a vision of opportunity post Brexit , she need to abandon the Treasury world view with alacrity as well . wed to its gravity model and ridiculous projection of what Brexit would do to the economy in the short and long term , HM Treasury have box itself into a corner and ca n't get out.Unfortunately it mean the post-Brexit vision be box into a corner as well . the electorate be desperate for a positive vision of Brexit . it have vote to leave the EU and now want its political leader to promise the world and deliver it . somebody need to brief the Prime Minister on the remarkable opportunity that have land on her doorstep , which she seem unaware of . First be the historic opportunity to implement classical free trade . the Prime Minister have the opportunity to go down in history as the First Lord of the Treasury who deliver the Holy Grail . in his biography of Sir Robert Peel , the Prime Minister who lead the 19th century abolition of the Corn Laws , Douglas Hurd state : ` ` he do not invent the doctrine of free trade . but Sir Robert be in undisputed charge of the crucial country at the crucial moment . ' ' Second be the political opportunity.The treasury perspective on Brexit be producer drive , whereas classical free trade be drive by the consumer and the gain they will receive from trading at low world price - a difference that could be 10pc to 20pc . the gain to consumer from classical free trade be huge . the Prime Minister have an unprecedented opportunity to be on the side of the little guy and show why free market competition be good for everyone . classical free trade will lower price and boost the spending power of consumer in the short term and raise long-term productivity and income . third , classical free trade provide a deliverable opportunity . if the government promise it they can deliver it . it ' s a decision entirely within the control of the government . it do n't have to be negotiate with the EU , all it require be lodge a tariff schedule full of zero with the WTO . fourth , Brexit provide an opportunity for moral leadership . classical free trade be a truly selfless policy . it ' s a world apart from selfish protectionism or even self-interested trade negotiation . it could be our great export to the world . classical free trade be also an enlightened policy because at its heart lie the counter intuitive truth that by move to trade at world price , powerful positive economic force be unleash . this be the economic opportunity from Brexit . the economic opportunity come in two part . First be the static effect , whereby low import price free up the spending power of consumer to purchase other good and service . the full effect of tariff and non-tariff barrier impose by the EU have be estimate to raise import price 10pc to 20pc compare with world price . this be a huge potential boost to the discretionary spending power of consumer . second be the dynamic effect . this be the spur of great competition on UK producer , which raise productivity and make both producer and consumer well off in the long run . then there be the entrepreneurial opportunity . Brexit provide the opportunity to systematically take down the regulatory state and its impact on product and labour market . it ' s an opportunity to implement common sense regulation alongside common sense value . however the entrepreneurial opportunity should not end there . the government should seize the moment and announce a breathtaking shift in tax policy to boost the UK ' S competitiveness . the obvious example would be to say corporation tax would be reduce to 10pc by @card@ . there ' S also the opportunity to use classical free trade to boost the City . the big advocate of free trade would be home to the big financial centre . talk about great brand and alignment in a 21st century network world . this be an opportunity that would grow and grow as the EU pursue its desire for a financial transaction tax . finally , post Brexit the UK could get its geopolitical relationship with the EU and the rest of the world right . the analogy here for the EU be that we all have great friend , but if we marry them that relationship could end in divorce . one can get too close with certain friend and that undermine instead of strengthen the relationship . with regard to the rest of the world , opportunity for free trade agreement abound , but there be also the opportunity to develop deep trading relationship with the Anglosphere - the US , Canada , Australia and New Zealand . these economy already account for 33pc of global GDP with the UK . the fall in the price of food as a result of the abolition of the Corn Laws unleash a tremendous rise in production from factory aid by the new rail economy . this can be surpass in the 21st century by free trade and the new network economy . in the word of the Foreign Secretary , we need to ` ` let the lion roar ' ' . the Chancellor ' S Autumn Statement take its cue from the Office for Budget Responsibility ' s downward-biased forecast for Britain ' s Brexit economy . it and he fail to take account of the optimal policy for carry Brexit through . these be free trade with low consumer price and more competition , good ( home-based ) regulation and intelligent control of immigration to limit costly unskilled immigration . the OBR follow the Remain consensus argument that Brexit will reduce trade ; via fall sterling , reduce growth ; reduce immigration generally ; and cause damaging uncertainty . for the follow reason that consensus be wrong : @card@ the Brexit uncertainty effect be small - and also positive . as we have see already , the effect of any Brexit ` ` uncertainty ' ' have be minimal : in the second and third quarter when it be at its maximum , growth be strong at @card@ per cent and @card@ per cent . ` ` uncertainty ' ' simply consist of not yet be sure that we will have a clean Brexit ( with positive result for growth ) or a ` ` soft ' ' Brexit which be the status quo . so any uncertainty be about the extent of the upside . 2 the average fall in sterling against other major currency of about @card@ per cent be a huge monetary stimulus to the economy . it raise export , reduce import and so raise income ; this in turn stimulate employment and consumption . yes , price will rise but then so will wage in the tight labour market we now have . @card@ Brexit will increase trade not reduce it . how can opening the UK up to free trade with the whole world , include the EU , reduce trade ? Whitehall be unable to grasp the idea of such free trade , yet ordinary people do , even if they work within EU-protected sector such as manufacturing . for example , all car-making constituency vote leave , for the good reason that our car industry sell two third of its export outside the EU on world market . the long-term bonus for the UK economy from the opening up of our trade to the world would , I estimate , be around @card@ per cent on GDP , with an @card@ per cent fall in consumer price act like a big tax cut for UK household . @card@ unskilled EU immigration be a drain on our taxpayer and the economy . Remainers in Whitehall endlessly bang on about the gain from immigration ( which we all accept ) . they do not grasp that the economic problem of immigration consist exclusively of allow unskilled immigrant on low wage unfettered access to our welfare state , both for themselves and for any dependant they bring in . the well available Labour Force Survey datum suggest that each adult EU unskilled immigrant cost the UK taxpayer around £3,500 a year . this burden fall on the poor community where these immigrant live and where , to add insult to injury , they also drive down local wage . control unskilled immigration - while be as liberal as now on skilled immigration that more than pay its way - be the optimal policy . on these four point the OBR and Chancellor have get it wrong , wrong , wrong and wrong . we expect good in future . this indulgent Tory infighting risk turn Brexit into a national disaster ; Cabinet minister must stop put their own ambition and grudge before the national interest
human like to think we be good than animal . sometimes , though , observe beast can tell us a lot about human behaviour . when , for example , a pack of dog lose its leader , the hound often descend into a power struggle , snarl and scrap to test one another ' S strength . as it turn out , Cabinet minister be n't so different from dog . with Theresa May humble by the general election , the Cabinet be now in an open war with itself . it ' S not a pretty sight . minister be send out ` ` friend ' ' to brief against one another and accuse their colleague of skulduggery on Sunday chat show . the conflict supposedly revolve around enormous policy difference between great and powerful rival . the truth , though , be that the government ' s war faction be not as far apart as they look . their power struggle be about personality , not policy , and it be threaten to turn Brexit into a disaster . on the face of it , the ongoing disagreement about Brexit - soft or hard , fast or slow - look fundamental . the fight in Parliament , between die-hard Remainers and the rest , have an epic feel to it . but among minister there be , in fact , a broad consensus . hard-headed politician , Remain and leave , accept that Brexit must be implement and they mostly agree that it should be do sensibly , with a reasonable transition period . both side in this fight , from arch-Brexiteer David Davis to Remainerin-chief Philip Hammond , accept this reality . they both want the Brexit transition to be time-limited . they both want to negotiate a final deal with as low an exit fee as possible , conditional upon a free-trade agreement . they might disagree over the timeline and the trade-offs that Britain face , but these outcome will be determine by the negotiation in Brussels , not by theoretical argument in Cabinet . the government ' S division be spread , however . recently , a new fissure have open up on fiscal policy . the fight centre on whether to loosen the purse string for public sector pay . Mr Hammond , ever the fiscal hawk , say no . his rival , lead by Michael Gove , disagree . but the difference , as with Brexit , be n't as wide as it look . listen to the nuance on both side , and you ' ll hear the fiscal dove admit that they have little appetite for a massive spending splurge , while Mr Hammond admit there be certain recruitment problem in public service that must be address . in other word , the Cabinet policy split be not irresolvable . the more vicious row be about power and presentation : should the Tories adjust the pay cap quietly or ostentatiously ? and , crucially , who get to decide ? these fight , over Brexit and fiscal policy , need n't tear the government apart . unfortunately , with the premiership seemingly up for grab , ambitious minister smell an opportunity . they be exaggerate their difference to set out their stall and drum up support . meanwhile , on its two most important political battlefield , the government be adrift . the legislation need to implement Brexit face threat from all side , start with the repeal bill , which will shift all our current law on to British , rather than EU , foundation . even without a majority , an authoritative government might have railroad its bill through Parliament . instead , the Cabinet have declare open season on itself . MP be form themselves into raid party , ready to attack the legislation with all sort of amendment and obstruction . and this be only the first of many bill . if the situation in Parliament be bad , it be even bad in Brussels . a government without the command of its own Cabinet and MP be in no position to strike highly contentious political agreement abroad . the Whitehall machinery seem to be in disarray . its Brexit planning operation be so fragile that , accord to the chief of the National Audit Office , it ' S liable to ` ` fall apart like a chocolate orange ' ' . our new EU ambassador hardly seem to be involve , have not even move to Brussels for the job . and as their minister tussle , civil servant be lock in turf war or toil away on policy that might be abandon or alter as the government ' S strategy evolve . the chaos mean that our negotiate team can not guarantee that its promise or demand will not shift or fall apart later . this be poison for a negotiation , substantially raise the risk that the talk will fall apart . if so , the public wo n't easily forgive the conservative . it ' S one thing for Brexit negotiation to collapse over a fundamentally irresolvable disagreement . it be quite another for them to fail because the government be simply too incompetent and wrack with infighting . none of this be necessary or inevitable . it have come about because Cabinet minister be put their own ambition and grudge before the national interest . they should instead be play a long game . their electoral success be tie to that of Brexit , and that wo n't be determine by a quick , sharp skirmish . it be a long , protracted battle and , with the EU ' s own institution evolve , a shrewd , well-run British government may well have opportunity to further its interest in the year ahead . in order to get there , though , two thing need to happen . the first be that the conservative must fill their leadership vacuum . fight dog only quieten down once they establish definitively who be master and who be follower . likewise , the government will only regain stability through a leadership contest or a grand bargain between the major player that be support by MP . after that , whoever be in charge need to create a policy consensus by admit that it want a sensible transitional deal before it tackle longer-term matter , like develop our future immigration policy and build the infrastructure it require . this would enable MP of different stripe to rally behind a programme and create space for Parliament and the public to scrutinise the fine detail of policy , head off unnecessary row like Britain ' s Euratom withdrawal . the government be in a terrible mess of its own making . but it can be unmake . if it be n't , voter will deliver a harsh verdict at the next election - and the Conservatives will roundly deserve it . follow Juliet Samuel on Twitter @ CitySamuel ; read more at www.telegraph.co.uk/ opinion
we will be bribe with our own cash
at time like this I turn to history for enlightenment . back in the year @card@ , there be five Roman emperor . the result be chaos for Rome . and thing be n't exactly hunky-dory for the emperor either . the first four lose their life . this year could turn out to be similarly chaotic - although hopefully it will only be political career that be lose . it be ironic that the Brexit negotiation start on June @card@ , the same day as the Queen ' s Speech in Parliament . if the government ' S programme be not pass , then there would surely have to be a change of prime minister , and possibly another general election . since the political future be so uncertain , large part of our economic future be uncertain too , include what sort of Brexit we will secure and , indeed , whether Brexit will happen at all . such uncertainty be debilitate for the economy . nevertheless , there be some reassuring precedent . ' it will be difficult to enact the measure necessary to in @card@ , the Labour Party under Harold make Brexit work ' Wilson win the general election with a majority of only four seat . this make govern extremely difficult . two year later , however , he secure a big majority . the economy perform reasonably well . in @card@ , Harold Wilson again win most seat but it be a hung parliament . in the second election in October he achieve a three seat majority . Labour cling on with support from the liberal until @card@ . this period be widely regard as one of the bad in live memory , with high inflation and serious industrial unrest . yet the economy grow at an average annual rate of 3pc . towards the end of John Major ' S government , the economy continue to grow strongly , even though he have lose his majority . more recently , the election of @card@ produce a hung parliament , lead to the Conservative-Lib Dem coalition , under which the economy recover and the budget deficit be considerably reduce . and the uncertainty cause by last year ' s Brexit vote do not impede Britain ' S growth . so the economy can be remarkably resilient in the face of political upset and uncertainty . nevertheless , it would not be surprising if some real investment in the economy be now put on hold or consumer decide to rein in their spending a bit . either would depress the economic growth rate . fortunately , there be an offset , namely the weakness of the pound , which should bolster Britain ' s net export . uncertainty may be a bad thing , but the way it be eventually resolve can also have adverse economic effect . if we land up with a Labour Government under Jeremy Corbyn then both government spending and tax would rise . this be exactly the opposite of what need to happen to make Brexit work well for Britain . even if current uncertainty be resolve by the continuation of Mrs May , or someone else , as the head of a Conservative minority government , Brexit will be messy . she call the election supposedly to strengthen her hand in the Brexit negotiation . presumably it follow that her , or her successor ' S , hand be now weak . moreover , whether the UK secure a deal or not , it will be difficult to enact the sort of radical measure that be necessary to make Brexit work . for the British people seem to be tire of austerity . they want improve public service and various other goody , to be pay for , of course , by someone else . the Labour manifesto offer exactly this , include the abolition of tuition fee , which go down well with many student . by contrast , the Conservative manifesto offer the opposite , include plan to end the triple lock on pension . whatever happen in the next few week , it be surely go to be difficult for the Conservative Party to face the electorate again with so few goody in the shop window . in view of this , the agenda that many of us have hope a Conservative government would pursue coincident with Brexit , namely continue pressure on public expenditure enable radical reduction in tax , no longer seem very plausible . I fear that we may be in an era when the political party compete to bribe us with our own money . that be exactly what Roman emperor use to do with the provision of bread and circus . our Brexit Bill need no amendment ; ESTABLISHED @card@ body : at first glance , the amendment to the EU ( Notification of Withdrawal ) Bill in the House of Lords give Parliament a ` ` meaningful vote ' ' on a Brexit deal may look innocuous . after all , Britain have vote to restore the primacy of its own Parliament , so why should that Parliament not decide on the Brexit deal ? that be the argument that advocate will make for the amendment , which may well be endorse in the Upper House and conceivably by the House of Commons next week , since a number of Conservative MP be say to be mind to support it there . yet that argument be flaw and this amendment should not pass . the flaw be both practical and principled . the practical flaw be find in the effect this amendment would have on Brexit negotiation . it be no secret that some EU leader still believe that Britain can be persuade to reverse its decision to leave ; the EU , after all , have a history of try to overturn democratic vote , even referendum decision , a contempt for the electorate that partly explain why the integrationist project be fail . if those leader believe that the British Parliament could reject any Brexit deal and instead continue our membership , they will have a strong incentive to offer the bad deal possible . the principled objection to the amendment be that it misinterpret the referendum vote and its meaning . Britain have indeed vote to restore national sovereignty , free itself from EU rule and return to a situation where the law and decision that affect the British people be make by politician accountable to the British people . but that do not mean that Parliament must now govern : that be the job of minister . the proper arrangement be that minister make decision and then account for those decision to the representative of the British people in Parliament . that be what should happen on the Brexit deal . in truth , the bid for a ` ` meaningful vote ' ' for Parliament be simply a ruse , an undeclared attempt to defy and eventually reverse the instruction the people give at the referendum . the same be true of the argument by the liberal democrat and other that the deal should be put to a second referendum . if the Remainers really want to force the question over the final deal to a vote , perhaps the proper forum be , as Lord Hague suggest opposite , a general election . whenever that election come , we be confident the electorate will strongly endorse Mrs May ' s handling of our EU exit .

close trade will secure our special relation
it have be just over @card@ year since Winston Churchill introduce the phrase ` ` special relationship ' ' to describe the intimate bond between the United States and the United Kingdom . despite its longevity , even the good relationship require work . in this moment - with a new and unconventional president in my country and grow political , economic and security challenge in the UK - that work necessitate a discussion about how we approach issue like Brexit , the economic relationship between our country , and the grow threat of terrorism . but first , what the special relationship be not . while our unique and beneficial association have endure through @card@ US president and @card@ British prime minister , it be not principally a relationship between two elect leader . even Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher find their relationship strain by such thing as the war in the Falkland . I have experience the special relationship through three distinct lens : first as a student study at Edinburgh , second as majority leader in the US House of Representatives , and now as the vice-chairman of a US-based investment bank with office and extensive business in the UK . what make the relationship special be the closeness of our people and our shared belief in principle of self-government , free enterprise , and human freedom and dignity . the US be strengthen when the UK be strengthen , which be why we both need a Brexit that provide certainty and great economic opportunity for the UK . while we may share common goal , the task of conclude a successful Brexit belong to the UK ' S leader . the US government should offer support in the Brexit negotiation , but must recognise that , at time , the good support may be in the form of space for UK and EU leader to manoeuvre . in the US , we must do a good job of ignore the noise of the day and instead remain focus on the overriding objective : a successful conclusion to Brexit . while UK official be negotiate , business leader on both side of the pond must continue to do what we do good : look for opportunity for great business engagement between the US and UK firm . even with the political uncertainty around Brexit , there be ample opportunity for investment and growth . at the appropriate time , our elect leader should further cement the economic tie between our two nation with a robust trade agreement , which through the elimination of tariff and non-tariff barrier can serve as a model for the rest of the world . goal for a US-UK trade agreement must include ease market access - especially for service industry - strengthen investment procedure , include through appropriate dispute resolution mechanism , facilitate cross-border datum flow , and great co-operation on the protection of intellectual property . the reduction of non-tariff barrier , especially in government regulation , between the US and Europe , be a major goal of the now-stalled Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership ( TTIP ) . there be a tremendous opportunity to enhance the economic tie between the US and the UK via a trade agreement that achieve for our two country the goal of TTIP - namely great regulatory co-operation and standard setting , include in the financial service sector . in the same speech that Churchill coin the ` ` special relationship , ' ' he also introduce the phrase ` ` iron curtain ' ' . much of what animate that speech and our special relationship be our share security interest . while we no longer confront the threat of Soviet aggression , our two country have be force to confront the danger of terrorism . these be challenge time for the British and American people . but strong economic and security tie will cement the special relationship in the same way it do for prior generation , and it will endure .
