it will take age before we be able to work out Brexit ' s impact
how be the UK economy perform since we vote to leave the European union at the end of June ? the answer be that we do n't really know - and wo n't for some time . the figure we have so far present a very incomplete picture . retail sale appear to hold up well in July , while CBI survey indicate resilient manufacturing order and output - possibly help by a weak pound . inflation pick up slightly but it remain very low , at 0.6pc . however , the fall in sterling be start to push up the cost of import . as these high cost feed through to consumer , they could well put a brake on spending growth - as we see when the pound fall sharply after the financial crisis . we be clutch at straw , however , if we make too much of these very early and fragmentary piece of information . we still have no comprehensive official figure cover any period since the referendum for industrial production , GDP , employment , investment , broad measure of consumer spending and overseas trade . it be far too early to draw any substantive conclusion about the economic impact of the Brexit vote . when will we be able to do so ? the analysis we conduct at PwC before the referendum suggest that there be three key area of likely impact - and the timescales to assess them stretch from about six month after the referendum result to a decade or more . the most immediate impact be political and economic uncertainty . this be particularly acute at the beginning of July after the Prime Minister resign and the leadership of the country be adrift . the formation of a new government under Theresa May have stabilise the political situation - though the direction of policy be still unclear on many issue , not least the timing and content of future Brexit negotiation with our EU partner . a degree of uncertainty could also persist during these negotiation - from next year onwards . however , base on the contact with business that I have have over the summer , most company seem prepare to take time to assess the full implication of the Brexit vote . they have absorb the initial shock of the EU referendum vote and be now in ` ` wait and see ' ' mode . day-to-day business carry on as normal , but there may be a more cautious approach to big strategic investment in the UK . I do not find it surprising that retail sale be hold up in the aftermath of the Brexit vote . uncertainty will affect consumer mainly through its effect on job and investment - and it will take a while for these to feed through to individual spending decision . we will need to see at least three to six month of datum before we draw even provisional conclusion about the impact of Brexit uncertainty on job , investment and consumer spending . the second key time horizon be when negotiation about the UK ' s relationship with the rest of the EU be take place between @card@ and @card@ . over this period , we will become clear about how close our trade relationship be with the European Single Market , not just generally but in key sector like manufacturing and financial service . if it be possible for the UK to strike a deal with other EU member which largely preserve our access to European market in manufacturing and key service , this will be a good Brexit outcome - not just for the UK but for the rest of Europe . but it be also possible that the negotiation become confrontational and unproductive . we will not know much about this until Article @card@ be trigger next year . the third time horizon we need to think about be the long term - how strong economic growth will be in the 2020s and 2030s in a UK outside the EU . here , there be two alternative vision of the future for the UK outside the EU . many - like myself - who argue for a Remain vote worry that the longterm economic impact of Brexit be quite likely to be negative . in the past @card@ to @card@ year , the performance of the British economy benefit from membership of the European Economic Community and the EU . the UK turn around from be the ` ` sick man of Europe ' ' in the 1960s and 1970s to become one of its good performer from the 1980s onwards . our close relationship with European market play an important part in this improvement in economic performance , as new investment be attract to the UK - for example in the car industry . the alternative view be that there be now a big world of opportunity in rapidly grow market such as China , India , Africa and South America - and UK economic growth could be boost by forge strong trade link with these country and region . the challenge here will be our ability to gain access to these market on good term . that will not be sort out until we have complete our negotiation with the EU and establish a new relationship with the World Trade Organisation , the guardian of global trade agreement . in summary , therefore , we may learn more about the short-term impact of Brexit over the next six month or so . but the more profound effect will be feel over year and decade . previous experience suggest we should not be surprise if it take a while for even the short-term impact of the Brexit decision to feed through to the UK economy . in the early 1990s , it take one to two year before high interest rate push the economy into recession . even though the first tremor of the global financial crisis be feel in @card@ , the economy do not move decisively into recession until late @card@ . I ' m keep an open mind on the economic impact of Brexit . by the end of this year , we should be clear on the effect of heightened uncertainty on the UK economy . but the other economic impact will take year and possibly decade to unfold . in the meantime , however , consumer and business would be wise to adopt a ` ` wait and see ' ' approach , and not rush to either a negative or excessively positive view . decision which have yet to be take and discussion which have not yet start will have a crucial impact on the full economic consequence of Brexit . Andrew Sentance be senior economic adviser at PwC ' most company seem prepare to take time to assess the full implicaitons of the Brexit vote '

the lady be not for turn as Tory aim to ' plough on ' with Brexit plan
there be no sign of retreat . perhaps that will change but , for now , the Government position on Brexit appear to be ` ` plough on ' ' . there be an inexorable logic to this decision . the staunch Brexiteers in office be afraid of open a can of worm by trigger any kind of leadership contest . they win the argument in Cabinet before the election and their good hope for execute it be to seize the initiative now , before their opponent can get organise . the problem with this strategy should be obvious . Brexit be n't a momentary decision or a single bill . it ' S not like a box that can be close one minute and open the next . it be more like build an enormous cathedral over many year . the architect of one particular plan might be very keen to get start , but if they forge ahead without check everyone be on board , their chance of success be extremely low . in Brexit ' S case , the mason , carpenter and painter reside in Parliament . Brexit can not be implement properly without pass law . and whereas the definitive result of the referendum have push both chamber of parliament into a quiescent state , make them ready to fall into line in spite of their strong pro-Remain tendency , the inconclusive election result have reawaken the spirit of rebellion . many backbench Tory be uneasy with the Prime Minister ' S plan and although Labour ' S manifesto outline a similar approach , that position command little support among MP . in short , the government ' s original plan have become unworkable . many Brexiteers do not yet see it that way , imagine they might be able to ram a deal through Parliament by present it , at the last minute , as the only alternative to no deal at all . but because of the many new area of law Britain plan to take back from Brussels , Brexit require Parliament to pass a series of bill - on immigration , fishery , agriculture and so on - and MP can not therefore be hold to ransom at the eleventh hour . the decision to press ahead obliviously be fraught with risk . negotiator in Brussels will be entitle to question whether May can actually deliver any promise or concession she offer , and will also wonder why they ought to give any ground when it ' S not clear if Parliament would vote through any deal . this heighten the risk of the talk collapse . for business , this be a nightmarish cocktail of political risk . everything suddenly seem to be back on the table , from a ` ` hard ' ' Brexit with no deal to none at all . those hope that Brexit can now somehow be avert be ignore the toxic electoral politics of such a move but , equally , Brexiteers who think nothing change last week be in for a surprise . the simple way out of the current mess would be for Theresa May to seek a transitional arrangement that buy more time for both politics and business to adjust . she would probably have have to do so anyway , because it be unlikely that a comprehensive trade agreement could have be finalise in the next @card@ month . her shaky support at home make a transitional arrangement even more important as a way of create parliamentary consensus and protect the economy from an unnecessarily sudden shock . there be only one obvious , readymade template suitable for a transition : join the European Economic Area . this would not yet allow the government to deliver on its immigration promise , but would set Britain on a smooth path out of the EU while we get our house in order and negotiate the fine detail of whatever our new relationship be . join the EEA would require the permission of its current non-EU member - Norway , Iceland and Liechtenstein - but assume they can be persuade , it be the obvious halfway house . shun the EEA and seek just to join the European Free Trade Association , as some Brexiteers advocate , be n't actually much simple than go for a fully complete Brexit , because in order to maintain full market access it would be necessary to negotiate a lot of bilateral agreement with the EU , as Switzerland have do . EEA membership , by contrast , be relatively straightforward . it allow unfettered market access in return for an agreement to obey whatever regulatory diktat come out of Brussels . Britain would get back control of home affair and could request , separately , to remain part of the custom union until we be ready to sign our own , new trade deal and work out a new tariff schedule . before any Remainers get too excited by the prospect of this watered-down Brexit , however , it should be make clear that EEA membership be not a permanent solution , as a permanent arrangement it be the bad of all world , require obedience to Brussels but allow no input into its rule making . the fact that it deny the government the ability to control immigration will also be unacceptable to voter in the long-run . it make sense , therefore , to set a clear time limit on the transitional arrangement . five year , extendable by mutual agreement , should allow enough time to work out a proper long-term trade agreement between Britain and the EU , while give business and investor time to understand and adjust to the change . most Brexiteers understand that Brexit can not be pull off in the blink of an eye . their fear that it might never happen doe not , however , justify a headlong rush into the unknown when there be good way to approach it . voter have force the government ' S hand and it be no longer possible for May to set her own pace and priority . parliamentary involvement might be annoy and inconvenient , but there be now no way around it . the government will negotiate more effectively if it recognise its new situation at the outset , rather than face a crisis later when it ca n't deliver on its promise . Brexit fade to insignificance set against other economic challenge
Investment , investment and investment . if there be one thing Phillip Hammond , the Chancellor , need to focus on like a laser in next month ' S budget , it be this long standing deficiency in the UK economy . in our obsession with Brexit - what form it might take , whether it will be good or bad for the economy , or indeed the anxiety over whether it will happen at all in any meaningful sense - we ' ve tend to shove all other concern to one side . the business of leave the European Union threaten to become so all consuming that it eclipse everything else . citizen can be divide into two extreme . for avid Brexiteers , there be the almost delusional belief that the mere act of exit the EU automatically transform economic prospect for the well ; the fact that the economy have so far defy warning of Brexit invoke doom be take as evidence that thing can be even more glorious once formally free from the dead hand of the Brussels machine . at the other extreme lie those who cling almost religiously to the view that because of the potential damage to trade with Europe , Brexit be almost bind to be harmful to the economy in the long run . for them , today ' s consumption-led growth be just a case of pain delay , buy largely on the ` ` never never ' ' of spending beyond our mean . they be equally impervious to counter argument . despite the futility of these prediction - it will be a long time before we know one way or the other , and in any case , the ultimate outcome depend crucially on how policy respond to Brexit - they have come to dominate economic debate to the exclusion of virtually all else . Brexit spell either disaster or sunlit upland , take your pick ; fundamentally , the debate have n't change since the heat of the campaign . it have fall to the Institute for Fiscal Studies ' s annual ` ` Green Budget ' ' - which attempt to assess the nation ' S tax and spend choice - to provide its now customary , Eeyore-like reality check . Brexit or no Brexit , there remain a daunting array of economic challenge for the government to address . these non-Brexit issue can be divide into three broad category . first , there be the continued , harrow legacy of the financial crisis . despite real term cut in public spending of @card@ per cent since @card@ - the long and big fall in public spending on record - Britain be still run one of the large budget deficit in the world . what ' s more , this shortfall seem substantially impervious to an increase tax burden , expect shortly to rise above 37pc of national income for the first time since @card@ . as a percentage of national income , the national debt be also at its high level since the mid-1960s , and be again one of the high debt burden in the industrialise world . in any case , by the IFS ' S estimation , it will require a further £34bn of fiscal consolidation on top of that already plan to eradicate the deficit by the unspecific target date of some time during the next parliament . what then be the chance of the government achieve this apparently ever recede goal ? give the record so far , pretty much zero . the second challenge revolve around the cost of an age population . since the financial crisis , the government have be relatively effective in keep the lid on health spending , which in real term be rise at its slow rate since comparable record begin in the mid-1950s . because of cut in other public service , however , it be continue to rise quite sharply as a proportion of total spending . unfortunately , this do n't much mitigate the evident sense of crisis in a health service stretch to break point . the unavoidable implication of the now intense demographic pressure on public spending be that the tax burden will rise further , just the opposite of what be require to ensure a competitive , post-Brexit economy . . the third concern revolve around still very depress level of productivity growth and business investment . many of the pressure on the public finance outline above could be relieve or even get rid of altogether by a return to pre-crisis level of productivity growth , but there be no such miracle in the making , or if there be , it be very well hide . minister be not entirely tin-eared . even as it cut back on day-to-day , current spending , the government be increase the share of the cake that go to capital project . I ' d add a hat tip to Sajid Javid ' S proposal , outline in a White Paper yesterday , to revive Britain ' S shamefully poor level of housebuilding . I doubt they be enough , but almost anything that confront this key structural deficiency in the UK economy deserve some applause . yet the big difference be go to be make in business investment , and on this front there be as yet little reason for optimism . to the contrary , Brexit have add a further level of uncertainty . since the referendum , a number of big , high profile investment project have admittedly be announce , both by overseas company and British one . overall investment never the less remain subdue , both relative to precrisis level and overseas competitor . as a country , we be still invest disgracefully little in our long term future , but continue to spend as if there be no tomorrow . this have to change . the difficulty face by the Chancellor as he square up to these myriad economic challenge be that in order to succeed and attract the business investment need to prosper in post-Brexit form , the UK will need to become one of the most business friendly economy on the planet . this necessarily require sharp cut in business taxation and regulation . at the same time , however , the Chancellor may need to increase most form of personal taxation to meet the challenge of an age population . politically , this be go to be an extraordinarily difficult trick to pull off . Theresa May have thankfully retreat somewhat from the antibusiness , anti-globalisation rhetoric of her early month as Prime Minister . but for a government intend on do something for the ` ` just about managing ' ' , axe business taxation at the same time as massage it up for the humble citizen be not go to look good , not good at all . Britain , as a country , be begin to run out of worker . you can blame David Cameron and Iain Duncan Smith : their welfare-to-work reform be too much of a success . unemployment now stand at the low level in my lifetime , and be fall still . as one minister tell me : ` ` there only be a few hundred people on the dole in my constituency , and I ' ve meet them all . ' ' Britain be approach what economist call full employment : joblessness sinking as low as can be reasonably expect . so if company be panick , this be why . for about a decade , British employer have never have to worry about this because they see migration as the answer to almost any problem . a FTSE @card@ chief executive once confess to me that when he need worker for a new warehouse , he advertise with an agency in Poland and fly them over . other sector have be use similar method : EU national may make up @card@ per cent of worker in food manufacturing , for example , but it be a negligible @card@ per cent before Poland join the EU in @card@ . so the workforce be transform quickly : you can see the same in the change face of warehouse worker , lorry driver , chef and housekeeper . the bottom line be that for a decade and more , a great many industry have expand use immigration . and the result ? it be a stunning success : the influx of industrious , taxpaying , intelligent immigrant that enrich the economy , country and society . but there be side effect : pressure on public service and house , for example . and there be another conundrum : if you can import as many trained worker as you need then why bother to develop your own staff or train new recruit ? ten year ago , a seminal House of Lords report warn that company would grow lazy on immigration , and might not spend as much time or money train their own staff . the update to that report , recently publish , say thing develop just as they fear . nursing be the bad example : the NHS find that they could pay non-European nurse £6,000 less , on average , and fund far few training place than be need . in construction , too , there have n't be anywhere near enough apprenticeship . across too much of the economy , employer have not be invest in people as they should have . and now they ' re panick . company have grow a little too quick to complain about a skill shortage , and be rather slow to do anything about it themselves . now the British workforce have expand to the high number in history and even @card@ immigrant a month be not enough . so it ' s time to think differently . perhaps invest a bit more in machinery , move worker to higherskilled job , increase productivity , spend more on training and increase pay . this be how a healthy economy be suppose to function . a shortage of worker should mean average salary on the rise - something that have n't really happen in Britain for a decade or more . now and again , it ' S argue that we need high-skilled immigration but not low-skilled . now , it ' S become clear that we need both - but neither will ever be enough because there ' s no substitute for a country invest in its own workforce . so this panic be , in a way , a useful panic . employer realise now , more than ever , that people be the great resource of all . all tell , it be not a bad problem to have . follow Fraser Nelson on Twitter @ FraserNelson ; Read More at www.telegraph.co.uk/ opinion

what if ... ? the fate of Brexit in a coalition no @card@ ; Analysis
suppose - just suppose - that Theresa May fail to win a majority in the election on June @card@ , would that mean Brexit be off ? if ` ` off ` ` mean really , definitely off , then the answer be simple : no . Brexit be start by a referendum . only another referendum could stop it . maybe if a party win a majority have say , in term , that it would stop the Brexit process if elect , it could claim a mandate for do so . but no party be go to put that pitch to the electorate : even the liberal Democrats say only that they want a second referendum . in any case , a party could claim a mandate to overturn the referendum result only if it win a majority not just of seat in the Commons , but of vote in the country - something that no party have manage since before the Second World War . without an electoral mandate to halt Brexit , even if some kind of Labour/SNP/Lib Dem government deal be to emerge after the election , the process would continue , and the government would continue to negotiate the term of the UK ' s departure from the EU . we can deduce from past announcement that such a government would pursue a very different kind of Brexit from Theresa May ' S version : it would , for example , probably seek continue membership of the single market . the talk would , nevertheless , go on . but what would happen once the talk have conclude ? if it do n't get a deal that it like , could such a government decide not to pursue Brexit after all ? that depend on three thing : the law ; European politics ; and domestic politics . in term of law , the question be whether it be possible , now that Article @card@ have be trigger , to revoke that trigger . on this , there be no absolute certainty . article @card@ provide no process for reversal . but many lead lawyer think there be an implied right for country to change their mind . at the very least , everyone agree that the trigger of Article @card@ could by some mean be revoke if all the other @card@ member state agree to it . many also think it could be revoke unilaterally - but only the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg can decide on this . that matter because it determine the importance of the second factor - EU politics . if the UK can unilaterally revoke the trigger of Article @card@ , then the process be simple : the UK ' s permanent representative in Brussels just deliver a letter to Donald Tusk , nullify the letter he hand to him at the end of March . if , on the other hand , agreement of the other member state be need , then some of them be likely to seek concession before consent . that could make thing messy and end up give the UK bad term of EU membership than it have have to date . then come UK domestic politics.As I have say , last year ' S referendum can be reverse only by another referendum : it would be politically untenable for any government to do www.otherwise.No government be likely to call another referendum unless it feel pretty confident of win it - unless , that be , it see clear evidence that significant part of the electorate be get cold foot on Brexit . that might happen : the negotiation might go badly , and voter might be persuade that the decision to leave the EU be an error . but there be no sign of any such change of heart yet . the negotiation might go well than many expect , or voter might pin the blame for problem on the EU and become firm in their desire to leave . so the outcome of the election be more likely to determine the form of Brexit than it be to influence whether it happen at all . a reversal be possible , but an improbable victory for Mrs May ' S opponent be only the first of many step need to get there . the IMF be miss the point on Brexit ; Comment
there be two way of look at the IMF ' s pronouncement on the economy , Brexit and all other matter . the first be to dismiss everything it say as irrelevant : after all , it have regularly change its mind in recent decade over central issue of economic policy and utterly fail to predict or understand the bubble of the 2000s and the subsequent crash and financial collapse . it also prove unable to properly predict the eurozone crisis , or to be sufficiently objective about the launch of the single currency . it get it wrong on austerity , or at least on the impact of the version practise by George Osborne , force a rare apology . time and again , its prediction or prescription turn out to be want . I would n't go as far as to claim that it be a contrary indicator - it be right on some major question , such as the desirability of globalisation and free trade - but its record be poor when it matter . like almost all international organisation and institution , it buy into the current ( and everchange ) ' the status quo itself be unstable : the EU will receive economic change over the next few year ' wisdom . international bureaucracy support other international bureaucracy ; and the IMF , all too predictably , back the EU . Christine Lagarde argue that the referendum on Brexit could create uncertainty , whereas she believe that certainty would be preferable ( sadly , bureaucrat never like the fact that democracy actually imply a choice from empower voter ) . despite all of that , I prefer the second option , which be to take all argument seriously , even if their source be suspect and have a terrible history of get it wrong . the IMF be engage in what could be a six-month project to write a report on how Brexit would impact the economy , the conclusion of which be likely to be predictable ; but when it be publish , it will deserve to be take seriously even by those of us who already suspect that they wo n't be convince . the real debate to be have within the business community be slightly different , however . I have speak to several anti-Brexit CEO in recent week , who have make the same point : they believe that the EU be procapitalist and those who oppose it be not . I have also speak to pro-Brexit business people and economist who have argue the exact opposite : it be the EU that be anti-capitalist , its centralise , harmonise and regulatory instinct inherently at odd with real free market . it be a fascinating divide : two group of intelligent people be look at the same organisation , and come to radically different conclusion . one group be right , and the other wrong . in a variation on the same theme , one prominent chief executive tell me that his own decision as to whether or not he would back Brexit would boil down to whether he think that an independent UK would be more protectionist and inward-looking - or whether Brexit would make us more global in outlook and more likely to embrace pro-growth reform . the truth be that we can not know for sure . it be possible that we would become a lot more protectionist if we be to leave the EU , or at least loosen our tie with it ; in particular , there be a good chance that the labour market will become less liberal ( though more barrier to EU migrant might be cancel out by few barrier for certain non-EU one ) . but it be equally possible that the rise of Marine Le Pen in France and other factor will make the EU far more interventionist and illiberal than it be today , impact us , too . the status quo itself be unstable : the EU will change over the next few year and us with it . my own guess be that the sort of constitutional and cultural shock that a Brexit /proper renegotiation would guarantee would jolt Britain out of its current complacency . paradoxically , trade and life would continue unchanged for the first few year at least ; but it would nevertheless be a seismic event for Westminster elite . attitude would change very quickly . they would become far more aware of the need to attract capital and talent ; the pressure to allow the construction of new airport capacity would be great ; we would finally sort out our domestic political institution ; we would have to fight harder and be good in every way , focus on education , investment and competitiveness . the artificial European cocoon would be go , if only psychologically ( in practice , the UK and the EU would probably remain just as economically integrated as they be today ) . far from retreat into protectionism and nimbyism , I suspect that we would become even more open . it ' S just a guess , of course - but contrary to what the IMF seem to believe , certainty be n't possible in the real world . allister.heath @ telegraph.co.uk ' The status quo itself be unstable : the EU will change over the next few year '

we should all be optimistic about Brexit - here ' S why
the Treasury want to keep the lid on public spending and limit tax giveaway until UK public finance be sound . this be a good aim , since the government ' S debt be about 80pc of our national income when you strip out the effect of the Bank of England ' s operation in the money market and the debt of RBS . but in March @card@ we formally leave the EU ; and probably by mid @card@ we be out of the transition period . we must have the right policy to make sure the economy thrive . for that the Treasury need to have a positive mindset . unfortunately , it seem quite determine to take the gloomy view possible . the Treasury have not retract the assessment of Brexit it make before the referendum : long-term , that GDP would be reduce by any Brexit , most of all ( 7pc ) by a clean Brexit with no EU trade deal , and short-term , that there would be a sharp and immediate recession . the short-term one have already be contradict by event : the UK be still grow well . the long-term assessment have come under widespread attack ; its protectionist assumption be contrary to the government ' s trade policy , and its empirical work be largely base on non-UK experience . neither the Treasury nor the Chancellor have reply to these crucial criticism . against this depressing background the economist for Free Trade group have feel it necessary to do its own assessment of the budget outlook up to and after Brexit . there be four main reason why we take a much more upbeat view of the future for the economy and the public finance . first , there be the current economic fact : the economy be do well . growth accord to the ONS be run at just below 2pc per annum.We think that when all the data be in the final revised GDP growth rate will be see to have be run at 2pc-plus since the referendum . that would fit with the datum from the purchasing manager indices , CBI survey and robustly grow employment . it also fit with the steady improvement in the public finance . you would hardly think from all the report hand-wringing that public borrowing be run below the OBR ' s forecast for this financial year . the money come in from revenue be grow more strongly , at 4pc , than the money go out in spending ( at 3pc ) . it look as if borrow this year will be around 2pc of GDP . second , that steady trend in revenue growth look set to continue up to Brexit as growth in money GDP stay around the 4pc mark , so that by @card@ , borrowing will have get close to zero . when borrowing be this low , debt fall as a percentage of grow GDP . by @card@ , regardless of Brexit , debt would have reach 75pc of GDP , well on its way towards the safe target level of 60pc , where the risk of a sharp interest rate rise cause a crisis become manageable . third , the official gloom about UK productivity growth stall be mislead . there be a huge measurement problem for the quality , and so the productivity , of service . it be easy to measure the number of plate roll off a production line ; but how to measure the service you get from your mobile phone or your computerise booking agency ? for example , accord to ONS figure , productivity in education , healthcare and social service have be fall since @card@ at 4pc a year ; this be an absurdity . unfortunately until we can get some grip on the measurement issue the only reliable figure for the economy ' S growth be money GDP - the money value of what we spend and produce . fourth and finally , there be Brexit and the massive boost that its economic revolution will provide by bring free trade and world competition , home-grown pragmatic regulation and an end to subsidise , unskilled EU immigration . in the long term this raise our GDP by 7pc , bring down consumer price by 8pc and boost the live standard of the low income group by 15pc . from @card@ , it take gradual effect because of the usual time lag ; by @card@ about 2pc of the full 7pc will have come through , with the rest due by @card@ . the total effect on government revenue will be a rise of about 10pc , worth £80bn in today ' S economy but of course much more by @card@ . when you feed Brexit into the public finance , two thing happen . first , the future path of debt be much lower relative to GDP , as the finance improve sharply with no change in assumed public spending ; this permit the UK to get the debt/GDP ratio to 60pc faster and indeed below 50pc by @card@ . second , there be a policy need to support the change Brexit economy , to make the most of our new opportunity . face with chance to grow faster and penetrate new market all around the world , UK competitiveness should be reinforce : tax rate should fall , infrastructure be improve , and public service make fit for a strong economy . if you put these thing together , Brexit create a dividend or fiscal fund that can satisfy this policy need while still bring the public finance to a safe debt/GDP ratio in the 2020s . we show that we can afford to spend another £25bn a year from @card@ , top up by a further £40bn a year in @card@ . this will be enough to spend another £33bn a year on public service and infrastructure by @card@ , a lift of about 4pc in public spending ; and also to cut corporation tax to 14pc , the top rate to 36pc with no additional rate above it , and the standard income tax rate to 18pc . this be truly a future to be optimistic about . Professor Patrick Minford be the chairman of the economist for Free Trade group ' sadly , the Treasury seem quite determine to take the gloomy view on Brexit possible '

more than Brexit at work in large market movement
there have recently be large movement in the price of three major financial asset - share , bond and the currency - that , it be alleged , derive directly from the Brexit vote . but have these change really be cause by the referendum result ? it do n't take long for market operator to work out that the price of many of the share quote on the London Stock Exchange should rise , not directly because of the Brexit vote , but rather because of the associate fall in the pound . many of our large company have substantial overseas interest , range from investment and significant business operation abroad to simply sell a large part of their output overseas . if the dollar ( or euro ) value of these activity or investment be unchanged , then the sterling value must rise by the extent of the pound ' S depreciation . these company will have enjoy a substantial boost to their income and net asset value in sterling as a result of the exchange rate fall . accordingly , their share price should be high . so it be no surprise that the FTSE @card@ have recently be trade at about 11pc up from its level just before the referendum . interestingly , since the pound have fall by more than this , in dollar term , the FTSE @card@ be down by 8pc.Meanwhile , the share of company not involve in international trade or investment be generally lower even in sterling term . much more significant than share price movement have be the change in the government bond market . during the referendum campaign , some prominent Remainers argue that if we vote to leave the EU the UK would face a funding crisis . after all , they argue , the government be run a large budget deficit of about 4pc of GDP and , alongside it , we have a very large current account deficit of more than 5pc of GDP which require capital inflow of that amount to finance it . the Governor of the Bank of England , Mark Carney , say we be rely on ` ` the kindness of stranger ' ' . actually , it be n't kindness that persuade foreign capital holder to pour money into the UK , but rather their perception of significant prospective return . more importantly , whether you call it kindness or self-interest , their money do not help but rather hinder our economic progress . it serve to keep the pound at a very high level which thereby exacerbate the very current account deficit that the capital inflow be finance . nevertheless , you can see that the worrier have a point - and not only with regard to the currency . in principle , it be possible that if we vote for Brexit the market would take fright about the UK ' s fiscal prospect and accordingly drive the yield on British government debt appreciably high . on a casual inspection , they seem to have be vindicate . the yield on 10-year gilt have recently just about double from 0.5pc to 1pc . yet this be no cause for alarm . this rise come after an earlier sharp drop . far from there be panic about hold British government bond , the initial reaction after the Brexit vote be to pile into them . accordingly , the recent rise in bond yield have still not take them back to where they be before the Brexit vote . indeed , exclude the recent ultra-low level , they remain the low British yield on record . what ' s more , if you look at the credit default swap market - which give a measure of the market ' s anxiety about default risk - you see a small spike immediately after the Brexit vote follow by a return to previous level . so the market do n't seem to be alarm about the UK ' s fiscal health . so what do explain the recent pick-up in gilt yield ? I think this can be explain by a change in economic and financial circumstance which be only partly and indirectly due to Brexit . the fall of the pound have already increase inflation and it be likely to go on rise for the next couple of year . in the financial market , expectation of future inflation have pick up . other thing equal , this should push bond yield high as investor seek protection from the erosion in real value that inflation cause . yet the recent rise in gilt yield be not a uniquely British phenomenon . government bond yield have pick up from their ultra-low level in the eurozone , the US and just about everywhere else . surely that can not be due to Brexit . what explain this , I think , be a change in the medium-term outlook for short-term interest rate and in the prospect for quantitative easing ( QE ) . if short-term rate be ultra-low and be expect to be ultra-low for as long as the eye can see , then long yield will be low - even if inflation prospect suggest a loss of real value . equally , more QE , involve central bank buying of bond , will tend to depress yield . but the intellectual climate , not just here but globally , be shift against monetary stimulus - both low interest rate and QE . this be partly because the deflation danger no longer seem so threatening and indeed high inflation be in prospect , and partly because further monetary stimulus seem unlikely to do much good . turn to the pound , its huge fall this year be widely attribute to the Brexit vote . in one sense , this be right . Brexit be certainly the trigger . but I feel sure that it be not the underlie cause . the UK have be run a current account deficit of more than 5pc of GDP , which have result in a loss of net national wealth of that same magnitude per annum . this could not continue . so the underlie cause of sterling ' S fall be Britain ' s woeful balance of payment position and the fundamental need for a low exchange rate . the extraordinary thing that need to be explain be not why the pound have recently drop so sharply but rather why it be so strong for so long . Roger Bootle be chairman of Capital Economics roger.bootle @ capitaleconomics.com ' the thing that need to be explain be why the pound be so high for so long '

business and minister must unite to make a success of EU deal
with every pass day , it become ever clearer that make a success of Brexit will require a deep , sustained partnership between government and business . over the come month , we must work tirelessly together at both a strategic and a technical level - to achieve both the good possible overall deal , and to deliver the answer to the practical , real-world question that firm pose each and every day . many of the business community I repreRsent see the Westminster and medium debate on Brexit as something occur on a far-off planet , far remove from their day-to-day concern . in truth , only a minority of firm be actively think about Brexit at all - with a majority far more concerned about the impact of government policy and decision close to home . yet for those that see Brexit as a clear and present danger , the basic must come first . ` ` will our good get stick at border crossing or delay at the quayside ? who can we hire , and from where , and for how long ? who do we pay VAT to ? whose regulation do we need to comply with ? will change hit me all at once , or over time ? ' ' and so on . these vital and basic question must be answer , along with the technical and legal issue affect specific sector . from aviation to agriculture , there be complex and detailed discussion on regulation , standard , and institution that be vital to the UK ' s future economic interest . our business community want clear answer . they want the UK ' S negotiator to have the maximum flexibility possible to go out and secure those answer . and they tell us repeatedly that they have no appetite for a parting of way with the European union that do not include a deal . to be sure , individual business impact by Brexit have a range of opinion on what our final deal with the EU should look like . yet they be all clear that they only want to have to make one big adjustment to the condition of that deal . ask firm to incur the cost of one adjustment in @card@ , only to be follow by another a few year later , risk make UK business uncompetitive in an increasingly cut-throat global marketplace . for that reason , the British chamber of Commerce and other business organisation have call on the government to seek to maintain the economic benefit of the single market and the Customs Union , until a comprehensive final settlement between the UK and EU be agree and implement . this would also mean that business only face one set of adjustment cost . this sort of pragmatism , focus on real-world economic risk and opportunity , must be at the heart of the UK negotiator ' thinking . business I speak with on both side of the Channel would like to see flexibility not just from the government , but from the EU27 as well - so that the trade element of the talk can begin as soon as possible . the sooner Brussels agree to discuss the outline of the UK ' s future relationship with the European Union , and the length and scope of any transition period , the strong business confidence , investment and hiring be likely to be - both here in the UK and among our trading partner . attention be require away from the negotiation , too . unless our firm have the well possible environment for business here at home , even a great Brexit deal will have little impact . business community want to be reassure that government will also be focus on other issue that impact their competitiveness and their bottom line . that mean bring forward infrastructure project that have already be approve , give work to supplier and confidence to wide business community . it mean do more about the intermittent mobile and broadband connectivity that handicap firm ' ability to do business . and it mean a continued focus on training and export . yet a great business environment be about more than infrastructure alone . it ' S also about the tone of our political debate . in recent week , our business community have become increasingly concerned that politician and a segment of the public believe that significant tax rise on both business and individual be acceptable and even desirable . call for additional tax on business to pay for politically-expedient spending must be resist , particularly in the context of a Brexit transition . a high-cost , high-tax Britain with patchy infrastructure and serious skill gap would be no recipe for post-Brexit success . firm be already buckle under the weight of the cost they bear before they turn over a single pound . many have be hit by the impact of low sterling , business rate , the Apprenticeship Levy , the Immigrant skill Charge and pension autoenrolment - to name just a few . any politician who seek to raise the cost of do business in the UK at such a critical moment will have to explain to the electorate why few job be be create , why investment originally slate for the UK go elsewhere , and why the tax receipt flow into the Exchequer be low than originally anticipate . maintain a strong environment for business in the UK be just as important as achieve a businessfriendly outcome to Brexit negotiation . all who care about business , whatever their perspective on how we leave the EU , must make this point loudly and clearly . PIXEL8000
like wag a dog ' s tail to make it happy , EU exit warning be flaw
the Treasury recently bring out its report on the long-term effect of Brexit , say they will be dire . this week it follow that up with equally severe warning about the short-term impact . both be flaw . George Osborne be force to admit to Jacob Rees-Mogg in a Treasury select committee hearing that he have make unfavourable assumption about Brexit in the crucial ` ` World Trade Organisation option ' ' . the Treasury assume that if we leave the EU we would erect the same trade barrier on the whole world , include the European Union . these barrier be around 20pc on both agriculture and manufacturing , so that be a huge negative assumption . it would be a retreat from free trade ; it be certainly not the good ` ` WTO option ' ' . as economist for Brexit have repeatedly explain , the good option would be for the UK to abolish all the EU trade barrier and trade freely with the world , include the EU , at world price . Mr Osborne ' s excuse for the Treasury ' S assumption be that he think leave proponent favour some protection , such as on steel . but this be no excuse . first , it be perfectly consistent with general free trade to have some protection of particular industry : look at the free-trading US where a 267pc anti-dumping duty have just be levy on Chinese steel . second , whatever the view of leave proponent , it be the Treasury ' s duty to work out the well available option in the national interest . the Treasury have deliberately cook the book in its ` ` assessment ' ' of the Brexit outlook - both long term and short . the IMF and the Bank of England have now sign up to the International Friends of Messrs Cameron and Osborne Club . how could anyone resist such an establishment consensus ? but have they understand the deceit at the heart of the Treasury calculation ? Brexit , like the repeal of Corn Laws nearly two century ago , will lower the price of import by abolish the EU tariff enforce by the EU Customs Union . these EU tariff have a huge effect on our cost of living , through high food and manufacturing price . what about the threat that country who have a trade agreement with the EU will not replicate them for a post-Brexit UK ? there be no reason to think these agreement would not continue . but , if one country put up a barrier , it would have a tiny effect on world demand . the price of our product , sell to buyer from all over the world , would not change ; we would simply trade with other country . in order to create their case against Brexit , the Treasury have use a ` ` gravity model ' ' approach . the basic idea be simple : the amount of trade that people do with other country depend on basic measure of ` ` mass ' ' ( GDP , population ) and the cost of ` ` transport ' ' , mean all the cost associate with distance , whether geographical , political or tariff and other explicit barrier . to measure trade barrier , the Treasury use the suppose effect of membership in the EU , EEA and other trade agreement ; it get these effect measuring what happen to trade from the date they occur . the problem with these gravity equation be that they be mere association from past datum , which result from the policy and shock of the past . they be not causal relationship and so you can not assume they will be repeat in the future when the policy and shock will be different . in other word , they ca n't be use to predict the effect of a Brexit , which be take place in quite different circumstance . the Treasury then repeat the same gravity model for foreign direct investment ( FDI ) , again use datum from many country and time period . the same critique apply to this . matter do not end there . to link the economy to trade and FDI as predict by these gravity model , equation be estimate for the average relationship of productivity with trade and FDI . the problem be that these relationship too will vary accord to the shock the economy face and will not predict the effect of Brexit . this matter because the gain to welfare of UK citizen come from the effect on household live standard and on the industrial structure of output . more productive industry attract more FDI . trade change mirror sectoral change in production and consumption . hence measure these shift in the economy be vital to a proper assessment . an analogy might help . we can see that when a dog be happy ( perhaps because it have be chase squirrel ) it wag its tail vigorously . there be an association here between happiness and tail-wagging . one conclusion might be that , to make the dog happy , you should wag its tail for it . that be the wrong conclusion . so it be with trade and FDI . we observe that reform economy generate a lot of trade , FDI , and productivity ; some country join the EU to buttress their reform . be the conclusion that we can make these country more productive by force up trade and FDI ? or , be it that , with those reform establish , their achievement would be destroy if they leave the EU ? clearly not . it be in cost the WTO option , as I explain at the start , that the Treasury come most spectacularly to grief , bizarrely calculate that GDP will fall by nearly 8pc . in our standard model of trade , with proper free trade assumption , Brexit get rid of EU protection and reduce consumer price by 8pc . this , in turn , impact on wage and competitiveness throughout the economy . the structure of production shift towards non-protected sector , increase productivity overall , and consumer no longer transfer resource to foreign EU producer . GDP rise by 4pc . this WTO option allow the UK to abandon all EU regulation within the Single Market and politically give us full freedom from the EU in every respect - for example we need not negotiate a new trade agreement with the EU . this option be not dependent on good will from the EU , which may be in short supply on June @card@ . it can be implement by simply repeal the @card@ European Communities Act . the establishment be wrong over Brexit , as it be repeatedly wrong on major UK policy issue in the past @card@ year . Brexit will be a major liberal supply-side reform of the British economy . we should embrace it . Patrick Minford be co-chairman of economist for Brexit ' the problem with these gravity equation be they be mere association from past datum , which result from the policy of the past '

Ireland , like other nation with strong national identity and a naturally sceptical outlook on the EU political project , be anxious about be railroad into a union that go beyond the pure economic advantage it seek . we ' ve sign a blank cheque for nuclear power ; Brexit offer the perfect chance to cancel Hinkley Point , but Britain have give in to France and China
every cloud have its silver lining , and for Remainers such as me , one potential upside of Brexit be that it might finally bury that Franco-Chinese folie de grandeur-bysea , Hinkley Point C. regardless - regardless , that be , of the solvency risk it pose to EDF , already struggle with the finance for nuclear renewal in France , regardless of the late EDF resignation , regardless of the ever-escalating cost - estimate at £18 billion and rise the last time I look - regardless of the untested technology be adopt , regardless of the fact that it commit Britain to a Chinese solution to other nuclear reactor elsewhere in Britain , together with the accompanying security risk , and most important of all , regardless of spiral subsidy cost , include a strike price , inflation-proofed for @card@ year , for output which be more than double the current go rate for wholesale electricity . even Brexit could n't stop it . indeed , the referendum vote might actually have give it a boost overseas appetite for UK investment in the round . but then the largesse of the dowry be such that even in the face of a 10-year depression , EDF would have struggle to refuse . the bottom line be that far too big a price be be pay for an untried technology which will very likely be obsolete before the plant be even complete . to get Hinkley build , minister have have to agree an @card@ . with Hinkley Point schedule to provide Britain with @card@ per cent of its electricity need , any such delay would leave consumer disastrously expose to Britain ' s loom energy shortfall , as exist nuclear and coalfired plant come to the end of their natural life . in any case , a project of questionable value to the UK economy from the start have be leave look like a total white elephant by the collapse in the price of fossil fuel . the National Audit Office recently estimate that over the lifetime of the project , the extra cost to consumer of Hinkley ' S output have rise from a punish £6.1 billion when the strike price be agree three year ago , to a jaw-dropping £29.7 billion today . together with other policy design to deliver a lowcarbon future , Hinkley ' S cost will add approximately £230 a year to the average household electricity bill , accord to government estimate . climate change risk may well justify these environmental goal , but whether Hinkley be the right way to deliver them always seem questionable and today look positively reckless . to understand how we get ourselves into this mess require a little history . as with so many other pioneer technology under the Thatcher government , but be derail by the ` ` dash for gas ' ' and the fallout from Chernobyl . climate change objective give nuclear new leg , but private-sector solution have prove elusive . it be no accident that Hinkley ' S two backer , France ' s EDF and China ' S General Nuclear Power Corporation , be creature of the state , for the upfront cost of grand projet like Hinkley be so large and high risk that the private sector struggle to finance them . France and China will be charge us through the nose for the privilege . frankly , we would have be good off do it ourselves . there be much good solution to Britain ' s loom energy shortfall - gas as a stop-gap , small , more affordable nuclear power station from Japan , and further out , the development of ` ` small modular nuclear reactor ' ' , a promising technology where Britain could again excel . in the age of Trump , we need the buccaneering Hammond of old ; America be about to embark on the great supply-side tax cut since Reagan . Britain ca n't stand still
it will be hard for some to believe but Philip Hammond be once a colourful , buccaneering entrepreneur , the opposite of the grey-suited bean-counter he now purport to be . as a schoolboy in Essex , the man who today serve as our Chancellor of the Exchequer make good money rent out church hall for disco , before graduate to trading car make at the local Ford factory . he have a knack for spot a profit opportunity and strike his first real deal age just @card@ , when he buy out his employer ' medical product division for just £1 . over the year , Hammond have his fair share of failure as well as success , like all entrepreneur , but end up make million from a range of property and construction , manufacturing and energy business . people do n't really change , which be why I ' m hopeful that Hammond may rediscover his risk-taking instinct and ditch the ultra-cautious , lugubrious and bizarrely pessimistic persona he have acquire since enter politics . the world have shift dramatically in the past five month , and Britain desperately need a dose of the old , glass half-full Hammond . government must deal with reality as it be , not as they hope it would be , and this apply even more to Trump ' S triumph - which Downing Street neither predict nor want - than it do to Brexit . nobody know , at this stage , whether Trump ' S presidency will implode in an orgy of demagoguery , protectionism and corruption , or whether it will confound its critic by govern in a neo-Reaganite manner . Realpolitik must thus be the order of the day . give the inflammatory element of Trump ' S campaign , the British Government need to remain vigilant ; but it should also seek to make the most of the new world order and the imminent pro- Brexit and pro-growth shift in Washington . this be where Hammond come in . Brexit alone would have require a radical response from the Chancellor ; Brexit , Trump and the grow likelihood that strain in the eurozone will eventually reach break point make this an urgent necessity . Hammond ' S first Autumn Statement next week be the first real opportunity for the May Government to regain the initiative and to show that it have an exciting , optimistic plan for our post-Brexit prosperity . Hammond can not afford to be hem in by the pessimistic consensus - the same duff prediction that claim the Brexit vote would trigger an immediate collapse in growth and job . he need to break free from the constraint of the Treasury ' S model . the Chancellor should start off by point out - diplomatically , of course - that the rise in the deficit be largely the do of his predecessor : the previous prediction never have any hope of come true , Brexit or no Brexit . he must then retain an iron grip on almost all area of current spending , while announce his own deliberate but carefully control loosening in fiscal policy . the first big change be that the Chancellor need to be much more radical on tax , and unveil at least one flagship measure to improve incentive to work and invest . he should commission a major review of the tax system , with the aim of drastically simplify and flatten it . Trump change everything here : America be about to embark on the great supply-side tax cut on business and worker since Ronald Reagan . the Republicans want to slash the top rate to @card@ per cent , increase the personal allowance and abolish the estate tax , among other thing . capital gain tax rate would be no more than @card@ per cent . corporation tax would be slash to between @card@ per cent ( under Trump ' S plan ) and @card@ per cent ( the House ' S alternative ) . a special @card@ per cent tax rate could be introduce for US multinational repatriate the money they hold overseas , suck trillion of dollar back into the US economy . Britain can not afford to stand still . combine with the possibility of a major pro-growth shift in the way Wall Street be regulate , and the big London-based investment bank ' fear that they will be freeze out of European market after Brexit , now be also the time for Hammond to ditch the banking levy supertax . second , trade . the UK need to take every opportunity to defend the World Trade Organisation against the new administration ' s troubling protectionist instinct , which be likely to be focus on emerge market . but in other respect the dream of many Brexiteers have suddenly come true : there be now a real chance of a bilateral trade deal with the US , as soon as we leave the custom union . Hammond should ignore the clueless naysayer who claim that we should reject or delay this historic opportunity to ensure we do n't alienate the EU ; talk with Washington should begin in parallel with those with Europe . a US-UK free trade deal would transform our negotiate position with the EU and would be game-changing in every possible way . Hammond should at the very least hint that he be excite by this next week . next , defence . Trump ' s lukewarm approach to Nato mean that Britain ' s strong military will become a major bargaining chip in our Brexit talk , especially when it come to convince eastern Europe country . defence spending as a share of GDP fall to @card@ per cent in @card@ ; Hammond should pledge to increase it to @card@ per cent by the end of the decade . the Chancellor must also move fast on energy , infrastructure and housing . he need to intensify and accelerate the development of shale , and speed up road-building project . as for housing , apart from release more land , tear down barrier to entry for new housebuilders and apply some of the lesson he learn in his construction business , Hammond should slash stamp duty across the board . the fiscal impact would be limit - it be one of those tax cut that could pay for itself , directly as well as indirectly . the number of housing transaction would rocket , more people would be able to upgrade or downsize their home and lot of other spending and tax revenue would be generate . in his original , swashbuckling incarnation , Hammond love to roll the dice , to take a calculated risk . electorate here and in America be certainly in that sort of mood . the Chancellor need to show them what he be really make of , and deliver an Autumn Statement fit for the time . follow Allister Heath on Twitter @ AllisterHeath ; Read More at www.telegraph.co.uk/ opinion

the reformation offer a good lesson for Brexit ; Our history tell us that adopt a loose link with Europe can produce fresh way of think
one month on from the Brexit vote , and we ' re do fine . the fundamental be unchanged : a strong economy , a cohesive society and , lest we forget , we have n't actually leave the EU yet . despite this , some people still talk as though Britain detach itself from the continent and sink into the ocean . they need to relax - open a beer and enjoy the sunshine . history suggest that rupture in geopolitics can be the start of something beautiful . take the 16th-century reformation . as a Catholic , I be duty-bound to say that Henry VIII ' S divorce and the subsequent establishment of the Anglican Church be a disaster . the enormity of its change - the abolition of the monastery , sectarian conflict - dwarf Brexit , imply that leave the EU just be n't the big deal that Remainers insist . but the reformation do have two characteristic that hold out hope for a bright future in @card@ : continuity and the unleash of the English imagination . England do n't cease to be European after the reformation , much as it wo n't cease to be European after Brexit . follow our break with Rome , we seek allegiance with Protestant power and play host to Protestant refugee , such as the Huguenot - among them , a distant relative of Nigel Farage . Catholicism do not evaporate . element of Catholic theology remain embed in the Anglican tradition , while popery creep back into the Royal family . just as the Protestants struggle to rid England of Catholic influence , so the Catholic recusant accept aspect of the reformation as vital . even when Mary I , the most vicious persecutor of Protestants , launch her counterreformation , she find the only politically feasible way to do it be through Parliament . England immediately follow the reformation be thus still deeply Catholic , but a new political idea be take hold - that England should be sovereign in all affair . certain Reformation-era myth about Englishness remain powerful today . one be geographic . the physical separation from Europe define our identity , conclude many Protestant , while the proximity of Scotland , Wales and Ireland translate into some English right to dominate them - our equivalent of the America ' Manifest Destiny . another fantasy be that the persecution under Mary and the suppose tolerance of Elizabeth ' s Anglican settlement confirm that England tilt towards liberty , while Catholic Europe prefer violent tyranny - a view later confirm in some mind by Napoleon and Hitler . perhaps most importantly , the Reformation cause us to investigate ourselves . the emergence of English as an evangelical language spawn the most wonderful literature : the book of Common Prayer , Paradise Lost , the Pilgrim ' S progress and the visionary poetry of William Blake . this be not to say that Brexit be go to spark an English renaissance : the hymn of Charles Wesley can hardly be compare to Mike Read ' S Ukip Calypso . but rupture prompt nation to rethink who they be and how they govern themselves . and there ' s no doubt that the reformation empower Parliament . at the height of the British Empire , the Victorian conclude rather arrogantly that they have a duty to spread the march towards democracy and capitalism around the globe . as regard Europe , they want to live peacefully with their neighbour but , ultimately , in ` ` splendid isolation ' ' . the break from Rome be weave into a narrative of Great Britain as a naval power , sail westward from the continent into the sunset . Brexit contain the seed of a similar revolution in the English imagination . the Leftist Euroscepticism of Tony Benn see Brexit as a chance to build a socialist commonwealth . the Rightist tradition of Enoch Powell dream of a Britain that be small and free - although no one now see Powell ' s grim monoculturalism as a necessary part of that package . both of these be root in reformation utopianism ; both overlook the practical upside to Brexit . one be that Parliament will once again be sovereign , but the people increasingly want democracy to be more local . to save the Union , we may have to devolve it completely . federalism be on its way . but the most obvious benefit to Brexit be that it compel us to look beyond Europe for our market . I do n't like use history to make prediction , but decoupling from economic alliance have often prove beneficial . when we abandon the Gold Standard in @card@ , everyone predict disaster - but it actually help us get out of the great depression . when we slip out of the Exchange Rate Mechanism in @card@ , it feel like the sky have fall in , but @card@ year of astonishing growth follow . crucially , the future be only as bleak as we allow it to become . Brexit be a vote to reaffirm British self-governance . we may choose to shrink the state and become a big , rich Hong Kong . we may choose to nationalise and build the socialist Jerusalem . what we must not choose be what so many Remainers seem to be willing on : we must not choose to fail . follow Tim Stanley on Twitter @ timothy_stanley ; Read More at www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion

the Lords must learn the lesson of history or face a new revolution ; Obstructing Brexit would risk another political upheaval that could sweep the upper house away
the House of Lords be debate the legislation that trigger Brexit . it should return it to the Commons untouched and wrap up in a ribbon . as Theresa May remind them by attend the deliberation on the step of the royal throne , a fight against this Bill be a fight against democracy . a few Europhiles imagine that they can stuff the legislation with compromise and roadblock and pray for future reversal . this would be stupid . the Brexit revolution be grow and gather momentum . any institution that stand in its way risk be flatten . this be the way of revolution . they start out as a debate about one thing and wind up in a war about everything . consider the French revolution . in @card@ , the issue be whether or not Louis XVI could govern without consult all class of society . compromise be possible ; a constitutional monarchy be on the table . yet by the mid-1790s , the revolutionary have cut off Louis ' head , abolish nobility and be busy replace God with a Supreme www.Being.No one predict this ; it be n't plan . accident happen . one of those accident be Louis - and while it sound like victim-blaming to say he bring this on his own head , he really do . Louis could have make a constitutional monarchy work , but he do n't want one . on June @card@ @card@ , he and his family attempt to flee Paris in order to join rebel force and , it be allege , return as a despot . like Charles I or Tsar Nichola , Louis ' stubbornness condemn him . the narrative of every revolution be thus determine as much by its opposition as by its supporter . fast-forward to June @card@ @card@ . the issue on the ballot be membership of the European Union . most of us who vote leave see it as a simple , unemotional proposition : we judge that we ' d be wealthy and free outside the EU . of course there be radical and extremist on the Eurosceptic side - I shall come to them in a minute - but for most of us this be a rational choice . indeed , much of the heat in this debate since the vote have come not from a leave campaign that never even expect to win but from the Remain campaign , who be shock and appall by defeat . they be the one who have try to redefine what Brexit be all about . it ' S about racism , they say . English nationalism . retreat from the world . a conspiracy by the Right-wing medium . a plot to defund the NHS . even , and this be the good one , a coup d'état by the Russians . do you not realise that your Ukip-voting grandma in Cheriton Fitzpaine be a mole for the KGB ? well , now you know . now you know that Brexit be a vote on everything but the EU - it be a contemptible spasm of xenophobia and ignorance . if you believe that , as the liberal establishment do , then it make sense to try to reverse the vote . several peer have detail the plan openly . first , identify as many constitutional mechanism as possible to drag out debate and limit the government ' s negotiate position . secondly , use the next two year to run a PR campaign to influence the electorate . thirdly , establish the logic for a second referendum in which Briton will choose to stay in the EU after all . the strategy be technically possible and superficially clever . but Remainers be commit a terrible mistake - the same mistake make by Louis XVI . they be confirm the accusation of their most extreme critic . they be radicalising the situation . it be Nigel Farage who declare that Brexit would not end with Brexit - that it be just ` ` the first brick knock out of the Establishment wall . ' ' why ? because the sheer scale of opposition to Brexit have expose the existence of what he call a ` ` political class ' ' - not dissimilar to the aristocrat of old France . and every institution that house these counter-revolutionaries now find itself under scrutiny . the Lords have step into the spotlight , and the radical Eurosceptics have question . can we truly call peer such as Peter Mandelson or Neil Kinnock fair-minded when they receive such generous pension from the EU ? how can it be right that Ukip get @card@ per cent of the vote in the @card@ general election and yet have only three peer to speak for it - while the Europhile Lib Dems , who have just nine MP , enjoy more than @card@ member of the House of Lords ? the irony be that the Eurosceptics ask such question be overwhelmingly constitutional conservative : they vote leave out of love for Parliament and British tradition . to restore the greatness of the institution , they be now prepare to overthrow the institution themselves - and it be exactly that kind of iconoclasm that mark a revolutionary situation . the Eurosceptics be not the silly little fringe that Tony Blair and the Establishment still see them as be . they have the will of the people as express in a referendum behind them . and while the Lords do exist to question the action of the commons , it do not exist to contradict the verdict of the people . if the Lords be see to be do that , then there will be call for stuff them with Tory , make them elect , even abolish them altogether . the people will wave their little finger and they ' ll be go . I do n't want this . as I say , for most of us Brexit begin and end with Brexit , and be never suppose to be about anything else . but emotionally charge opposition be force voter to re-evaluate several aspect of our constitutional settlement . the Right be ask why they finance a BBC that , they allege , do n't give them a fair say . one half of the UK be ask why the other half should be allow to block the Brexit that they vote for . and the Labour Party , which be struggle to maintain a consensus that will get it through two perilous by-election , be split . Blair and his militant Remainers be help to kill it . one of the few institution that have emerge from Brexit with some strength be the Conservative party , even though it ' S probably the most divided party of all . Theresa May do the right thing . she hear the people sing and decide to make the song her own . for the sake of its own survival , I beg the Lords to join the sublime chorus of history . follow Tim Stanley on Twitter @ timothy_stanley ; Read More at www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion
