ignore the doom-mongers . Brexit should be a cause for optimism
last week I write on the outlook for the UK economy in the year ahead without even mention Brexit once . this be not accidental . nor be it because of a suspicion that you be all bore to death by the subject ( although you may well be ) . rather it reflect my judgment that the Brexit negotiation will not play a major role in determine how the economy fare this year . this may seem surprising . there be a widespread belief , fan by part of the medium , that our economic fate hang by a thread and if Brexit negotiation go badly then the economy could be in serious trouble . this be completely misguided . admittedly , the political world and the medium world that live off it will be on tenterhook for much of this year . each twist and turn of the negotiation will be report and analyse ad nauseam . yet the economy will trundle on much as before , whatever happen in the talk . as I never tire of tell people , on the whole , political event have next to no impact on immediate economic performance . this be determine by much more humdrum factor such as the growth of income or change in interest rate . similarly , the several serious political issue currently beset the European Union , include Catalonia , the impending Italian election , the absence of a German government and the increase alienation of Poland and Hungary , despite their long-term importance , be unlikely to dent the current expansionary phase in the eurozone economy . this be not to say that the term of Brexit be economically irrelevant . rather , their impact on the economy will unfold over several year . and even the long-term impact be not mechanistically determinate . it will depend largely on the policy decision that we make . nevertheless , at the beginning of the year in which many of the issue surround Brexit will become clearer it be appropriate to take stock . what have the effect be ? accord to the Treasury , the vote to leave be suppose to send the economy into recession . this turn out to be nonsense on stilt . even so , accord to Tony Blair , you can see the ill-effects of Brexit in everything from the crisis in the NHS to our poor productivity performance . I be surprise that he do not throw in recent extreme weather event for good measure . the truth be that whatever be wrong with the British economy at the moment - and there be quite a few thing - predate the Brexit vote and have next to nothing to do with it . in fact , last year ' s growth rate of a probable 1.8pc be only marginally low than the previous year ' S 1.9pc . this degree of difference be not worth quibbling about . it may reflect all sort of statistical quirk . moreover , it may even be revise away . admittedly , the UK have slip down the international growth table as other country ' growth have pick up . but this reflect difference in the timing of the economic cycle and probably wo n't last . true , some investment be defer but by the end of last year the overall impact of this appear to be minor . investment grow more strongly last year than it have in @card@ . where there have be a continue effect from Brexit , albeit indirectly , be on consumer spending . this have be hit by the squeeze on real income result from the rise in inflation that be cause by the fall of the pound . however , this effect be set to subside as inflation fall back . moreover , we should soon enjoy a substantial increase in export , reflect our improve competitiveness . there be clear sign that this be already happen . so , Brexit have contribute to the rebalance of the UK economy that have long be necessary . with regard to the eventual outcome of the negotiation we be still not at all sure what may transpire . future possible trading relationship with the EU range from some continued pseudo-membership of the custom union and single market , through to Theresa May ' s ` ` special partnership ' ' , which would involve tariff-free and interferencefree trade , to departure without a deal and trade on WTO rule . far from be a disaster as so many assume , if the EU do not play ball with May , this last outcome could in fact be the good . but even if we know this be go to be the outcome it would not fully dispel uncertainty . simply say that we will trade under WTO rule do not say anything specific about tariff rate . it would be consistent with impose tariff on import from the EU or keep such import tariff-free while abolish tariff on import from the rest of the world , and all station in between . WTO rule merely stipulate that whatever tariff rate be decide must be impose on all country - unless there be a free trade agreement in place . this uncertainty about our future relationship with the EU do not help business to plan or to invest . however , to portray this as a disaster for the UK economy , as so many Remainers do , be ridiculous . this be an attempt to serve up a reheat version of ` ` Project Fear ' ' . true , British export to the EU be an extremely important part of the economy . they account for about 12pc of our GDP . but this mean that about 88pc of the UK ' S GDP do not consist of export to the EU . moreover , whatever trade relationship be agree , the overwhelming bulk of existing EU-UK trade will continue . and whatever trade relationship be agree , the share of the EU in the UK ' S trade will continue to fall as the EU fade in relative importance in the world . there be good reason to be optimistic . if you be to embark on a major change to your trading and economic arrangement it be good to do this when the world economy be grow well and your currency be competitive . for the first time in many year , both these criterion be currently meet . Roger Bootle be chairman of Capital Economics roger.bootle @ capitaleconomics.com ' Brexit have contribute to the rebalance of the UK economy that have long be necessary '

A ' cliff-edge ' Brexit be just another name for Project Fear
the referendum campaign continue . proposal for transition period and the various scare story concern a ` ` cliff-edge ' ' be really project fear in disguise . the British public risk be mislead by the establishment - all over again . moreover , as Brexit shenanigan continue within the Conservative Party , you could be forgive for believe that the most serious issue at stake be the self-interest of those who be position themselves to become the next Prime Minister . some of our senior civil servant be hope that a combination of delay , only half-leaving , and the inexorable approach of the next election will see the cherished membership of the Union preserve in substance , if not in name . they be not do this for personal advancement but rather in pursuit of what they perceive to be the national interest . meanwhile , large established business and their lobbying organisation be , as usual , argue in favour of the status quo , which happen to protect them . the City be try to bamboozle minister , lack in both detailed financial knowledge and intellectual selfconfidence , with tale of its importance and future threat to its success if we do n't cling to something very close to EU membership . the Delayers ( aka the Remainers ) have try to gain advantage through the use of language . ` ` Hard ' ' Brexit seem to imply a reduction in our living standard , so if you support this type of Brexit presumably you accept the reduction as a price to be pay in order to recover sovereignty . yet there be no conflict between the recovery of sovereignty and economic self-interest . quite the reverse . Brexit can bring economic gain - escape from the EU ' s trade protectionism that oblige us to impose tariff on import from the rest of the world , and escape from its regulatory burden . this be what make yesterday ' s launch of a document call ` ` from Project Fear to Project Prosperity ' ' by economist for Free Trade ( EFT ) so significant . eft be comprise of a number of economist ( include me ) who believe that Britain ' s economic interest be well serve by Brexit , and a full Brexit at that - the sooner the better . the voice of consumer be seldom hear above the cacophony of special pleading by business interest . at the heart of our analysis be the large potential gain to consumer from low price make possible by Brexit . unless the UK can wring some remarkable concession from the EU , a transition period will delay these gain . supposedly , though , a transition period would avoid a ` ` cliff-edge ' ' in March @card@ . but would n't this simply put off the ` ` cliff-edge ' ' for two year ? in reality there be no cliff-edge . if we do not secure a free-trade agreement ( FTA ) with the EU by the time of our departure then trade can continue , albeit with EU tariff on British export . but we know that , on average , such tariff be trivial . where they be not , the low pound be a major offset . in any case , why should agree an FTA with the EU be so difficult ? why ca n't the essence of it simply be to continue with the status quo ? as the former Cabinet Minister , Peter Lilley , have point out , this be the first negotiation in history about an FTA between two party who currently do n't impose any tariff on each other . admittedly , a transition deal be allegedly also about buy time to ensure that custom procedure be fully adapt . yet most country undertake trade with the single market without run into custom problem . and custom procedure be now almost entirely electronic and undertake before good cross the border . why be the EU drag its foot about set up the relevant procedure and kit for trade with us ? of course , money be at the heart of this - lot of it . the public be be soften up for a sell-out by the British establishment under which it agree to pay huge sum to the EU . yet we should n't pay a penny for so-called ` ` access ' ' to the single market . what do America pay for such access ? or Singapore ? the answer be zilch . the suppose rationale for the idea of a large payment to the EU be that the latter ' s planning period run over several year and the UK have already sign up to the last one . yet the UK ' s acceptance of this financial plan be clearly predicate on the implicit assumption that we would continue to be a member of the EU and would meanwhile benefit therefrom . ( EU membership do provide benefit , do n't it ? ) the EU make no provision for a country leave . now that we be set to do so , it should simply redo its financial planning . and we should pay nothing after our membership end . the adoption of a transition period sound so mild and reasonable . but what should really worry you be that many of those push for one be not only on the lose side of the Brexit referendum but be also on the wrong side of the debate about join the euro . for most of the British establishment ( but not , in this case , the Treasury ) , this be another instance of stand on the wrong side of history . there they be , now stand by the ` ` cliff-edge ' ' , still try to tell us that they know good : gilded , cosset - and profoundly wrong . Roger Bootle be chairman of Capital Economics roger.bootle @ capitaleconomics.com ' the voice of consumer be seldom hear above the cacophony of special pleading by business '

Scotland can be a beacon for the UK after Brexit ; Letters to the Editor Holyrood ' S plan should be give a fair hearing - they could help to reduce cost by maximise trade
in what be the first comprehensive proposal by any administration within the UK to deal with the Brexit challenge , the Scottish Government have now publish its plan for Brexit , entitle ` ` Scotland ' s place in Europe ' ' . the Standing Council on Europe , an advisory body set up by the Scottish Government , which I chair , be consult on these proposal , which be develop by Scottish minister . as with any group of expert , we each bring specialist perspective and different shade of opinion on matter of detail . but the Standing Council be unanimous on the follow point : First , membership of ( not simply access to ) the European Single Market ( ESM ) be vital to protect the economic and social interest of the UK and Scotland . secondly , a Brexit which move away from membership of the ESM and the custom union will be extremely damaging to an economy such as the UK which rely so heavily on service export , or the export of manufacturing , where the supply chain be spread across Britain and Europe . there be no equivalence between a bespoke free-trade agreement ( FTA ) and membership of the single market . even if the UK be to negotiate tariff-free access to the EU , which be possible , it will be the non-tariff barrier that will damage our economy . this be especially the case in financial service . over two million job depend on this key sector , and £66 billion of tax revenue - much more than we pay into the EU budget - help sustain the NHS and other vital public service in Britain . what have catch the eye of a number of commentator about the Scottish Government ' S proposal be the notion of a so-called ` ` differentiate agreement ' ' . this mean that , in the event that the UK Government opt for a hard Brexit , outside of the custom union and the ESM , the Scottish Government want to explore the possibility of leave the EU but remain in the single market . to be clear , the proposal be one to keep Scotland within both the UK and the ESM : in essence , a ` ` parallel market ' ' solution . this would not imply a border within the UK single market for good . so any UK company wish to sell product to Scotland , or vice versa , would encounter no barrier . this be because the custom border would lie between the whole of the UK and the ESM . under the differentiate solution , the whole of the UK would leave the custom union . system of check good between Europe and the UK , include Scotland , would have to be set up as a result of Brexit , not as a result of the differentiate model . but be this be good for UK business ? by keep part of the UK within the ESM , there will be small loss in term of fall trade flow with Europe . this in turn will help to sustain economic activity in the whole of the UK . the Office for Budget Responsibility currently estimate that there will be around £15 billion in high borrowing per annum due to Brexit . there be challenge to be face . some worry that increasingly divergent regulation between Scotland and the UK over time could impact on intra-UK trade . but there be mechanism which could help here . for example , the UK and Scotland could coordinate their regulatory regime , perhaps by have a federal market authority , which seek to coordinate the ESM and UK regulatory framework both for business and product . one advantage of this be that it would keep UK good market regulation anchor more closely to that of the European Economic Area ( EEA ) : in essence Scotland would be an ` ` EEA beacon ' ' which UK regulator could follow . it would make it easy for UK export to trade with our EU neighbour . indeed , the differentiate model would work good if the negotiate FTA between the UK and the EU ensure maximum access . the selfconfident Brexit supporter , who believe that the UK negotiation with the EU-27 will go extremely well and will result in a bespoke UK zero-tariff FTA on good and great market access in service , should be extremely sanguine about a differentiate Scottish solution . in such a case the differentiate model would impact minimally on production and trade pattern within the UK . the propose differentiation in immigration rule between Scotland and Europe would not create difficulty in term of the free movement of people within the UK . as a City of London report show recently , a differential regional visa system , base on employer monitoring , and enforceable through the national insurance and tax system , have be use in Canada and Australia and would provide a differential solution that address regional skill need in different part of the UK . all of this be complex , but the only simple Brexit be UK-wide singlemarket membership outside the EU . beyond that any Brexit be complicate and very costly . these proposal can reduce cost by maximise trade and the flow of skill with European market . they deserve serious scrutiny . Professor Anton Muscatelli be the principal of the University of Glasgow

ask migrant : what can you do for Britain ? ; finally , for the first time in decade , we have the chance to put the need of British people first ; the BREXIT dividend
when Theresa May announce at the recent Cabinet awayday at Chequers that restrict EU immigration will be at the heart of the Brexit negotiation , you could almost hear the sound of @card@ million people collectively sigh with relief . they , like me , vote to leave the EU on June @card@ and , like me , they have be leave on tenterhook for week wait to find out precisely what our new Prime Minister actually mean when she say thing like ` ` Brexit mean Brexit ' ' . so , now we know that Mrs May want to control the number of European immigrant , the question still remain as to how she plan to do it . we now have the first opportunity in a generation to replace our current mess - to which the British people never consent - with sensible border control at long last , cut net immigration from @card@ a year to something more practical . while the minutia have yet to be work out , any new immigration should undoubtedly be base on one simple principle : it should unashamedly be for the benefit of the British people , and not for the benefit of those who want to come here . cue the anguish cry of horror from the pro-immigration brigade who fervently believe that it be Britain ' s job to offer a haven to the poor and huddle mass from every country under the sun . sorry , but it be n't . we have no duty of care to improve the lot of poor Romanian or Pole or Pakistani or anyone else who be not a British citizen . while I have nothing but admiration and respect for anyone who want to travel across a continent to make a new life for themselves and improve their lot , the reality be that British taxpayer do n't owe the rest of the world a living . we can offer trade deal or international aid , by all mean , and we should never desert asylum seeker in their time of need , but we do n't have a moral responsibility to open our door to the five billion-odd people on this planet who live in poor country than ours . instead , to paraphrase the former US President John F Kennedy , we should instruct would-be immigrant : ` ` Ask not what this country can do for you , ask what you can do for this country . ' ' if you have something to offer Britain , whether it be much-need qualification or skill , entrepreneurship , create job , or big wad of taxable cash , then by all mean do come in and make yourself at home , I ' ll put the kettle on . if , however , you have no qualification , no professional skill other than a drive licence , and can barely speak English , or you have a criminal record , then thanks but no thanks . if that sound harsh , then tough . while we be each lucky to be bear here in a wealthy country where we enjoy the rule of law and freedom , it be not a matter of luck that Britain be the country it be . Great Britain do n't just happen ; the British people create this country through decade and century of hard work , fight for democracy , the welfare state and all the other benefit we currently enjoy . that be why we have every right to close our door to economic migrant who will contribute less than they will take out - whether it be in term of work tax credit , housing and child benefit , or in publicly fund school , housing , healthcare and public transport . Britain be a very desirable place to live and , thanks to English be the world ' s international language , we be ideally place to pick the bright and the good to come to live and work here . so why be n't we more choosy ? the only sensible immigration policy be one use skills-based work permit . yes , that will involve more paperwork than an open-door policy , but most country manage it . and indeed , we already operate such a system for non-EU migrant , so it be hardly beyond the wit of man to devise one that operate across the board . currently , an EU citizen need to fill out more paperwork to get a Sainsbury ' s Nectar card than they do to come to Britain , so a little more red tape wo n't do anyone any harm . but there be one other crucial requirement that should also be at the heart of any new immigration policy , and that be the ability of new arrival to integrate and assimilate into British society . admittedly , this be a rather more difficult and subjective criterion than a university diploma , but it be just as vital - and especially after year in which mass immigration have enable many new arrival to live and work in entirely separate ethnic , religious or national community in many of our city . if you do n't want to learn English and you do n't embrace fundamental British value like democracy , woman ' S equality and the freedom to choose who you marry , then Britain be probably not the country for you . control immigration do n't require us to close our door to the rest of the world - far from it . but it do mean us get to decide who we want to live here and , for the first time in decade , put the need of the British people first . Julia Hartley-Brewer be a journalist , broadcaster and talkRADIO presenter

it be far from over for the leave side . the receive wisdom in Westminster be that the outer be all but finish , and that the only question now be how badly they will be thrash . that ' S nonsense . with four week leave , and the government now ban from deluge us with its taxpayer-financed propaganda under the purdah rule , anything remain possible . but the leave campaign face an increasingly difficult dilemma : as a broad Left-Right independence coalition , whose member disagree on just about everything other than the need for self-governance , it be find it tricky to articulate a strong macroeconomic case for Brexit . this be become a major issue , especially for more prosperous , middle-class , centrist and Toryleaning voter in London and across the country , who be crave reassurance that it ' S safe to vote for Brexit . many Telegraph reader fall into this camp ; and we all have friend , relative and neighbour who be vacillate , wonder whether maybe - especially the Treasury ' s analysis of the short-term consequence of leave - they be a scandalously unethical concoction of a kind eerily reminiscent of Tony Blair ' s dodgy dossier prior to the Iraq war . but the fact that they be flaw do n't mean that their argument can be ignore . it be desperately important that the economic case for Brexit be make much more vigorously . it need to be divide into two component : a takedown of the EU as an ultimately doom , job-destroying , decline and mismanage behemoth that stand no chance in an increasingly agile , globalised world ; and the mapping out of a clear exit strategy , compatible with leave ' S objective , that show how we would maintain and enhance our openness to the world . the message must be clear : we would be good off out - in term of job , wage and growth . the cost of leave will be small than the benefit , and this would become evident within a few year of leave . the core assumption of the anti-Brexit economist be that leave would erect damaging barrier to trade ; the pro-Brexit side must take on and demolish these argument . the good news be that it ' S quite easy to do so . the leave campaign ' s long-term aim be to break away completely from the EU . but there be no doubt that , be we to vote leave on June @card@ , the UK would seek to adopt , as an interim solution , a Norwegian-style relationship with the EU which ensure that we remain in the single market , give us plenty of time to work out new arrangement with the rest of the world . that be both the only realistic way we would quit the EU - the only model that , plausibly , MP would support as a cross-party compromise deal - and the good possible way for us to do it . the Norwegians would welcome us with open arm , as their own influence would be enhance , and other EU nation would seek to join us . such a deal would eliminate most of the cost of leave , while deliver a hefty dose of benefit as a down-payment . as part of the European Free Trade Association , we would remain in the single market , complete with its four freedom , while withdraw from agricultural and fishery policy , justice , home affair and the custom union . the City would n't lose access and virtually all of the anti-Brexit scare story would be neutralise , which be presumably why that option be mysteriously absent from the Treasury ' s ludicrous analysis of the short-term impact of Brexit . we would save money : Norway ' s net contribution per person be low than Britain ' S . we would have to follow few rule : Norway have adopt @card@ out of @card@ EU directive , and just @card@ out of @card@ EU regulation . so Norway have be force to swallow just @card@ per cent of the total ` ` acquis communautaire ' ' , against all of it for the UK . leave the EU and join EFTA would make us more , rather than less , influential . we have only a small share of the vote in Brussels and can thus easily be outvote . but Norway , which have technically no vote , have regularly mould key rule , include the Consumer Rights Directive . the real reason why we - as a large and powerful economy - would have great influence in EFTA than in the EU be that Brussels be increasingly not the place where big decision take place . rule be increasingly negotiate under the auspice of global body : automotive norm be determine by the World Forum for the harmonisation of Vehicle Regulations ; food standard be determine by Codex Alimentarius ; naval rule be under the aegis of the International Maritime Organisation ; and the crucial new banking regulation be be determine by the Financial Stability Board . these regulation be then pass down , with the odd gold-plate , by the EU . these global body proceed by consensus , not qualify majority ; we be currently represent by the EU at these meeting . a Brexit would allow us to have a seat at these top table , and thus to disintermediate Brussel . we would also be able to sign free-trade deal with country such as China : the EU have prove incompetent at this task , partly because it need the agreement of all @card@ member . the Brexit revolution have fan the flame of a hard-left rebellion ; the Tory Right think a post-EU debate would be on their term - now they have to save capitalism
revolution often end up a long way from where they start . a year after triumph in the Brexit referendum , many conservative learn this the hard way during a brutally disappointing election night . the rebellious spirit that carry them to victory last June have seem sure to manifest itself again by lift the Tories , the newly commit champion of Brexit , to unprecedented height . instead , like a train switch track , the momentum suddenly turn and take a hard Left . with the government now in paralysis , Tory Brexiteers be in danger of lose control of the revolution they begin . history be full of example of campaign and rebellion that , once start , unleash new political current and take up new cause . yesterday it be sovereignty . today , austerity . my current reading , a history of the Habsburg Empire , seem to be full of analogous event . the book , a revisionist take by Pieter Judson , be n't quite explicit about map the EU on to the Habsburg Empire , but it argue that nationhood be a recent , contingent invention in Europe and that ordinary European be just as capable of loyalty to a supranational authority . this be , of course , music to the ear of EU federalist . like the EU , though , the Habsburg Empire run into trouble because it have a centralise tendency that often rub its subject up the wrong way . in @card@ , tire of Vienna ' S supremacy , a group of Polish landowner try to re-establish an independent Polish state . they gather their force and march into Galicia , a Habsburg territory that straddle modern-day Poland and Ukraine , hope to rally the peasant to their cause . but instead of join the noble , the peasant massacre them . the violence be so bad that Vienna intervene to protect the rebel . what the lord have fail to realise be that , to the Galician peasant , the reformist Habsburg Empire offer the prospect of emancipation . local rule mean continued serfdom and forced labour . two year later , with revolution sweep Europe , the noble have another chance . this time , like Boris Johnson and Michael Gove with their ` ` £350 million to the NHS ' ' bus , the landowner be fall over themselves to make appealing promise about the end of forced labour . unfortunately for them , the Habsburg governor announce the emancipation of the peasant one day before the noble have plan to do the same and their populist drive be puncture . political movement do n't succeed unless they maintain support from a wide alliance of interest . you might think you ' re start a revolution about sovereignty , until suddenly it turn into a fight over emancipation - or austerity . for Brexiteers like Mr Gove and many pro-immigration , Tory internationalist I know , Brexit be purely about democratic control . but they rally voter against a centralise and remote foreign rule by include a wide range of juicy promise in their programme , from immigration cut to public service funding . unfortunately , political alliance be unstable and it be easy to mistake voter ' instinct and mood for commitment to a cause , particularly if it be a cause you have champion for decade . it be always the elite who chafe most against EU authority . the unauthorised transfer of power from Westminster to Brussels be most keenly feel by those accustom to wield power . that do not mean that voter do not understand or care about it . it just be n't their top priority . it be not easy to influence what their priority be , particularly after a political upset . this time last year , immigration be far the most important issue to most voter , accord to YouGov . since then , the importance place on health have rise dramatically . Tory Brexit campaigner know that the referendum would open up policy area that have be ignore or outsourced for many year , like immigration , agricultural policy and state aid . this be , indeed , the point . but they think the battle over the interpretation of Brexit would be on Right-wing territory , whether it be about free trade and a ` ` global Britain ' ' or a Nigel Farage-ist emphasis on sharp immigration cut . their hope be that Britain would move in a Tory direction , towards deregulation and economic competitiveness . what they never consider be the possibility that Britain might leave the EU only to embrace radical socialism . Brexit seem to have throw all sort of taboo out of the window and conservative now find themselves in a pitched battle to save capitalism . who could have predict that the anniversary of the referendum would be greet by Corbyn-mania at Glastonbury ? who consider that Brexit Britain want to be neither Singapore nor little England , but Greece ? all of this be under way as the Brexit negotiation begin . the political instability have leave the interpretation of Brexit down to an unpredictable tussle between Parliament and a hamstrung government . the dynamic be not favourable for Tories . every concession the government make will feed support for a Labour Party run by the hard Left . meanwhile , the Right face a difficult challenge . make the case for Right-wing idea would be a start , but in itself be n't enough . like the Polish nationalist in Galicia , conservative need to construct a new proposition for voter - one potent enough to rival the prospect of Labour ' S largesse . whether that means rebranding the NHS bus again , build more home or offering incentive to make Britain a nation of owner and saver , it be just as important as make the ideological argument . as Brexit pressure mount , we must remain open for business
ahead of last year ' S referendum , I be optimistic about Britain ' s future outside of the European Union . I still strongly believe that the country make the right decision to leave the EU and that business and the economy will thrive . but the short-term impact and opportunity arise from Brexit will only ever be as good as the execution of the separation and how it be negotiate . and I fear that , unless action be take on two front , we be head towards a very sub-optimal outcome . with regard to the Brexit negotiation , money need to be front and centre . most recently , we have see the Prime Minister generously offer approximately £20bn in payment to the EU during the propose transition period , without have a firm EU-UK trade deal in place post-Brexit . unless the EU begin trade talk without further delay , we will - to use a phrase coin by Lord Bridges , the former minister from the Department of Exiting the EU - be discuss Britain ' S gangplank , rather than the bridge to our final post-Brexit destination . government negotiator should also have the confidence to spell out to the EU ' s negotiator what the consequence will be of fail to agree term of trade with Britain , specifically the full implication of not have access to our market . in essence , our position ought to be that we will not pay a penny unless we have proper access to EU market on fair term ; and that if we do n't get that access , the EU should not expect to have access to our market on fair term . on the other hand , we should make clear what our financial offer would be , should we reach appropriate term , as an inducement for European government to put pressure towards a settlement . such an offer should be spread over a number of year , say @card@ , to help ensure adherence to the deal . thus , for instance , £5bn a year over @card@ year as a carrot , or nothing if no deal be reach . Jean-Claude Juncker ' s recent ` ` state of the union ' ' address be a timely reminder of the EU ' s direction of travel . government across the EU listen patiently to what he have to say and several reply : ` ` no , thank you ' ' . this lay bare the divergent interest of the European Commission and the member state that pay for it and provide a useful reminder to British voter that the EU be still on an integrationist track . on the domestic front , the Prime Minister provide a defence of free enterprise to a Bank of England audience , shortly before the Conservative party conference . but these word now need to be match by a policy vision to support wealth creation in a post-Brexit Britain . we need more pro-business policy ; more commitment to deregulation ; more encouragement for small business ; and more tax incentive . as well as aspire to be the number one trading destination in Europe , we should aim to make Britain the number one destination in Europe for entrepreneur to set up . one only have to look at how clever both Ireland and Luxembourg have be with their tax policy and measure design to encourage talented people to go there . the priority for a pro-business agenda be simple : deregulate - red tape continue to exert an especially onerous burden on SMEs that lack the resource to handle regulatory compliance ; cut corporation tax - create a globally competitive tax regime encourage business to be in Britain and will enlarge the overall tax take ; give SMEs employ under @card@ people a more flexible employment regime - enable firm to manage a change commercial environment and reduce the regulatory downsides of hiring ; Focus government grant - adopt the Israeli model where the government match start-up funding for technology business . in the UK , funding should be available to start-up outside of the South East in sector where British ingenuity be world-class , such as pharma , biotech and medical device ; Commit to infrastructure - upgrade originally promise to realise the economic potential of the Northern Powerhouse initiative should be build without delay ; Expand capacity at both Heathrow and Gatwick - airport capacity be vital to Britain ' S future ; cut stamp duty on housing - the high rate of stamp duty have cause tax take to fall as the top end of the housing market become illiquid , discouraging foreign wealth creator that want to live and work in the UK . the clock be tick - the conservative have four and a half year to put in place measure to fundamentally improve the economy . if they succeed , they can win the next election . Fail and Britain may face the seemingly unthinkable prospect of a Labour government lead by Jeremy Corbyn . the stake be high and the government face two challenge , not just one . Howard Kerr , the chief executive of the BSI which bestow the ' Kitemark ' symbol , say the move will commit the UK to maintain some @card@ industrial and technical standard in order to facilitate ` ` frictionless ' ' trade after Brexit . ` ` the preference in industry and government be for the UK to continue to trade use single standard across Europe and for the UK be a full member of the three [ European standard ] agency , ' ' he say in an interview . the BSI , which be a private body that operate under a UK government mandate from the Department of Trade , be already in the process of formally request the right to remain a member of the European Committee for Standardisation ( Cen ) after Brexit . the move will require Cen and two other European standard organisation to re-write their membership statute to enable Britain to re-join when the UK become a non-EU country . the BSI and Government be quietly confident this will happen . Cen , and its sister-organisations CENELEC and ETSI which produce electro-technical and telecoms standard , be not European Union body , and include EEA member state like Norway as well as EU accession country , like Turkey and Serbia , among their membership . the government commit to remain a full member of the three body in the Brexit White Paper earlier this year as a means of retain British influence in the creation of global standard . however , the move will raise some question about the extent to which Brexit will enable the UK to diverge from EU standard , with some @card@ per cent of publish European standard be develop ` ` as a result of request from the European Commission ' ' , accord to the White Paper . ` ` as a full future member of the European future standard system , with harmonise standard and national adoption of those standard , it would not be possible for the UK to diverge on harmonise EU standard [ after Brexit ] , ' ' Mr Kerr concede . in theory it would remain possible to create specific UK standard for product be sell solely in the UK market , but in practice Mr Kerr say business have no appetite for create cumbersome dual standard regime . ` ` why would business want different standard for trading in the UK ? Business want to make product once , to one single standard , ' ' he add . the adherence to EU product standard could have a bearing on Britain ' s ability to cut trade deal with the rest of the world , accord to Prof Alan Winters , director of the UK Trade Policy Observatory at Sussex University . ` ` the UK will be negotiate with third country , but with a good deal less muscle than the EU , ' ' he say . ` ` the EU have more ability to lean on a partner to accept their standard , but it will be the same dynamic . ` ` take control ' ' - actually mean something . ` ` strong and stable ' ' do not . so the idea , last year , be to serve up an inspiring message that would lead million to back change . lesson one : hope sell . perhaps it be because Mrs May do not support Brexit that she never quite see the need to frame it as be open and globalist . as Vote leave know from the offset , they would be accuse of be xenophobic little Englander with no interest in life beyond the English Channel . so they choose internationalist argument : why , they ask , do we discriminate against immigrant from non-EU country ? why not trade fairly with the Third World ? and yes , let ' s offer immediate and unconditional assurance to every single EU migrant in Britain : we need them , they can stay . but it be a cold , mean version of Brexit that Mrs May end serve up in the election . the warm version that Boris Johnson work on - offer unilateral security to EU migrant , emphasise good relation with European neighbour - be a policy that end up be steal by the Labour Party . the Tories find themselves look a bit like ( as someone once put it ) the nasty party . it be as if the Conservatives have grow addict to the negative campaigning deploy in the Scottish referendum then by Remain . when so much be at stake , voter want more than to be tell to fear the other side . lesson two : project fear do n't work . then come the great Brexit variety show . vote leave ' s two star striker be Boris and Michael Gove , but if you do n't like them then there be the Labour MP Kate Hoey and Gisela Stuart . in fact , if you find Boris a bit too wet - with his declaration of be ` ` passionately pro-immigration ' ' - then there be Nigel Farage , with his ( to me , repulsive ) point about HIV-infected migrant and his notorious ` ` break Point ' ' poster show Syrian refugee . and then the other outrider : business for Britain , Muslims for Britain , Labour leave , Out and Proud . so the Brexit campaign have a great many people with a great many message . a contrast to the @card@ Tory general election campaign which only feature one Tory : Mrs may herself . if you find her indecisive , robotic , power-hungry ( or all three ) then there be n't an alternative . it be Jeremy Corbyn who use outrider group - like his momentum and other leftwing campaigner - with different message spread on digital platform to reach young voter , two third of whom turn up . lesson three : coalition win campaign . perhaps the strong weapon in Vote leave ' S arsenal be its claim that Britain send £350 million a week to the EU , and that this could be well spend on priority like the National Health Service . monstrous lie , say Remain : factor in the rebate and the real figure be far low . and to be sure , the real sum that Vote leave be promise for the NHS be close to £100 million a week . but whether you believe the big or the small figure , the overall impression be the same : there ' d be a lot more money for the NHS after Brexit . and here be something else that Theresa May lack in the election : a firm offer for voter . none of this be genius : time change , and successful campaign change with them . politician take note and adapt : or do , if they want to win majority . but give that the Tories might find themselves fight another campaign at any moment , it might be worth thinking about a message that go beyond attack the other chap . in all of the drama of the last year , the Tories have lose sight of what people vote for in the referendum . it be not about use EU national as bargaining chip , or snarl at Brussels . it be about retrieve sovereignty while manage immigration well , disengage from the European Union while find good way to be good European . this be not about a hard Brexit or soft Brexit - neither of which mean anything - but an open Brexit , one that let Britain well engage with the rest of the world . a rather compelling agenda , and one that ' S still there for the taking . follow Fraser Nelson on Twitter @ FraserNelson ; read more at www.telegraph.co.uk/ opinion

zero . what make the current difficult period especially problematic be the profound weakness of the British government . at the good of time , politician be not usually bless with a good grasp of New Zealand ' s trade minister Todd McClay say something similar recently : ` ` we have signal our interest in a free trade agreement with [ the UK ] when they be in a position to negotiate one independently of the European Union . ' ' it matter very much whether this be right , for two reason . first , if the UK can not even commence trade negotiation with other country until after it leave the EU , that mean ( give such negotiation take at least a few year to conclude and ratify ) that after it leave , Britain will have no trade agreement other than its post-Brexit EU deal . secondly , trade negotiation tend to turn out good for whichever country have strong ` ` outside option ' ' , so the UK ' s deal with the EU be likely to be good for us if we have credible deal with non-EU country in the pipeline . fortunately , the answer be that Hammond , Ciobo and the rest be wrong . they be wrong legally , in term of what the treaty demand . and they be wrong in term of pragmatic politics . Let ' s see why . the main bar to the UK negotiate its own pre-Brexit agreement with non-EU country be that , while the UK be a member of the EU , it have to stick to the rule and let the EU negotiate its trade deal . but the EU ' s pre-eminence in trade negotiation flow from treaty give it competence over the ` ` common commercial policy ' ' of member state . of course , the UK ' s post-Brexit trade policy be not part of the common commercial policy of the EU . so the EU have no more competence over it than it do over the trade policy of Brazil or Russia . moreover , it be a general principle that there can not be a competence when there be not a power . since the EU do not have the power to make new trade deal for the UK after Brexit , it can not claim competence over the making of them . even if strike our own deal be not narrowly legal under the treaty , the UK be withdraw from them , and repeal the European Communities Act @card@ , which be the mechanism by which they have legal effect in the UK . once we have do that , whether we abide by the treaty in every detail be a matter of politeness and realpolitik , not law . why would we want to accept the principle that we should have no post-Brexit trade deal ? it should be obvious that this be unacceptable and we shall not accept it . indeed , the @card@ member state who will remain in the EU after we leave rightly expect that the UK will not use its current , notional voting right to interfere with EU plan that will come into effect only after the UK leave the EU . for example , a few day ago German defence minister Ursula von der Leyen warn the UK against interfere with plan for an EU army . quite right . why should we get to stop the EU do thing that will come into effect after we leave ? the obvious pragmatic quid pro quo be that the EU can not expect to stop the UK do our deal for after we leave . the UK should not accept that we can not negotiate such agreement until after we have leave the EU . we can and should negotiate and ratify these deal , start now . until we get that straight in our own mind , we will never make the good of the opportunity such deal will offer . Britain and the EU can have a great free trade future
the Prime Minister be well aware that repeating ` ` Brexit mean Brexit ' ' be not go to suffice for long so when she make her speech outline the government ' s strategy for Brexit negotiation she be also aware she ' d need to outline specific plan with some clarity . the White Paper on the United Kingdom ' s exit from and new partnership with the European Union confirm and elaborate on what she say . on the issue of membership of the single market she could not have be clear or indeed more emphatic . the UK will not be a member of the single market after Brexit . but there be also question about the government ' s position on the custom union . here the answer Theresa May give , and the position in the White Paper , be a little more ambiguous . what the Prime Minister essentially say about no longer be bind by the common external tariff and have our own schedule at the WTO mean that the UK will no longer be part of the custom union . however , she go on to signal a clear desire to put some form of agreement in place to preserve frictionless trade with EU member state . this be a sensible response to what must be do in the negotiation . detailed research by the Legatum Institute ' S special Trade Commission set out how tariff and non-tariff barrier that might apply outside of the custom union can be manage or indeed avoid altogether . ideally a comprehensive Free Trade Agreement ( FTA ) will be agree and ready to come into force on the day after Brexit , under which the UK and the EU decide not to apply tariff or quota to import from each other . this be n't the end of the story . a custom union be an arrangement where two or more country agree to apply the same tariff and custom control on good come into their territory . they can then eliminate tariff and custom control on good . FTAs include provision reduce and eliminate tariff on good trade between the party , but do not control the party ' trade policy with other country . so under an FTA good must still be subject to custom control for various reason , include to ensure that only good that actually originate in one of the country benefit from preferential tariff . if one of the party have low or no tariff on a particular product than another , exporter could circumvent one country ' S tariff by ship their good through the other . so this be where the rule of origin come in - a mechanism to determine what country an item originate from and in what circumstance it can therefore benefit from the FTA . the complexity come where product comprise part or ingredient from several source . if tariff-free trade be agree with the EU all exporter will need time to assess the make-up of their product . this be not the system whilst Britain be a member of the custom union and move away from that may mean a phase introduction of rule of origin will be necessary . as describe in our paper , one way of do this would be for us to commit to keep the same tariff and quota as the EU as against the rest of the world for a short period of adjustment , say , a year . both side could then waive requirement to prove the origin of good we import from each other during that transition period . agree a full FTA be a challenging goal in the time allow by Article @card@ , but it be possible , and permissible under WTO rule , to agree zero tariff and quota between the two side for a limited period of time , in anticipation of an eventual FTA . even if the EU will not agree to this , there be way to mitigate the impact of tariff . the fall in the pound will allow many manufacturer to absorb the import duty , and integrated supply chain will be protect by the availability of inward and outward processing relief , which mean that duty be not payable on part that cross border as part of a supply chain until they be import as a product for sale on the market . if the EU impose tariff on our import , Britain would have the right to impose the same tariff on import from the EU , but while this could deliver significant revenue for the treasury it would increase price , especially food price , for ordinary consumer . the government could choose to keep EU import tariff free - a huge step with repercussion for UK farmer and manufacturer . it would also mean that other country might have less incentive to reduce their tariff on import from the UK , so while consumer would benefit from low price and more competition , the longer-term gain from FTAs with established and emerge market could be threaten . this may look risky , but our report describe how a balance could be strike by selectively reduce and eliminate tariff on good that the UK do not produce or compete with , or where the tariff be very low . this would shield consumer from price rise , while maintain our negotiation position with supplier country . ultimately , being outside the custom union will allow the UK to reduce and eliminate tariff and quota as part of a global free trade agenda . the commercial interest on both side strongly point towards these interim measure be agree in time for the kind of phase implementation envisage by Mrs May . to paraphrase Mrs May , it would indeed be an extraordinary act of self-harm for the European Union not to deliver the minimal level of cooperation to realise first the necessary interim measure , and then the final comprehensive FTA . Shanker A. Singham , chairman , Legatum Institute special Trade Commission , and Victoria Hewson , senior counsel ' be outside the custom union will allow the UK to reduce tariff as part of a global free trade agenda '

Brexit - whether you welcome it or not - provide a game-changing opportunity for Africa and the UK . outside the custom union , the new government could fundamentally change its relationship with the country of the continent to the advantage of both Africa and the UK . these benefit have be identify in a report from a committee of distinguished African and British politician and business leader . their inquiry into the UK ' S effort to boost trade in Africa through the Africa Free Trade Initiative gather evidence from more than @card@ expert over six month . the report , publish a fortnight ago , do not shy away from the significant short-term challenge to trade pose by Brexit . but these be eclipse by what Ali Mufuruki , the Tanzanian entrepreneur who cochaired the inquiry , describe as the ` ` big prize ' ' . Brexit , the inquiry conclude , provide ` ` an opportunity for the UK to lead the world in structure a pro-development trade policy with Africa ' ' . the example of the US show what could be achieve . through the Africa Growth and Opportunity Act ( AGOA ) , almost all product from the continent now have duty-free entry into the US . this have be couple with a package of trade-boosting summit , mission , business council and regional trade hub . the impact for both Africa and US business have be dramatic . the Act be credit since @card@ with create more than a million job in Africa and generate more than $ 26bn in dutyfree export to the US . at the same time us export to sub-Saharan Africa have quadruple . it all point to what the UK could do . some critic of Brexit accept that the UK will now have the freedom to alter trade policy in favour of support African development but doubt the institutional bandwidth exist to develop a set of enlightened trade policy . they believe all our effort will be expend instead on try to agree trade deal with the world ' s big economy . but if British policymaker require motivation , then they should take a sideward glance at Turkey . Brexit give the UK a chance to strike a bold and ambitious deal with African country , focus on trade as the route out of poverty . take the good from AGOA , it should combine easy access to the UK for African exporter , more investment from the aid budget to build Africa ' s trade capacity , and world-beating infrastructure on the ground to get deal flow . the Africa Prosperity Partnership , as it could be call , would then be the gold standard of trade and development policy the world over . it would be a powerful motor for employment and prosperity across Africa . importantly too , it would offer the well possible proof that Britain outside the EU be a force for good internationally and provide a sharp riposte to those who believe Brexit mean our retreat from the world . big business must take some blame for Brexit ; firm have use cheap foreign labour as a lazy substitute for investment in training and productivity
how naive can you get ? Downing Street ' s attempt to strong arm big business into sign a letter of support for the nation ' S still confuse Brexit strategy be almost bind to backfire , and so it have . large number of corporate boss have angrily refuse to sign , and many have express astonishment that they be even ask in the first place . have no-one at Number @card@ notice that global business be vehemently oppose to Brexit , and indeed continue to regard it as a historic mistake , for which Britain will pay a high economic cost ? still bruise and resentful over the electorate ' S decision , global CEO be in no mood to cheerlead the endeavour . they might nevertheless try a little self reflection . in no small measure , it be their own behaviour that lead directly to today ' s state of affair . I say this as someone who be both generally sympathetic to the interest of business and the City , and who support Remain ; if the vote for Brexit be , at least in part , a backlash against globalisation and mass immigration , then these lobby have much to answer for . company have be only too happy to avail themselves of the benefit of cheap foreign labour and good . in so do , many of them have shamefully neglect their wide social responsibility . why recruit and train locally when it be possible to hire the necessary skill at a fraction of the cost from overseas ? one answer to this question , I suppose , be that with the economy begin to run up against acute labour shortage , we need the migrant supplement . despite the surge in European migrant , unemployment be close to a record low and the number of job at a record high . as a percentage of the unemployed , vacancy have also never be high . even with mass migration , and even with the displacement effect of automation and artificial intelligence , it ' s prove hard to get the staff . yet despite these shortage , the labour market be not behave as it should . though technology be probably the great cause of this malfunction , mass migration have undoubtedly play some part . too often , firm have use cheap foreign worker as a lazy substitute for investment in training and productivity . the effect have be distinctly unhealthy . for almost a decade now , growth per capita have be at a virtual standstill . real wage growth have be similarly non-existent . as I say , this can not all be blame on immigration . lack of significant wage inflation be common to nearly all advanced economy , even those without much immigration . take Japan , which have a shrink workforce , little immigration to speak of , exceptionally low unemployment , and a prime minister who routinely urge his business leader to pay their worker more . yet still it have virtually no nominal wage growth . in any case , the traditional yardstick by which government judge their economic success - low unemployment and sustained growth in overall gross domestic product - do n't mean a lot if people do n't feel any well off . Brexit supporter would not be have their ` ` independence day ' ' but for these wide social frustration . but business leader would not be face the challenge of Brexit have they be a little more responsive to the socially unsettling downsides of globalisation and mass migration . whether displace by a migrant or a machine , worker need help in adapt and reskilling for alternative , higher-paid work . the good company offer that progression ; too many do n't . one of the first rule of business be that you try not to kill the goose that lay the golden egg . by embrace free movement and borderless trade so enthusiastically , many firm have do precisely that , and thereby bring Brexit on themselves . few issue speak more loudly to the contradiction at the heart of Brexit than free movement . both Liam Fox and David Davis come over all misty eye when extol the suppose benefit of free trade ; their ambition , once unchain from the EU , be for a global , free-trading Britain . yet the intellectual justification for free trade be almost exactly the same as for the repudiate free movement . both rest on the idea of ` ` comparative advantage ' ' - that if a country or individual can supply something more cheaply than we can , it be economically more advantageous to buy from them , keep the saving and focus on what we do well . a virtuous circle of economic enhancement be thereby establish . in some respect , free movement be an extension of the same principle . yet it be pointless tell people that immigration be good for them if they can not feel it in their pocket . assume effective border control be eventually introduce , we face an interesting economic experiment . will restriction on immigration make us poor , as some company believe ? or will they act much like the Black death in the 14th century , create an extreme shortage of labour that kickstarts decent level of wage inflation . if the latter , many will think it a pretty good outcome . follow Jeremy Warner on Twitter @ JEREMYWARNERUK ; read more at www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion

we need a new vision to fight the religion of European integration
my attempt last week to shoot down ten canard about Brexit leave a major question unanswered . why do so many intelligent and well-meaning people wish to stay in the EU ? some do so because they believe one or more of the fallacious argument that I attack last week . I hope my duck shoot give them food for thought . and there be a few more canard flap across the landscape . one of the juicy be the idea that the improvement in the UK economy that have take place since we join the EU in @card@ have happen because of our membership . accordingly , some people associate Brexit with a return to the condition that exist prior to our entry , include dreadful coffee and ubiquitous all-day breakfast . in practice , of course , nearly all country in the world have enjoy the benefit of economic growth over this period . another argument , although not quite a canard , concern the reaction of foreigner to Brexit . there be a widespread fear that foreign-own firm will fail to invest in the UK and/ or withdraw or scale down their operation here . this fear encompass the auto sector , Japanese investment in all sort of manufacturing and investment from all around the world in the City of London . in practice , this argument involve a good deal of circularity for if Brexit really be n't that bad for the UK economy , and indeed may actually be beneficial then , give very low tariff , foreign firm be unlikely to scale down or withdraw their operation in the UK . there be also a fear that the EU will punish the UK , include through the operation of various non-tariff barrier . this be not daft . but it would be against the EU ' s own economic interest . and whatever the Commission ' S inclination , not many European firm or consumer would favour this approach . so its scope will be limit . more tellingly , it be widely believe that , although the eurozone have have its fair share of travail , nevertheless there be potentially major economic advantage to be have from size and integration . accordingly , by cut ourselves off , the UK will be settle for an inferior economic out-turn . this may not be obvious at first but the cost and disadvantage will build up over time . similarly , there be a legitimate argument that although it be perfectly possible for the UK to choose policy after Brexit that will bring a net economic benefit - zero tariff on all import , for instance - in practice , a combination of economic ignorance and political pressure will mean that we do not adopt such policy . consequently , Brexit will lead to fall in trade , with a consequent hit to productivity and investment . more generally , leave to its own device , the UK be likely to make bad economic decision on tax , government spending , regulation and the environment . Remainers be , of course , welcome to this belief but the evidence surely scream the opposite . the cost of EU membership be set to increase sharply as it integrate and control more , and its decision-making and policy choice be likely to be bad than those that we would make in pursuit of our own interest . many opponent of Brexit be particularly concern about reduce immigration - ostensibly for economic reason . they associate the number of immigrant , regardless of their skill , with wealth creation . they be confuse the overall size of GDP with GDP per capita . it be true that , other thing equal , the few people we admit then the small our overall economy will be . but so what ? no one eat aggregate GDP statistic . on the opposite tack , some opponent of Brexit openly downplay GDP against consideration of war and peace . they believe that the European Union be responsible for continued peace in Europe since @card@ . this argument be not to be lightly dismiss . peace and the preservation of human life surely trump mere economics . but most Eurosceptics do not believe that the EU be the source of peace in post-war Europe . this have rather be due to the combination of Nato , nuclear weapon and a change set of attitude on the part of ordinary European people that have nothing to do with the EU . more generally , a large part of the opposition to Brexit be political and people use economic argument , include the various canard that I have bring down , as cover for their political view . they value the development of a common European identity and they associate this with the EU . equally , they be suspicious of a purely national identity , and perhaps especially of a British national identity . some actively dislike Britain and Britishness . for such people , economic argument may cut little ice . their Europeanism be close to be a religion . feeling , or want to feel , ` ` European ' ' be understandable . I feel European myself . but European identity be not the same as belong to a common European political entity . there be Europe well before the EU . and there can be Europe outside the EU , or even well after it . counter the religion of European political integration may require the adoption of a new vision . it should surely concentrate on the concept of global Britain . admittedly , there be Brexiteers who nurse a nostalgic , warm beer and village cricket , view of Britain outside the EU . this often feature in the caricature that Remainers like to attack . but most of the lead light behind Brexit be not like this . they see the EU as an inwardlooking , protectionist bloc that be fade in relative importance at just the time that the rest of the world be open up and develop . Britain ' S future can readily involve a close relationship and deep friendship with the country of the EU while simultaneously set our sight over the horizon , economically , politically and culturally . the vision of the future that the government should actively promote be of an outward-facing but proudly independent Britain , play a full part on the world stage . that be a future well worth strive for - and vote for . Roger Bootle be chairman of Capital Economics roger.bootle @ capitaleconomics.com ' I feel European myself . but European identity be not the same as belong to a common European political entity '

there be two strategy that a country can adopt during moment of national emergency . the bold be for Left and Right to come together in a unity government , put aside their difference to fight for a common purpose . this reduce the space for democratic dissent , and risk enshrine groupthink , but it can be a vital way forward in extreme circumstance . it allow the government to speak on behalf of the vast majority , rather than merely one party , which be especially useful in time of war .
